- **Deity or Energy Form**: Śiva as Paśupati—depicted in earliest Indus Valley seals in yogic posture surrounded by animals; one of the five primary aspects of Śiva (Sadyojāta, Vāmadeva, Aghora, Tatpuruṣa, Īśāna); venerated especially in the famous Paśupatināth temple in Nepal
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: In Śaiva sādhana, meditation on Paśupati represents recognition that one's individual consciousness (paśu-bhāva) is not separate from supreme consciousness; the yogi moves from identifying as paśu (bound animal nature) to recognizing identity with Paśupati (the lord/consciousness itself)
- **Mantric Significance**: The pañcākṣara mantra "Namaḥ Śivāya" is essentially an offering to Paśupati; Vedic śatarudrīya hymn addresses Rudra-Paśupati repeatedly
- **Dharmic Significance**: Liberation (mokṣa) in Śaivism is the recognition that paśu and Pati were never truly separate—the bound soul realizes itself as Śiva; devotion (bhakti) to Paśupataye is the path of recognizing the lord as both transcendent protector and one's own innermost Self
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad, Śaiva Āgamas, Paśupata Sūtras, Rudra hymns of Yajurveda, Śiva Purāṇa
पश्यति:
# पश्यति
**Transliteration**: paś-ya-ti
**POS**: verb (3rd person singular, present indicative active)

**Root Analysis**:
- √दृश् (dṛś) – "to see, perceive, behold" + शप् (śap) present class marker + ति (ti) 3rd person singular ending = पश्यति (paśyati) "he/she/it sees, perceives, beholds"
- Note: √दृश् (dṛś) becomes पश्य (paśya) in present tense formations through phonetic transformation

**Meanings**:
- Literal: he/she/it sees, perceives, beholds, observes, witnesses
- Contextual: in Bhagavad Gītā and Upaniṣads, often describes the vision of the wise—one who paśyati truly sees reality as it is, not as it appears; frequently appears in philosophical discourse distinguishing between one who sees (paśyati) truth versus one who remains in ignorance; can refer to the seer (draṣṭṛ) as pure witnessing consciousness
- Symbolic: represents the act of pure perception without distortion; the consciousness that paśyati is the eternal witness (sākṣin) that sees all modifications without being modified itself; seeing in the highest sense—direct realization (sākṣātkāra)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Paśyati" = sees (3rd person singular present). Root √dṛś becomes paśya- in present tense. Extremely common verb—master all forms. Related to paśya (imperative: see!), draṣṭṛ (seer), darśana (vision, philosophy). BG uses paśyati constantly: "paśya me..." (see my...), describing various levels of vision from ordinary sight to divine perception.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Represents cit-śakti (consciousness power) in its function as witness; the eternal seer (draṣṭṛ) that paśyati all phenomena while remaining unchanged; in Sāṃkhya, Puruṣa simply paśyati—witnesses Prakṛti's dance without involvement
- **Dharmic Significance**: The distinction between ordinary seeing and true seeing—one who paśyati with jñāna-cakṣu (eye of wisdom) perceives Brahman in all; BG teaching: "He who paśyati the Self in all beings and all beings in the Self" describes the vision of non-duality; represents the shift from bhāva (becoming) to darśana (seeing)—from being lost in experience to being the witness of experience
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Bhagavad Gītā (especially BG 13: field and knower of field), Upaniṣads (particularly teachings on sākṣin/witness), Yoga Vasishtha, Yoga Sūtras (draṣṭṛ-dṛśya distinction)
पश्यतेनात्मानं:
# पश्यतेनात्मानं
**Transliteration**: paś-ya-te-nāt-mā-naṃ
**POS**: sandhi phrase (verb + negation + object)

**Root Analysis**:
- पश्यते (paśyate) – 3rd person singular middle/passive present of √दृश् (dṛś) "to see" = "he/she/it sees" or "is seen"
- न (na) – negative particle "not"
- आत्मानम् (ātmānam) – accusative singular of आत्मन् (ātman) "Self, soul"
- Sandhi: पश्यते (paśyate) + न (na) = पश्यतेन (paśyatena); पश्यतेन (paśyatena) + आत्मानम् (ātmānam) = पश्यतेनात्मानं (paśyatenātmānaṃ)
- Full phrase: "does not see the Self" or "the Self is not seen"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: does not see the Self, the Self is not perceived, fails to perceive one's true nature
- Contextual: in Vedāntic discourse, describes the state of avidyā (ignorance) where one paśyatenātmānaṃ—does not see the ātman due to identification with body-mind; characterizes the unawakened state where consciousness looks everywhere except toward its own source; the fundamental problem that all sādhana addresses
- Symbolic: represents the primary existential blindness—being the Self yet not seeing the Self; like an eye that sees everything except itself, or like searching for spectacles while wearing them; the paradox that ātman is self-evident (svayam-prakāśa) yet appears hidden

**Learning Tip**:
- "Paśyatenātmānaṃ" = paśyate (sees/is seen) + na (not) + ātmānam (Self). The middle voice paśyate can mean "sees for oneself" or "is seen." The phrase captures the tragedy of spiritual ignorance: being the Self yet not seeing it. Practice sandhi: paśyate + na → paśyatena; add ātmānam with anusvāra (ṃ).

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Represents the fundamental condition of avidyā or ajñāna that conceals Brahman; the māyā-śakti that creates the illusion that one paśyatenātmānaṃ—cannot see what one actually is; this "not-seeing" is not mere absence but an active veiling (āvaraṇa-śakti) that makes the ever-present appear absent
- **Dharmic Significance**: The root problem that Vedānta addresses—one paśyatenātmānaṃ and therefore misidentifies with anātman (not-Self); liberation is simply the removal of this ignorance, revealing that ātman was never actually hidden; represents the need for ātma-vicāra (Self-inquiry) and śravaṇa-manana-nididhyāsana (hearing-reflection-meditation) to shift from "not seeing Self" to "seeing Self everywhere"
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Upaniṣads (especially Kaṭha and Muṇḍaka on the hidden ātman), Yoga Vasishtha, Advaita Vedānta texts on avidyā
पश्यन्:
# पश्यन्
**Transliteration**: paś-yan
**POS**: present active participle (masculine, nominative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- √दृश् (dṛś) – "to see, perceive, behold" + शत् (śat) present participle suffix → पश्यत् (paśyat) "seeing, one who sees"
- पश्यन् (paśyan) is the nominative singular masculine form
- Note: √दृश् becomes पश्य (paśya) stem in present formations

**Meanings**:
- Literal: seeing, while seeing, one who is seeing; the seer (in the act of seeing)
- Contextual: in philosophical texts, describes the seer (draṣṭṛ) in the continuous act of witnessing; often used to describe the sage who, while paśyan (seeing all phenomena), remains established in the awareness that transcends seen objects; emphasizes the participial quality—not just "has seen" but actively, presently seeing
- Symbolic: the eternal witness (sākṣin) in its active witnessing function; represents consciousness not as static entity but as dynamic seeing-awareness; the "I" that is always paśyan—seeing thoughts, emotions, perceptions—yet never becomes what it sees

**Learning Tip**:
- "Paśyan" = seeing (present participle, nominative masculine singular). From √dṛś → paśya stem + -at participle → paśyan (nominative). Other forms: paśyantī (feminine), paśyat (neuter). Used to describe someone *while* seeing, emphasizing ongoing action. BG: "paśyan śṛṇvan..." (seeing, hearing...) describes the sage witnessing all while unattached.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Represents the draṣṭṛ-svarūpa (nature of the seer) as distinguished from dṛśya (seen); in Sāṃkhya-Yoga, Puruṣa is eternally paśyan—witnessing Prakṛti's transformations while remaining uninvolved; the consciousness principle that is always "seeing" yet never changes based on what is seen
- **Dharmic Significance**: Central to sākṣi-bhāva (witness attitude) practice—establishing oneself as paśyan (the seeing) rather than identifying with seen phenomena; represents the shift from "I am this body-mind experiencing" to "I am the paśyan—the witnessing awareness"; in Advaita, even the paśyan is ultimately transcended in recognition of pure cit (consciousness) beyond subject-object duality, but paśyan-bhāva is crucial intermediate practice
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Bhagavad Gītā (description of sthita-prajña as paśyan yet unaffected), Yoga Sūtras (draṣṭṛ-dṛśya-viveka), Yoga Vasishtha, Aṣṭāvakra Gītā, Advaita texts on sākṣi
पश्यन्ति:
# पश्यन्ति
**Transliteration**: paś-yan-ti
**POS**: verb (3rd person plural, present indicative active)

**Root Analysis**:
- √दृश् (dṛś) – "to see, perceive, behold" + शप् (śap) present class marker + अन्ति (anti) 3rd person plural ending = पश्यन्ति (paśyanti) "they see, they perceive, they behold"
- Note: √दृश् becomes पश्य (paśya) stem in present formations

**Meanings**:
- Literal: they see, they perceive, they behold, they witness
- Contextual: in scriptural discourse, often refers to the wise ones, seers, or jñānīs who paśyanti—truly see reality; contrasts with ordinary people who merely look but don't see; used in Upaniṣadic teaching to distinguish those who perceive truth (paśyanti) from those lost in appearances
- Symbolic: the collective vision of realized consciousness; represents not individual seeing but the universal seeing of truth by all who have awakened; the dharma that all enlightened beings paśyanti identically because truth is one

**Learning Tip**:
- "Paśyanti" = they see (3rd person plural present). From √dṛś → paśya stem + anti ending. Compare singular paśyati (sees) with plural paśyanti (they see). Common in teachings: "paṇḍitāḥ paśyanti" (the wise see), "jñānīs paśyanti" (the knowers perceive). The plural often indicates the consensus of realized beings.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: In tantric śabda-brahman (word as Brahman) theory, paśyanti is one of the four levels of vāc (speech/manifestation): para (supreme unmanifest), paśyantī (seeing/visionary), madhyamā (subtle/mental), vaikharī (gross/spoken); paśyantī-vāc is the level where undifferentiated consciousness first "sees" differentiation arising, though still in subtle unified vision before actual separation
- **Mantric Significance**: Paśyantī as a level of vāc represents the stage where mantras exist in visionary form—seen as light or subtle vibration before becoming audible sound; yogis develop access to paśyantī level where all language is perceived in its archetypal, pre-differentiated unity
- **Dharmic Significance**: When used as simple verb (they see), emphasizes that all realized beings paśyanti the same truth—"ekam sat viprā bahudhā vadanti" (truth is one, the wise speak of it in many ways)—they all see the same reality though expressing it differently; represents inter-subjective validation of spiritual realization
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Vāc-theory texts (Tantrasāra, Tantraloka); as verb: Bhagavad Gītā, Upaniṣads, Yoga Vasishtha
पश्यन्ती:
# पश्यन्ती
**Transliteration**: paś-yan-tī
**POS**: present active participle (feminine, nominative singular); also technical term for level of speech

**Root Analysis**:
- √दृश् (dṛś) – "to see, perceive, behold" + शत् (śat) present participle suffix → पश्यत् (paśyat) → पश्यन्ती (paśyantī) feminine form "seeing, she who sees"
- Note: √दृश् becomes पश्य (paśya) stem in present formations

**Meanings**:
- Literal: seeing (feminine participle), she who is seeing, the female seer
- Contextual: As grammatical form, describes a feminine subject in the act of seeing; as technical term in Tantric philosophy, पश्यन्ती (paśyantī) is the second of four levels of vāc (speech/creative power)—the "seeing" or "visionary" stage where consciousness first beholds its own creative impulse before differentiation into distinct words or sounds
- Symbolic: represents the divine śakti of perception; consciousness at the threshold between unity and multiplicity—seeing the vision of manifestation but not yet manifesting; the intuitive flash before articulation

**Learning Tip**:
- "Paśyantī" = seeing (feminine participle) or "the seeing level" (vāc theory). Feminine nominative of participle paśyat. In vāc theory: para (beyond) → paśyantī (seeing) → madhyamā (middle) → vaikharī (manifest). Remember: paśyantī is where consciousness *sees* what will be spoken but hasn't yet spoken it—like seeing the whole meaning in a flash before finding words.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: In the four-level vāc (speech) cosmology: (1) parā-vāc—supreme undifferentiated word-consciousness in Brahman; (2) paśyantī-vāc—the "seeing" level where Śakti first beholds the seed-forms (bīja) of manifestation while still in unified vision, associated with buddhi-tattva or vijñāna; (3) madhyamā-vāc—subtle mental speech; (4) vaikharī-vāc—gross audible speech
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Paśyantī corresponds to the subtle visionary state accessed in deep meditation where one "sees" truths holistically before they crystallize into thoughts or words; associated with ājñā-cakra; yogis cultivate access to paśyantī level to perceive the archetypal patterns behind manifest forms
- **Mantric Significance**: At paśyantī level, mantras exist as luminous seed-visions (sphuṭa-nāda)—not yet audible but visible to inner sight as patterns of light and subtle vibration; the level where all language is one continuous seeing; mantra-sādhana aims to access this unified pre-verbal wisdom
- **Dharmic Significance**: Represents prajñā-śakti (wisdom-power) in its immediate intuitive mode—direct seeing before conceptual division; the flash of recognition that precedes analysis; in Vedāntic terms, the buddhi operating at its subtlest, most unified level of perception
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Tantrasāra, Tantraloka (Abhinavagupta), Vākyapadīya (Bhartṛhari), Kashmir Śaiva texts, Śrī Vidyā literature
पाञ्चरात्न:
# पाञ्चरात्न
**Transliteration**: pāñ-ca-rāt-ra (variant: pāñ-ca-rāt-na)
**POS**: adjective/noun (neuter); technical term for religious tradition

**Root Analysis**:
- पञ्चन् (pañcan) "five" + रात्रि (rātri) "night" → पञ्चरात्र (pañcarātra) "five nights" → पाञ्चरात्र (pāñcarātra) adjectival form "relating to five nights"
- Note: The spelling पाञ्चरात्न (pāñcarātna) appears to be either a variant or confusion with रत्न (ratna) "jewel"; standard form is पाञ्चरात्र (pāñcarātra)

**Meanings**:
- Literal: relating to five nights, pertaining to a five-night period or ritual
- Contextual: refers to Pāñcarātra—a major Vaiṣṇava tradition and collection of Āgamic texts; according to tradition, this knowledge was revealed by Nārāyaṇa over five nights (pañca rātra); encompasses philosophy, ritual, temple worship, yoga, and cosmology centered on Viṣṇu-Nārāyaṇa
- Symbolic: represents systematic, revealed wisdom structured around the divine manifestation of Viṣṇu; the five nights may symbolize stages of revelation or levels of reality

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pāñcarātra" = pañca (five) + rātra (night) + adjectival ending. Not to be confused with pañca-ratna (five jewels). The Pāñcarātra tradition is parallel to Pāśupata (Śaiva) tradition—both are Āgamic. Remember: Pāñcarātra = Vaiṣṇava Āgama tradition revealed over five nights.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Pāñcarātra cosmology describes Viṣṇu's emanations through vyūhas (divine formations): Para (supreme Vāsudeva), Vyūha (Saṅkarṣaṇa, Pradyumna, Aniruddha), Vibhava (avatāras), Antaryāmin (inner controller), Arcā (temple image); systematizes the relationship between transcendent and immanent divine
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Centers on Nārāyaṇa-Viṣṇu and his consort Lakṣmī (Śrī); the vyūha system maps divine śakti onto cosmic and human levels; emphasizes Vāsudeva as supreme Brahman with other vyūhas as his conscious emanations
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Prescribes detailed sādhana including mantra-initiation (dīkṣā), nyāsa (placement of deity in body), dhyāna (meditation on vyūhas), elaborate pūjā procedures; integrates bhakti with jñāna and yoga in systematic framework
- **Symbolic Representation**: Temple consecration and image worship (arcā-avatāra) central to practice; elaborate iconography of Viṣṇu's forms and their placement in temples; śrī-cakra adaptations in some traditions
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Pāñcarātra Saṃhitās (Jayākhya, Sāttvata, Pauṣkara, Īśvara, Ahirbudhnya, and many others—over 200 texts); Viṣṇu Purāṇa references; forms scriptural basis for Śrī Vaiṣṇava tradition
पातञ्जलः:
# पातञ्जलः
**Transliteration**: pā-tañ-ja-laḥ
**POS**: adjective/patronymic (masculine, nominative singular); refers to Patañjali or his tradition

**Root Analysis**:
- पतञ्जलि (Patañjali) proper name + अ (a) adjectival suffix → पातञ्जल (pātañjala) "belonging to Patañjali, relating to Patañjali"
- Patañjali possibly from: पत (pata) "falling" + अञ्जलि (añjali) "cupped hands, reverent gesture" – traditional etymology relates to sage falling into Pāṇini's cupped hands
- पातञ्जलः (pātañjalaḥ) nominative form "one belonging to Patañjali's lineage" or "the Pātañjala system"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: relating to Patañjali, belonging to Patañjali's school, associated with the sage Patañjali
- Contextual: refers to the Pātañjala system of yoga—the classical eight-limbed (aṣṭāṅga) yoga systematized in the Yoga Sūtras; also refers to Patañjali's grammatical commentary (Mahābhāṣya); when personified, refers to Patañjali himself, the sage-compiler
- Symbolic: represents systematic, scientific approach to spiritual practice; the codification of practical methodology for liberation; Patañjali as the systematizer who organized scattered yogic teachings into coherent darśana

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pātañjalaḥ" = belonging to Patañjali. Name Patañjali traditionally from pata (falling) + añjali (cupped hands)—sage who fell as serpent into cupped hands. The Pātañjala system = Yoga Sūtras tradition. Adjectival suffix distinguishes: Patañjali (person) vs. Pātañjala (his system/followers).

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Patañjali considered avatāra of Ādiśeṣa (cosmic serpent) incarnating to systematize yoga; represents divine grace organizing spiritual science for human accessibility; his work bridges Sāṃkhya metaphysics with practical methodology
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: The Pātañjala system presents aṣṭāṅga-yoga (eight limbs): yama, niyama, āsana, prāṇāyāma, pratyāhāra, dhāraṇā, dhyāna, samādhi; emphasizes citta-vṛtti-nirodha (cessation of mental modifications) as means to kaivalya (isolation/liberation); provides framework for working with kleśas (afflictions), saṃskāras (impressions), and guṇas (qualities) toward puruṣa-prakṛti viveka (discrimination)
- **Dharmic Significance**: Represents kriyā-yoga (yoga of action) combined with jñāna (knowledge) and vairāgya (dispassion); foundational text for understanding consciousness (citta), the seer (draṣṭṛ), and liberation; establishes yoga as one of six orthodox darśanas (philosophical systems); emphasizes īśvara-praṇidhāna (surrender to Lord) as accelerating factor
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Yoga Sūtras of Patañjali (195 sūtras in four pādas), Mahābhāṣya (great commentary on Pāṇini's Aṣṭādhyāyī attributed to Patañjali, though possibly different Patañjali)
पाता:
# पाता
**Transliteration**: pā-tā
**POS**: noun (masculine, nominative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- √पत् (pat) – "to fall, fly, descend" + तृच् (tṛc) agent suffix → पतितृ → पाता (pātā) "one who falls, faller, one who causes to fall"
- Alternative analysis: √पत् + णिच् (causative) + तृच् → पाता "one who causes to fall, destroyer"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: one who falls, faller; one who causes falling, destroyer, ruiner
- Contextual: can refer to one who has fallen from a higher state (spiritual or social fall); or to an agent that causes downfall; in compounds, often relates to protection from falling (pāta-rakṣaka)
- Symbolic: represents the descent of consciousness from unity to multiplicity, or the force that precipitates such descent; can symbolize ego as that which causes fall from grace, or sin/error that leads to spiritual downfall

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pātā" = one who falls/causes fall. From √pat (to fall) + agent suffix. Related to pāta (falling, descent), patita (fallen), patana (falling action). Context determines whether emphasizes falling or causing fall. Remember: same root gives us avatāra (ava + tṛ from √tṝ, related to descent).
पाद:
# पाद
**Transliteration**: pā-da
**POS**: noun (masculine, nominative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- √पद् (pad) – "to go, move, walk" + अ (a) nominal suffix = पाद (pāda) "foot, that by which one goes"
- Related to पद (pada) "foot, step, word"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: foot, leg, base, foundation; quarter (one-fourth); foot of a verse (metrical unit); column, pillar
- Contextual: in texts, pāda has multiple technical uses: (1) anatomical foot; (2) quarter division (as in catur-pāda, four quarters); (3) pāda as line/quarter of a verse (most Sanskrit verses have four pādas); (4) metaphorically, foundation or support of something; (5) in bhakti tradition, the holy feet (śrī-pāda) of guru or deity as object of devotion and refuge
- Symbolic: represents the foundation of any system—dharma stands on four pādas (truth, purity, compassion, charity); consciousness "walks" on its pādas (supports); taking refuge at divine feet (pāda-śaraṇa) symbolizes complete surrender

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pāda" = foot, quarter, verse-line. From √pad (to go)—the foot is what you go with. Multiple meanings require context: catur-pāda = four feet/quarters; śloka-pāda = verse quarter (line); viṣṇu-pāda = Viṣṇu's feet. Remember: pada (foot/word) vs. pāda (foot/quarter) distinguished by vowel length.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: The cosmic manifestation conceived as having pādas (quarters/foundations): the famous Puruṣa Sūkta describes three-quarters (tri-pāda) of Puruṣa as immortal in heaven, one quarter (eka-pāda) as mortal creation; brahma-pāda = Brahman's quarter/realm; represents division of reality into levels or supports
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: In prāṇāyāma, measured in pādas (units); the feet (pādas) in āsana provide literal grounding; mūlādhāra-cakra at base is the pāda (foundation) of kuṇḍalinī's ascent; meditation on guru's or deity's feet cultivates humility and receptivity
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Śrī-pāda (holy feet) central to bhakti—taking refuge in Kṛṣṇa's feet, Rāma's feet, guru's feet; Viṣṇu-pāda (Gaṅgā originating from Viṣṇu's foot); pāda-pūjā (worship of feet) as act of supreme devotion; in iconography, divine feet often marked with auspicious symbols
- **Dharmic Significance**: Dharma described as having four pādas in Satya Yuga, degrading to three, two, one in subsequent yugas; in Yoga Sūtras context, practice stands on multiple pādas (supports); prostration at pādas represents ego-dissolution
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Puruṣa Sūkta (Ṛg Veda 10.90), Upaniṣads (brahma-pāda), Bhāgavata Purāṇa (devotion to Kṛṣṇa's feet), all Sanskrit poetry (pāda as metrical unit)
पाद्:
# पाद्
**Transliteration**: pād
**POS**: noun stem (masculine); used in compounds

**Root Analysis**:
- √पद् (pad) – "to go, move, walk" + अ (a) nominal suffix = पाद (pāda) → पाद् (pād) stem form used before certain case endings and in compounds
- The stem पाद् (pād) appears with strong-stem case endings, while पाद (pāda) appears in weak cases and as independent form

**Meanings**:
- Literal: foot, leg (stem form used in inflection and compounding)
- Contextual: appears primarily in grammatical contexts—the stem form from which declined forms derive (पादौ pādau "two feet", पादाः pādāḥ "feet" plural, etc.); used as first or last member of compounds
- Symbolic: as stem, represents the root concept of "foot/foundation" before specific contextual application through case or compounding

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pād" = stem form of pāda (foot). Used in compounds: pād-odaka (water from washing feet), dvi-pād (two-footed), catur-pād (four-footed/four-quartered). In declension: strong stem pād- vs. weak stem pāda-. Example: nominative pādaḥ (with augment), but instrumental pādā (from pād + ā). Master this pattern—extremely common in -a stem masculine nouns.
पापे:
# पापे
**Transliteration**: pā-pe
**POS**: noun (neuter, locative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- Etymology uncertain; possibly from √पा (pā) "to drink" in sense of "drinking/absorbing negativity," or possibly from √पप् (pap) "to move crookedly"
- पाप (pāpa) "evil, sin, harmful action" → पापे (pāpe) locative singular "in sin, in evil"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: in sin, in evil, in harmful action, in wrongdoing; while engaged in pāpa
- Contextual: used in teachings about karma and dharma—being pāpe (in sin/evil) brings suffering as consequence; contrasted with puṇya (merit); in Yoga Vasishtha and Vedāntic contexts, often discussed in relation to ignorance (avidyā) as root cause of pāpa
- Symbolic: represents being situated in actions or states opposed to dharma (righteousness); symbolizes the condition of consciousness bound by adharmic tendencies; being "in" pāpa suggests immersion in patterns that harm oneself and others

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pāpe" = in sin/evil (locative of pāpa). Locative indicates "in/at/upon" so pāpe = "in the state of sin." Contrasted with puṇye (in merit). Common phrase: pāpa-puṇya (sin and merit, the dual results of action). Remember: pāpa (evil deed) vs. pāpin (evil-doer). Locative -e ending standard for neuter -a stems.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Pāpa represents actions that disturb ṛta (cosmic order) and generate negative karma; creates saṃskāras (impressions) that perpetuate bondage; in the cosmic moral economy, pāpa produces inevitable suffering as restoration of balance
- **Dharmic Significance**: In Advaita Vedānta, pāpa-puṇya (sin-merit duality) are relative concepts applicable to the empirical realm but transcended by jñāna; both bind consciousness to karmic cycles; the jñānī is neither pāpakṛt (sin-doer) nor puṇyakṛt (merit-doer) but beyond both; however, for spiritual aspirants, avoiding pāpa and cultivating puṇya creates conducive conditions for liberation; pāpa fundamentally arises from avidyā (ignorance) and ahankāra (ego) which create separation and selfish action
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Dharma Śāstras (classification of pāpa), Bhagavad Gītā (especially BG 4.37: "jñāna-agniḥ sarva-karmāṇi bhasma-sāt kurute"—the fire of knowledge burns all karma/pāpa to ashes), Yoga Vasishtha, Upaniṣads
पायूपस्थानि:
# पायूपस्थानि
**Transliteration**: pā-yū-pas-thā-ni
**POS**: dvandva compound (neuter, nominative/accusative plural)

**Root Analysis**:
- पायु (pāyu) "anus, excretory organ" (possibly from √पा "to drink/consume" in sense of processing/eliminating) + उपस्थ (upastha) "genitals, reproductive organs" (from उप upa "near" + √स्था sthā "to stand" = "that which stands below/near")
- Dvandva compound: पायु (pāyu) + उपस्थ (upastha) = पायूपस्थ (pāyūpastha) "anus and genitals"
- पायूपस्थानि (pāyūpasthāni) = neuter plural form

**Meanings**:
- Literal: the anus and genitals, the excretory and reproductive organs (plural)
- Contextual: in yogic and Āyurvedic texts, refers to the lower bodily openings associated with apāna-vāyu (downward-moving vital air); in discussions of brahmacarya (celibacy) and sense control, these organs represent the seat of basic biological drives to be mastered; in descriptions of mūlādhāra-cakra region
- Symbolic: represents the grossest level of embodied existence—elimination and procreation; the biological imperatives that bind consciousness to physical identity; in tantric transformation, even these "lower" functions are recognized as expressions of śakti to be neither indulged nor suppressed but understood and transcended

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pāyūpasthāni" = pāyu (anus) + upastha (genitals) + neuter plural -i. Dvandva (copulative) compound meaning "anus-and-genitals." Related to apāna-vāyu control in prāṇāyāma. Context: yogic physiology and control of lower functions. Remember: upastha literally "standing near/below"—euphemistic anatomical term.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: These organs governed by apāna-vāyu (downward/outward prāṇa) seated in mūlādhāra region; in haṭha-yoga, practices like mūla-bandha and aśvinī-mudrā involve conscious control of these regions to reverse apāna's natural downward tendency, redirecting energy upward for kuṇḍalinī awakening; brahmacarya (celibacy/retention) requires mastery over upastha; śauca (purity) extends to proper functioning and cleanliness of pāyu
- **Dharmic Significance**: Represents the physical-biological level of existence that must be neither obsessively controlled nor carelessly indulged; in brahmacarya discipline, upastha control conserves ojas (vital essence) for spiritual transformation; the yogi recognizes even elimination (pāyu function) as divine process but is not identified with or attached to bodily functions
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Haṭha Yoga Pradīpikā, Gheraṇḍa Saṃhitā (mudrās and bandhas), Caraka Saṃhitā and Suśruta Saṃhitā (Āyurvedic physiology), discussions of brahmacarya in Upaniṣads and dharma texts
पारदेन:
# पारदेन
**Transliteration**: pā-ra-de-na
**POS**: noun (masculine/neuter, instrumental singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- पारद (pārada) "mercury, quicksilver" → पारदेन (pāradena) instrumental "by/with mercury"
- Etymology of पारद: possibly पार (pāra) "crossing over, far shore" + द (da) from √दा "to give" = "that which gives crossing" (mercury as transformative agent); or पारद from पार (pāra) "mercury" + द "giving"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: by mercury, with quicksilver, through mercury; using pārada as instrument or agent
- Contextual: in alchemical (rasaśāstra/rasāyana) texts, pāradena refers to processes using mercury for transmutation of metals or preparation of medicinal compounds; in tantric-alchemical practice, mercury used in ritual and yogic processes aimed at bodily immortality (kāya-siddhi)
- Symbolic: mercury as supremely transformative substance—liquid yet metallic, poisonous yet potentially medicinal; represents the volatile principle (rasa) that when properly fixed (baddha) grants siddhi; symbolizes the mind—fluid, quicksilver-like, requiring stabilization

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pāradena" = instrumental of pārada (mercury). Pārada literally "giver of crossing/liberation"—mercury as alchemical transformer. In rasaśāstra, pārada is king of metals, associated with Śiva. Instrumental -ena shows means: "by means of mercury." Related: pārada-baddha (fixed mercury), rasa (mercury/fluid/essence).

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: In tantric cosmology, pārada represents Śiva-tattva (Śiva principle) while sulfur (gandhaka) represents Śakti; their union in alchemy mirrors cosmic Śiva-Śakti union; mercury's ability to amalgamate with other metals symbolizes Śiva's all-pervading nature
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Haṭha-yogic and rasāyana practices using pārada aim at kāya-kalpa (bodily rejuvenation) and deha-siddhi (bodily perfection); properly processed mercury (śodhita-pārada) used in compounds believed to stabilize bindu (vital essence), strengthen ojas, and prepare body for advanced prāṇic practices; mercury's fluidity parallels the yogi's goal of making the body fluid/subtle enough for immortality
- **Symbolic Representation**: Pārada associated with soma (moon/nectar) and Śiva; mercury liṅgas (pārada-liṅga) considered especially powerful for worship; in iconography, Śiva sometimes depicted holding or associated with mercury
- **Dharmic Significance**: The alchemical quest using pārada represents external counterpart to internal yogic transformation—both aim at transcending death and achieving liberation; the fixing of volatile mercury (sūta-bandhana) parallels the fixing of volatile mind (citta-sthairya)
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Rasārṇava, Rasaratna-samuccaya, Rasendramangala, and other rasaśāstra texts; Haṭha Yoga Pradīpikā mentions mercury practices; tantric texts on kāya-sādhana
पाशुपत:
# पाशुपत
**Transliteration**: pā-śu-pa-ta
**POS**: adjective/noun (masculine, nominative singular); refers to Pāśupata tradition or follower

**Root Analysis**:
- पशुपति (paśupati) "lord of creatures/bound souls" (पशु paśu "bound soul/animal" + पति pati "lord") + अ (a) suffix → पाशुपत (pāśupata) "relating to Paśupati, belonging to the Pāśupata school"
- Can function as adjective "relating to Paśupati" or noun "a Pāśupata (follower of this tradition)"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: relating to Paśupati (Śiva as lord of bound souls), belonging to the Pāśupata tradition
- Contextual: refers to the Pāśupata tradition—one of the oldest Śaiva philosophical schools and the first systematized Śaiva darśana; Pāśupatas are ascetic devotees of Rudra-Śiva who follow specific observances (vrata) including controversial practices like acting mad or inappropriate to burn karma and provoke others' censure (thus transferring their merit to the Pāśupata)
- Symbolic: represents the path of recognizing oneself as paśu (bound soul) utterly dependent on Pati (Lord Śiva) for liberation from pāśa (bondage); emphasizes bhakti combined with ascetic discipline and philosophical understanding

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pāśupata" = belonging to Paśupati/Pāśupata school. Derived from paśupati (lord of creatures) + -a suffix. Ancient Śaiva tradition predating Kashmir Śaivism. Related to paśu-pāśa-pati triad (soul-bondage-lord). Famous for controversial vrata practices aimed at ego-destruction. Distinguish: Paśupati (deity name) vs. Pāśupata (tradition/follower).

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Pāśupata philosophy systematizes Śaiva theology around paśu-pāśa-pati framework: paśu (individual soul bound by ignorance), pāśa (bondage: āṇava-mala/innate impurity, karma-mala/karmic impurity, māyīya-mala/delusory covering), pati (Lord Śiva who liberates); accepts five categories (pañca-padārtha): kārya (effect/world), kāraṇa (cause/Prakṛti), yoga (union/practice), vidhi (rules/observances), duḥkhānta (end of suffering/mokṣa)
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Centers on Rudra-Śiva as supreme deity; worship of Paśupati in his fierce, wild aspects; ash-smeared ascetics following Rudra's model; emphasis on Śiva as both destroyer and liberator
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Prescribes specific yoga practices including ash-bathing (bhasma-snāna), meditation on Śiva, pranava (Om) recitation; distinctive controversial vrata where practitioner acts improperly in public (feigning madness, making crude sounds, trembling) to attract censure and abuse, thereby burning karma and transferring others' merit while destroying pride
- **Dharmic Significance**: Liberation (mokṣa) achieved through Śiva's grace (śiva-prasāda) combined with jñāna, yoga, and observances; the paśu realizes identity with Pati not through own power but through grace; represents devotional yet philosophically sophisticated path
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Pāśupata Sūtras (attributed to Lakulīśa), Gaṇakārikā, Ratnaṭīkā (Bhaṣya on Pāśupata Sūtras), Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad (proto-Pāśupata), references in Purāṇas
पिता:
# पिता
**Transliteration**: pi-tā
**POS**: noun (masculine, nominative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- Possibly from √पा (pā) – "to protect, nourish" + तृ (tṛ) agent suffix → पितृ (pitṛ) → पिता (pitā) nominative "father, protector, nourisher"
- Alternative: Indo-European root shared across languages (Latin pater, Greek patēr, English father)
- Irregular noun with stem पितृ (pitṛ) but nominative पिता (pitā)

**Meanings**:
- Literal: father, male parent, progenitor, patriarch
- Contextual: in extended sense, any paternal figure—guru as spiritual father, king as father of subjects, ancestors (pitṛs) as forefathers; in Vedic context, often refers to deceased ancestors who receive offerings; in devotional literature, addressing God as father (pita) expresses filial relationship
- Symbolic: represents the active, protecting, guiding principle; in spiritual context, the guru or divine father who protects and guides the spiritual child toward realization; pitṛs (ancestors) symbolize the karmic lineage and inherited tendencies

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pitā" = father (nominative singular). Irregular declension: stem pitṛ but nominative pitā. Related: pitṛ (father in general), pitaraḥ (fathers/ancestors plural), mātā-pitā (mother-father). In compounds: pitṛ-. One of seven kinship terms with irregular forms. Remember: similar irregularity in mātā (mother) from mātṛ stem.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Pitṛs (ancestors, manes) occupy important cosmic role as intermediate beings between gods and humans; dwelling in pitṛ-loka, they receive śrāddha offerings from descendants; represent the karmic continuity and hereditary patterns transmitted through lineages; in creation cosmology, Prajāpati or Brahmā functions as cosmic pitā (father/progenitor)
- **Dharmic Significance**: Honoring father (pitṛ-pūjā) is fundamental dharmic duty; one of the ṛṇa-traya (three debts): debt to gods (deva-ṛṇa), ancestors (pitṛ-ṛṇa), and sages (ṛṣi-ṛṇa); the guru as spiritual father guides disciple from darkness to light; "You are my father, mother, brother, friend" (tvam eva mātā ca pitā...) devotional formula recognizes divine as all relationships; in bhakti, surrendering to divine father represents seeking protection and guidance
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Ṛg Veda (pitṛ hymns), Dharma Śāstras (pitṛ duties and śrāddha), Yoga Vasishtha (Vasiṣṭha as pitā to Rāma), Bhakti literature (divine as father)
पित्त:
# पित्त
**Transliteration**: pit-ta
**POS**: noun (neuter, nominative/accusative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- Possibly from √तप् (tap) – "to heat, burn" with metathesis, or from √पा (pā) "to drink" + past participle suffix, referring to "that which has been heated/cooked"
- पित्त (pitta) = bile, the humor associated with fire and heat in the body

**Meanings**:
- Literal: bile, gall; the yellowish-green digestive fluid; bodily heat
- Contextual: in Āyurveda, one of the three fundamental doṣas (humors/constitutions): vāta (air/wind), pitta (fire/bile), kapha (water/phlegm); pitta governs all heat-related and transformative processes in body—digestion, metabolism, vision, courage, intelligence; seats of pitta include small intestine, stomach, liver, spleen, heart, eyes, and skin
- Symbolic: represents agni-tattva (fire principle) operating in the physical body; the digestive and transformative capacity not just of food but of experiences; symbolically, pitta relates to tejas (brilliance, discrimination, understanding) and when balanced produces mental clarity and courage

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pitta" = bile/fire doṣa in Āyurveda. One of tri-doṣa (vāta-pitta-kapha). Associated with agni (fire), transformation, digestion, heat. Imbalanced pitta → inflammation, anger, acid conditions. Balanced pitta → sharp intellect, good digestion, courage. Think: pitta = "pit" of digestive fire. Related: pittala (brass, yellow metal associated with pitta color).

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Pitta as microcosmic expression of agni-mahābhūta (fire element); in the body's fivefold agni system, pitta represents metabolic fire (pācaka-agni) that transforms food into nutrients and waste; corresponds to tejas-tattva in Sāṃkhya enumeration
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: In prāṇic physiology, pitta concentrates in nābhi-cakra (navel center) as digestive fire; balanced pitta essential for converting prāṇa from food and breath; excess pitta creates obstacles in meditation (agitation, heat, anger); yogic cooling practices (śītalī, śītakārī prāṇāyāma) balance pitta; certain tapas (austerities) deliberately increase pitta to burn karma and impurities
- **Dharmic Significance**: Proper pitta balance enables viveka (discrimination) and buddhi (intelligence) to function clearly; pitta governs the "digestive fire" that processes not just food but also impressions (saṃskāras), helping burn through past conditioning; symbolically represents the transformative power needed on spiritual path—consuming the old to create the new
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Caraka Saṃhitā, Suśruta Saṃhitā, Aṣṭāṅga Hṛdaya (Āyurvedic classics on tri-doṣa theory), yoga texts discussing agni-tattva and digestion
पित्रे:
# पित्रे
**Transliteration**: pit-re
**POS**: noun (masculine, dative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- पितृ (pitṛ) "father, ancestor" → पित्रे (pitre) dative singular "to/for the father, to/for the ancestor"
- Irregular declension from pitṛ stem with dative ending -e

**Meanings**:
- Literal: to the father, for the father; to/for the ancestor
- Contextual: in ritual context, used when making offerings pitre (to the father/ancestors); in daily speech, indicates action done for father's benefit or directed toward father; in spiritual context, offerings or duties performed pitre (for the spiritual father/guru)
- Symbolic: the dative case expresses the relationship of giving, offering, or dedicating—pitre indicates that something is being offered to the paternal/ancestral principle; represents honoring the source from which one came

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pitre" = to/for the father (dative of pitṛ). Irregular noun declension: stem pitṛ → dative pitre (not *pitṛe). Compare: mātṛ (mother) → mātre (to mother). Dative shows recipient/beneficiary: "I bow *to* father" = pitre namāmi. Common in śrāddha (ancestor ritual) mantras offering pitre (to the ancestors). Master irregular pitṛ declension—very common.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: In śrāddha rites, offerings made pitre sustain pitṛs (ancestors) in pitṛ-loka; the act of giving pitre maintains cosmic reciprocity between living descendants and departed ancestors; represents honoring the temporal and karmic continuity of lineage
- **Dharmic Significance**: Giving pitre fulfills pitṛ-ṛṇa (debt to ancestors)—one of three fundamental debts (tri-ṛṇa); in guru-disciple tradition, service rendered pitre (to the guru as spiritual father) is form of guru-dakṣiṇā (offering to teacher); the dative relationship pitre symbolizes proper orientation of gratitude and respect toward source; even divine service can be framed as offering pitre (to the Supreme Father)
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Śrāddha mantras in Gṛhya Sūtras, Pitṛ hymns in Vedas, Dharma Śāstras on pitṛ-yajña (ancestor offerings)
पुंसामाधकं:
# पुंसामाधकं
**Transliteration**: puṃ-sā-mā-dha-kaṃ
**POS**: tatpuruṣa compound (neuter, nominative/accusative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- पुंसाम् (puṃsām) genitive plural of पुम्स् (pums) "man, person, human" + आधक (ādhaka) "a measure of grain/liquid (approximately 4 drona or 256 handfuls)"
- Sandhi: पुंसाम् (puṃsām) + आधकम् (ādhakam) = पुंसामाधकं (puṃsāmādhakaṃ)
- Genitive tatpuruṣa: "a measure (ādhaka) for/of men"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: a human measure, an ādhaka measure belonging to/for humans; the measure/portion appropriate for people
- Contextual: may refer to standard human portion or measure in contrast to divine or demonic quantities; could indicate moderation, the "middle way" suitable for human constitution; possibly refers to ritualistic or practical measurements scaled to human needs
- Symbolic: represents human limitation and appropriate scale—neither excess nor deficiency; the madhya-mārga (middle path) that honors human capacity without grandiosity or self-diminishment

**Learning Tip**:
- "Puṃsāmādhakaṃ" = puṃsām (of men, genitive plural) + ādhakam (measure). Ādhaka is ancient grain measure (about 8 pounds of grain). The compound suggests "measure suitable for humans"—not divine/excessive, not insufficient. Sandhi: puṃsām + ādhakam → puṃsāmādhakam. Related: pumān (man), ādhaka (measure), mānuṣa (human).
पुण्य:
# पुण्य
**Transliteration**: puṇ-ya
**POS**: adjective (all genders); also noun (neuter nominative/accusative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- √पु (pu) – "to purify, cleanse, make pure" + न्य (nya) adjectival suffix = पुण्य (puṇya) "pure, purifying, meritorious, virtuous"
- As noun (neuter): पुण्यम् (puṇyam) "merit, virtue, good karma"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: pure, holy, sacred, auspicious, virtuous, meritorious; as noun: merit, virtue, good karma, religious merit
- Contextual: in karma theory, puṇya refers to positive karmic accumulation from dharmic actions—opposite of pāpa (sin/demerit); puṇya creates favorable circumstances, happiness, and higher births; in popular religion, puṇya earned through charity (dāna), pilgrimage (tīrtha-yātrā), ritual (yajña), service; in philosophical texts, puṇya-pāpa are relative dualities to be transcended
- Symbolic: represents the purifying power of aligned action; that which uplifts consciousness toward sattva (purity) and away from tamas (darkness); yet even puṇya binds—golden chains are still chains

**Learning Tip**:
- "Puṇya" = pure/merit (from √pu to purify + nya suffix). Contrasted with pāpa (sin): pāpa-puṇya = sin-and-merit duality. As adjective: puṇya-kṣetra (holy place), puṇya-karma (meritorious deed). As noun: puṇyam icchati (desires merit). Remember: even puṇya binds according to Vedānta—must transcend both pāpa and puṇya for mokṣa.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Puṇya represents sattvic karmic energy that moves consciousness upward through lokas (realms); accumulation of puṇya creates sukha (happiness/pleasure) as karmic fruit and facilitates birth in favorable circumstances; in cosmic accounting, puṇya balances against pāpa, determining one's trajectory through saṃsāra
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Cultivation of puṇya through yama-niyama (ethical restraints and observances) purifies citta (mind-stuff), making it fit vessel for higher practices; puṇya creates the adhikāra (qualification) and favorable conditions (sat-saṅga, health, leisure) necessary for spiritual pursuit; however, attachment to puṇya or pride in virtue obstructs liberation
- **Dharmic Significance**: The puṇya-pāpa framework governs moral causality in empirical realm; for householders (gṛhasthas), accumulating puṇya through dharmic living prepares ground for renunciation; for jñānīs, the teaching is that jñāna burns both puṇya and pāpa equally—"ubhe sukṛta-duṣkṛte vidhunute" (shakes off both good and evil deeds); the liberated one transcends puṇya-pāpa duality, acting spontaneously without karmic binding; yet paradoxically, the jñānī's actions appear as supreme puṇya from relative viewpoint
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Bhagavad Gītā (especially BG 9.21 on puṇya exhaustion), Yoga Sūtras (śukla-kṛṣṇa karma), Dharma Śāstras (puṇya-karma classification), Upaniṣads (transcending puṇya-pāpa), Yoga Vasishtha
पुत्र:
# पुत्र
**Transliteration**: put-ra
**POS**: noun (masculine, nominative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- Traditional etymology (nirukta): पुत् (put) "a hell named Put" + त्र (tra) from √त्रै (trai) "to protect, save" = पुत्र (putra) "one who protects/saves from Put hell"
- Alternative: possibly from √पू (pū) "to purify" + त्र (tra) suffix = "purifier"
- Folk etymology emphasizes son's role in performing śrāddha rites that save ancestors from suffering

**Meanings**:
- Literal: son, male offspring, child, descendant
- Contextual: in Dharma Śāstra context, putra is essential for continuing lineage and performing ancestral rites (śrāddha, tarpaṇa) that liberate pitṛs; extends to adopted son (dattaka-putra), spiritual son (dharma-putra), disciple as spiritual son; in Yoga Vasishtha, Rāma is putra to Daśaratha and spiritual putra to Vasiṣṭha
- Symbolic: represents continuity, legacy, and responsibility; in spiritual sense, realization or enlightened understanding as "putra" born from jñāna; the inner "son" of awareness born from spiritual practice

**Learning Tip**:
- "Putra" = son. Traditional etymology: put (hell) + tra (protector) = "savior from hell" through ancestral rites. Related: putrikā (daughter), putrī (daughter), putra-kāma (desiring a son). Compounds: mahā-putra (great son), dharma-putra (righteous son, also name of Yudhiṣṭhira). Remember folk etymology connects son to ancestral salvation.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: In pitṛ-pakṣa cosmology, putras perform śrāddha that sustains ancestors in pitṛ-loka and facilitates their eventual liberation or good rebirth; represents continuity of dharmic transmission across generations; the putra continues yajña, learning, and dharma of lineage
- **Dharmic Significance**: Having putra is traditionally considered dharmic duty (pitṛ-ṛṇa repayment) and ensures continuation of family dharma; however, Yoga Vasishtha and Advaita texts emphasize jñāna-putra (son of wisdom) over biological putra—one's true "offspring" is realized understanding; in guru-śiṣya tradition, the disciple as spiritual putra carries forward the teaching lineage; the "sonship" to be cultivated is recognizing one's identity as putra of Brahman, offspring of immortal consciousness
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Dharma Śāstras (Manu Smṛti on putra duties), Śrāddha sections of Gṛhya Sūtras, Mahābhārata, Rāmāyaṇa, Yoga Vasishtha (Rāma as putra to both father and guru)
पुम्प्रकृ:
# पुम्प्रकृ
**Transliteration**: pum-pra-kṛ
**POS**: compound stem (appears incomplete or non-standard)

**Root Analysis**:
- पुम्/पुंस् (pum/puṃs) "male, masculine, person" + प्रकृति (prakṛti) "nature, original source"
- Appears to be stem form, possibly पुम्प्रकृति (pumprakṛti) with final syllable dropped, or variant/error
- If पुम्प्रकृति: would be tatpuruṣa compound "male nature" or "masculine aspect of Prakṛti"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: (if complete compound) male nature, masculine aspect of primordial nature; (as stem) incomplete form requiring completion
- Contextual: potentially refers to male principle within or in relation to Prakṛti; note that in classical Sāṃkhya, Puruṣa (consciousness principle) is distinct from Prakṛti (material principle), but in some contexts "male" and "female" aspects are mapped onto various cosmic principles
- Symbolic: if referring to masculine-Prakṛti relationship, would indicate the dynamic interplay between witnessing consciousness and active creative nature

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pumprakṛ" appears to be stem or abbreviated form. Full form likely: pum (male/masculine) + prakṛti (nature/primal matter). In Sāṃkhya: Puruṣa (witness/masculine metaphorically) vs. Prakṛti (active/feminine metaphorically)—though Puruṣa is technically genderless consciousness. Context needed to determine precise meaning. Related: puṃs (person/male), prakṛti (nature), strī-prakṛti (female nature).
पुरा:
# पुरा
**Transliteration**: pu-rā
**POS**: indeclinable adverb (avyaya)

**Root Analysis**:
- Possibly from पुर (pura) "front, before" + आ (ā) suffix = पुरा (purā) "in front (in time), before, formerly"
- Functions as temporal adverb indicating past time
- Related to पुरस् (puras) "before, in front"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: formerly, previously, in ancient times, in the past, once upon a time, long ago
- Contextual: in narrative texts (especially Purāṇas and epics), purā introduces stories from ancient times—"purā there was a king..."; in philosophical discourse, purā can refer to primordial or pre-manifested states; often used to contrast past with present (purā...idānīm "formerly...now")
- Symbolic: points to the eternal past, the timeless before, the original state; in cyclical time conception, purā refers to previous cycles, yugas, or kalpas; represents memory, tradition, and ancestral wisdom

**Learning Tip**:
- "Purā" = formerly, in ancient times. Indeclinable temporal adverb. Classic story opening: "purā āsīt" (there was formerly/once upon a time). Related: pura (before), puras (in front), pūrva (prior, eastern). Contrast: purā (formerly) vs. idānīm (now) vs. paścāt (later). Remember: Purāṇa = "ancient (stories)" from same root.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: In cyclical cosmology, purā points to previous manifestations—earlier yugas (Satya/Kṛta Yuga as the purā golden age), previous kalpas (cosmic days of Brahmā), or past manvantaras; represents the principle that what is now was purā in different form, and what will be was purā manifest—eternal recurrence
- **Dharmic Significance**: Purā invokes authority of ancient revelation and precedent; śruti and smṛti preserve wisdom from purā; in Yoga Vasishtha particularly, stories from purā illustrate timeless truths about consciousness; the teaching that ātman is beyond time means purā-idānīm-paścāt (past-present-future) are ultimately illusory divisions in the eternal Now
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Opening word of countless Purāṇic and epic narratives, Yoga Vasishtha stories, Upaniṣadic dialogues set "purā"
पुरुष:
# पुरुष
**Transliteration**: pu-ru-ṣa
**POS**: noun (masculine, nominative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- Etymology debated; traditional nirukta: पुरि शयनात् पुरुषः (puri śayanāt puruṣaḥ) "one who lies/dwells in the pura (city/body)"
- Alternative: पुर (pura) "city, fortress, body" + उष् (uṣ) from √वस् (vas) "to dwell" = "dweller in the city (of the body)"
- Or from पुरि पूर्णं (puri pūrṇaṃ) "that which fills the body/universe"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: person, human being, man, male; cosmic being, primordial person
- Contextual: In Sāṃkhya-Yoga philosophy, Puruṣa is the eternal consciousness principle—pure awareness (cit) distinct from Prakṛti (material nature); in Vedānta, identified with Ātman/Brahman; in Puruṣa Sūkta, the cosmic Person from whose sacrifice the universe manifests; in common usage, simply "person" or "man"
- Symbolic: the witnessing consciousness that is never touched by prakṛtic modifications; the Self that dwells in but is not limited by the body-city; the eternal seer (draṣṭṛ) observing the dance of seen (dṛśya)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Puruṣa" = consciousness/person. Root meaning: "dweller in the city (body)." In Sāṃkhya: Puruṣa (consciousness) ≠ Prakṛti (matter/nature). In Vedānta: Puruṣa = Ātman = Brahman. Puruṣa Sūkta describes cosmic Puruṣa with thousand heads, eyes, feet. Remember: puruṣa-avatāra (divine incarnations), uttama-puruṣa (supreme Person), puruṣārtha (human goals).

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: In Sāṃkhya, Puruṣa is one of two fundamental tattvas—alongside Prakṛti; Puruṣa is pure consciousness (cit), unchanging (akṣara), inactive witness; Prakṛti is unconscious, ever-changing, active principle; liberation (kaivalya) is Puruṣa's realization of its distinction from Prakṛti; in Puruṣa Sūkta cosmogony, the cosmic Puruṣa is sacrificed by gods to create universe—his parts become all creation (mind from moon, eye from sun, etc.); represents both individual consciousness and cosmic consciousness
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: In Yoga Sūtras, liberation is puruṣa-khyāti (recognition of Puruṣa's true nature) achieved through puruṣa-prakṛti-viveka (discrimination between consciousness and nature); meditation cultivates draṣṭṛ-svarūpa (resting in seer's nature)—the Puruṣa; the yogi realizes: "I am not body, mind, or experiences—I am Puruṣa, eternal witness"
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Viṣṇu as Puruṣottama (Supreme Puruṣa); the Hiraṇyagarbha (golden womb/cosmic egg) as Puruṣa; in Vaiṣṇava theology, distinction between jīva-puruṣa (individual soul), kṣara-puruṣa (perishable being), akṣara-puruṣa (imperishable being), and Puruṣottama (Supreme Person/Kṛṣṇa)
- **Dharmic Significance**: In Advaita, Puruṣa ultimately identical with Brahman—the non-dual awareness; the teaching is: realize yourself as Puruṣa (witness) not prakṛti (witnessed); the four puruṣārthas (human aims): dharma, artha, kāma, mokṣa—goals worthy of puruṣa; Puruṣa represents dignity, consciousness, and immortality of the Self
- **Symbolic Representation**: In Puruṣa Sūkta imagery: cosmic being with thousand heads, eyes, encompassing all—three-quarters in heaven, one-quarter as manifest creation; Viṣṇu's cosmic form as Puruṣa
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Puruṣa Sūkta (Ṛg Veda 10.90), Sāṃkhya Kārikā, Yoga Sūtras (esp. on puruṣa-prakṛti distinction), Bhagavad Gītā (chapter 15 on Puruṣottama), Upaniṣads, Vedānta Sūtras
पुरुषं:
# पुरुषं
**Transliteration**: pu-ru-ṣaṃ
**POS**: noun (masculine, accusative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- पुरुष (puruṣa) "consciousness, person, cosmic being" → पुरुषम् (puruṣam) → पुरुषं (puruṣaṃ) accusative singular with anusvāra
- Accusative case indicates direct object of verb or goal of action/meditation

**Meanings**:
- Literal: the person (as object), the being (as object), the consciousness (as object of meditation/knowledge)
- Contextual: in meditation instructions, puruṣaṃ dhyāyet (one should meditate on Puruṣa); in philosophical discourse, puruṣaṃ viddhi (know the Puruṣa); in Puruṣa Sūkta, describes seeing or knowing puruṣam as object of contemplation; the accusative marks Puruṣa as that toward which awareness is directed
- Symbolic: the paradox of making the subject into object—meditating on Puruṣa (the eternal subject/witness) as if it were an object; represents the penultimate stage before recognition that meditator and meditated are one

**Learning Tip**:
- "Puruṣaṃ" = Puruṣa in accusative (object) case. Accusative shows direct object: "I know *puruṣam*" (I know the Puruṣa), "meditate on *puruṣam*" (meditate on Puruṣa). The anusvāra (ṃ) represents final -m before certain consonants. Common phrases: puruṣaṃ paśya (see the Puruṣa), puruṣaṃ viddhi (know the Person). Remember: ultimately Puruṣa is subject, not object—but practice treats it as object of contemplation.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Dharmic Significance**: The accusative puruṣaṃ in meditation contexts creates methodological duality—treating Puruṣa (one's own witnessing consciousness) as object to be known or realized; this is the upāya (means) that uses duality to reach non-duality; phrases like "puruṣaṃ paśya" (see the Puruṣa) or "puruṣaṃ viddhi" (know the Puruṣa) point consciousness toward its own source; the final realization transcends subject-object: one doesn't see puruṣam (Puruṣa-as-object) but realizes "I am Puruṣa"—the eternal subject that can never be objectified
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Puruṣa Sūkta (ya evaṃ vidvān puruṣam...), Bhagavad Gītā (puruṣottama chapter), meditation instructions in Upaniṣads and Yoga texts using puruṣam as object of dhyāna
पुरुषस्य:
# पुरुषस्य
**Transliteration**: pu-ru-ṣas-ya
**POS**: noun (masculine, genitive singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- पुरुष (puruṣa) "consciousness, person, cosmic being" → पुरुषस्य (puruṣasya) genitive singular "of the Puruṣa, belonging to the person/consciousness"
- Genitive case indicates possession, relationship, or source

**Meanings**:
- Literal: of the person, of the consciousness, of the Puruṣa; belonging to the person; the Puruṣa's
- Contextual: in philosophical discourse, used to describe attributes or aspects of Puruṣa—puruṣasya dharmaḥ (the nature of Puruṣa), puruṣasya lakṣaṇam (the characteristic of consciousness); in Sāṃkhya, describes features puruṣasya (of Puruṣa) versus features prakṛteḥ (of Prakṛti)
- Symbolic: the genitive marks relationship—what belongs to eternal consciousness versus what belongs to nature; represents discernment between Self's attributes (immortal, unchanging, witnessing) and non-Self's attributes (mortal, changing, witnessed)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Puruṣasya" = of Puruṣa (genitive of puruṣa). Genitive shows possession/relationship: "puruṣasya guṇāḥ" (qualities of Puruṣa), "puruṣasya svarūpam" (nature of consciousness). Common in comparative philosophy: puruṣasya vs. prakṛteḥ (of Puruṣa vs. of Prakṛti). Remember genitive -sya ending for masculine -a stem nouns.
पुरुषस्याबस्थानं:
# पुरुषस्याबस्थानं
**Transliteration**: pu-ru-ṣas-yā-vas-thā-naṃ
**POS**: tatpuruṣa compound (neuter, nominative/accusative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- पुरुषस्य (puruṣasya) genitive of पुरुष (puruṣa) "consciousness, person" + अवस्थान (avasthāna) "state, condition, standing, abiding"
- अवस्थान from अव (ava) "down, in" + √स्था (sthā) "to stand, remain" + ल्युट् (lyuṭ) nominal suffix = "state of being, condition, abiding place"
- Genitive tatpuruṣa: "the state/condition/abiding-place of Puruṣa"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: the state of Puruṣa, the condition of consciousness, the abiding place of the person/Self
- Contextual: likely refers to the ontological state or condition in which Puruṣa exists or manifests; could indicate different levels or stages of consciousness-realization; may describe where/how Puruṣa "stands" or "abides" in relation to Prakṛti or body-mind
- Symbolic: represents the question of Puruṣa's relationship to manifestation—how does pure consciousness "abide" in or relate to the world of change while remaining unchanged?; the various avasthānas (states) from deep identification to pure witnessing

**Learning Tip**:
- "Puruṣasyāvasthānaṃ" = puruṣasya (of Puruṣa) + avasthānam (state/abiding). Compound describes consciousness's condition or state. Related to avasthā (state) as in the four states: jāgrat-svapna-suṣupti-turīya (waking-dream-deep sleep-fourth). The question: what is puruṣasya avasthānam? How does Puruṣa "stand" in relation to prakṛtic changes? Sandhi: puruṣasya + avasthānam → puruṣasyāvasthānam (y inserted between vowels).
पुरुषोश्नुते:
# पुरुषोश्नुते
**Transliteration**: pu-ru-ṣo-śnu-te
**POS**: sandhi phrase (noun + verb)

**Root Analysis**:
- पुरुषः (puruṣaḥ) nominative singular of पुरुष (puruṣa) "person, consciousness" + अश्नुते (aśnute) 3rd person singular middle voice present of √अश् (aś) "to attain, reach, obtain, enjoy"
- Sandhi: पुरुषः (puruṣaḥ) + अश्नुते (aśnute) = पुरुषोऽश्नुते → पुरुषोश्नुते (puruṣo'śnute/puruṣośnute) "the puruṣa attains/enjoys"
- √अश् (aś) – "to pervade, reach, attain, obtain, enjoy"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: the person attains, the puruṣa obtains, consciousness reaches/enjoys
- Contextual: in philosophical discourse, describes what puruṣaḥ aśnute (the Self attains or experiences); often used in discussions of karma-phala (karmic results)—what does puruṣa actually "attain" or "enjoy"?; the middle voice (aśnute, not aśnoti) emphasizes attainment for oneself
- Symbolic: raises the paradox—does Puruṣa (pure consciousness) actually "attain" anything, or is attainment solely prakṛtic?; in bhoga (enjoyment) contexts, the apparent "enjoyment" attributed to puruṣa when actually it's prakṛtic processes

**Learning Tip**:
- "Puruṣośnute" = puruṣaḥ (the person/consciousness) + aśnute (attains/enjoys). From √aś (to reach, attain, enjoy). Middle voice aśnute emphasizes "attains for himself." Sandhi: final -ḥ before vowel becomes -o and merges. Common in karma theory: "puruṣaḥ karma-phalam aśnute" (the person enjoys the fruit of action). Philosophical question: does pure Puruṣa truly "enjoy" or is it apparent enjoyment through identification with prakṛti?
पुरुषौ:
# पुरुषौ
**Transliteration**: pu-ru-ṣau
**POS**: noun (masculine, dual nominative)

**Root Analysis**:
- पुरुष (puruṣa) "consciousness, person, being" → पुरुषौ (puruṣau) dual nominative "two puruṣas, two persons, two consciousness principles"
- Dual number -औ (au) ending

**Meanings**:
- Literal: two persons, two beings, two puruṣas, a pair of conscious entities
- Contextual: in Sāṃkhya-Yoga philosophy, may refer to the duality of multiple puruṣas (the system accepts many individual puruṣas, each eternal and distinct); in Vaiṣṇava theology (especially BG chapter 15), refers to kṣara-puruṣa (perishable person) and akṣara-puruṣa (imperishable person)—the two puruṣas transcended by Puruṣottama (Supreme Person); in Upaniṣadic imagery, the famous "two birds" (dvā suparṇā) metaphor represents jīvātman and paramātman as puruṣau dwelling in same tree
- Symbolic: represents apparent duality within consciousness—individual and universal, bound and free, experiencing and witnessing; the teaching that these "two" are ultimately one is central to Advaita

**Learning Tip**:
- "Puruṣau" = two puruṣas (dual nominative). Dual number in Sanskrit indicates exactly two. BG 15.16: "dvāv imau puruṣau loke" (these two puruṣas in the world: perishable and imperishable). Famous Upaniṣadic image: two birds (puruṣau) on one tree—one eating fruit (jīva), one watching (Brahman). Dual ending -au standard for -a stem masculines.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: In Sāṃkhya, infinite puruṣas exist—any two would be puruṣau; each is eternally distinct consciousness-principle; in Bhagavad Gītā 15.16-18, the dvau puruṣau (two puruṣas) are kṣara (all perishable beings) and akṣara (the imperishable Brahman), both transcended by uttama-puruṣa/puruṣottama (Kṛṣṇa as Supreme); represents levels of reality—empirical multiplicity and transcendent unity
- **Dharmic Significance**: The Upaniṣadic teaching of "dvā suparṇā sayujā sakhāyā" (two birds, closely linked companions) describes jīva and Īśvara as puruṣau—both dwelling in the body-tree; one (jīva) eats the sweet and bitter fruits (experiences karma), the other (Brahman) merely witnesses without eating; meditation on this image reveals that the "two" are actually one—jīva's true nature is Brahman; Advaita teaches that puruṣau (the apparent two) are abheda (non-different) when rightly understood; the experience of duality is avidyā, the reality is non-dual consciousness
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Bhagavad Gītā 15.16-18 (kṣara-akṣara-uttama puruṣa teaching), Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad 3.1.1 and Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad 4.6-7 (two-birds imagery), Sāṃkhya Kārikā (plurality of puruṣas)
पुरोहिताः:
# पुरोहिताः
**Transliteration**: pu-ro-hi-tāḥ
**POS**: noun (masculine, nominative plural)

**Root Analysis**:
- पुरस् (puras) "before, in front" + हित (hita) past passive participle of √धा (dhā) "to place" = पुरोहित (purohita) "placed in front, one appointed to the front"
- पुरोहिताः (purohitāḥ) nominative plural "priests, royal chaplains, those placed in front"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: those placed in front, priests, chaplains; specifically royal priests or family priests who conduct rituals
- Contextual: in Vedic and classical contexts, purohitas are learned brāhmaṇas who serve as ritual specialists, spiritual advisors, and intermediaries between humans and gods; royal purohitas (rāja-purohita) advise kings on dharmic matters and perform state rituals; family purohitas (kula-purohita) conduct saṃskāras (life-cycle rites) for households
- Symbolic: represents spiritual authority and mediation; purohitas "placed in front" of the deity during worship symbolize humanity's approach to the divine through qualified intermediaries; embody the transmission of sacred knowledge and ritual efficacy

**Learning Tip**:
- "Purohitāḥ" = priests (nominative plural). From puras (before/in front) + hita (placed). The purohita is literally "placed in front"—standing before the deity on behalf of the patron. Related: purohita (singular priest), rāja-purohita (royal priest), kula-purohita (family priest). Famous purohitas: Vasiṣṭha (purohita of Ikṣvāku dynasty), Bṛhaspati (purohita of the gods). Plural -āḥ standard for masculine -a stems.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Purohitas function as human representatives before divine powers and divine representatives before humans; in Vedic cosmology, Bṛhaspati serves as deva-purohita (priest of the gods), while Śukra serves as asura-purohita (priest of the demons)—representing the cosmic principle that even divine beings require ritual specialists; purohitas maintain ṛta (cosmic order) through correct ritual performance
- **Dharmic Significance**: Purohitas bear responsibility for accurate transmission of mantra, ritual procedure, and dharmic guidance; their pronouncements and ritual actions have binding spiritual authority; the relationship between patron and purohita is sacred—the purohita's spiritual power (brahma-tejas) protects and guides; in Yoga Vasishtha, Vasiṣṭha functions as purohita teaching Rāma dharma and jñāna; represents the guru principle in its ritual-priestly aspect, distinct from but related to the jñāna-guru (knowledge-teacher)
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Vedic Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas (purohita duties), Dharma Śāstras (qualifications and responsibilities), Rāmāyaṇa and Mahābhārata (Vasiṣṭha and other royal purohitas), Yoga Vasishtha
पुष्पाञ्जलि:
# पुष्पाञ्जलि
**Transliteration**: puṣ-pāñ-ja-li
**POS**: tatpuruṣa compound (masculine, nominative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- पुष्प (puṣpa) "flower" + अञ्जलि (añjali) "hollow of joined hands, respectful offering gesture"
- Sandhi: पुष्प (puṣpa) + अञ्जलि (añjali) = पुष्पाञ्जलि (puṣpāñjali)
- अञ्जलि from अञ्ज् (añj) "to anoint, honor" + लि (li) suffix = "reverential gesture with joined cupped hands"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: flower-offering with cupped hands, handful of flowers offered reverentially; the gesture of holding flowers in joined, cupped palms and offering them to deity or honored person
- Contextual: in pūjā (worship), puṣpāñjali is a key offering—devotee cups hands, places flowers within, and offers to deity while reciting mantras; also offered to gurus, elders, and guests as sign of reverence; in temple worship, concluding offering after ārati; in classical Indian culture, used in welcoming ceremonies
- Symbolic: flowers represent the blooming of devotion, beauty offered to divine; the cupped hands (añjali) represent the heart as vessel; puṣpāñjali symbolizes offering one's purest, most beautiful qualities to God; the gesture of raising cupped hands to forehead before offering shows elevation of consciousness toward divine

**Learning Tip**:
- "Puṣpāñjali" = puṣpa (flower) + añjali (cupped-hands offering). Compound describes both the act and the object—flowers held in reverent añjali mudrā. Related: añjali (the gesture itself, also greeting), puṣpa-pūjā (flower worship), samarpayāmi (I offer). Practice: "puṣpāñjaliṃ samarpayāmi" (I offer flower-offering). Common in pūjā and devotional contexts.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: The añjali mudrā (hands joined at heart center) channels prāṇa and focuses devotional energy; raising puṣpāñjali overhead connects anāhata-cakra (heart) with sahasrāra (crown), symbolizing heart's devotion reaching toward divine consciousness; the act of releasing flowers represents surrender, letting go of ego to merge with beloved deity
- **Dharmic Significance**: Puṣpāñjali embodies bhakti-yoga—the path of loving devotion; represents samarpan (complete offering/surrender) to Īśvara; BG teaches: "patraṃ puṣpaṃ phalaṃ toyam..." (leaf, flower, fruit, water)—simple offerings made with devotion are accepted; puṣpāñjali as upacāra (devotional service) purifies heart and cultivates prema (divine love); in guru-pūjā, offering puṣpāñjali symbolizes placing one's blossoming understanding at guru's feet
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Āgamic pūjā manuals, Bhagavad Gītā 9.26 (on devotional offerings), bhakti literature, temple worship procedures
पूरकं:
# पूरकं
**Transliteration**: pū-ra-kaṃ
**POS**: adjective (neuter, nominative/accusative singular); also functions as noun

**Root Analysis**:
- √पृ (pṛ) – "to fill, make full, nourish" + अक (aka) suffix = पूरक (pūraka) "filling, that which fills"
- पूरकम् (pūrakam) → पूरकं (pūrakaṃ) with anusvāra

**Meanings**:
- Literal: filling, making full; that which fills or completes
- Contextual: in prāṇāyāma (yogic breath control), pūraka is the technical term for inhalation—the phase where lungs are filled with prāṇa; one of three primary breath phases: pūraka (inhalation), kumbhaka (retention), recaka (exhalation); in Haṭha Yoga texts, specific techniques and ratios for pūraka are prescribed
- Symbolic: represents the receptive phase—drawing in cosmic prāṇa, filling oneself with divine energy; symbolizes the soul receiving grace, knowledge entering the vessel of consciousness; the filling that precedes fullness (pūrṇatā)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pūrakaṃ" = inhalation/filling (from √pṛ to fill + -aka). In prāṇāyāma, the three phases are: pūraka (in-breath), kumbhaka (holding), recaka (out-breath). Think: pūraka fills (pūr-) the lungs like filling a pot. Related: pūrṇa (full), prapūraka (complete filling). Remember the sequence: breathe IN (pūraka), HOLD (kumbhaka), breathe OUT (recaka).

**Metaphysics**:
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Pūraka is first stage of prāṇāyāma where prāṇa-vāyu is consciously drawn in through nāḍīs; different techniques emphasize different nostrils (iḍā vs. piṅgalā), speeds, and depths; pūraka fills the prāṇa-maya-kośa (vital sheath) with energy, preparing for kumbhaka where prāṇa is distributed and assimilated; proper pūraka balances vāta-doṣa, oxygenates blood, and calms nervous system; in advanced practice, pūraka is visualization of cosmic prāṇa filling entire subtle body
- **Dharmic Significance**: Pūraka symbolically represents śravaṇa (hearing) in jñāna-yoga—the receptive phase where teachings fill the mind; just as pūraka precedes kumbhaka (retention), hearing precedes manana (reflection) and nididhyāsana (meditation); represents the principle that one must first be emptied (through recaka/exhalation/vairāgya) to be filled with higher wisdom; the rhythm pūraka-kumbhaka-recaka mirrors cosmic cycles of creation-preservation-dissolution
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Haṭha Yoga Pradīpikā (detailed pūraka instructions), Yoga Sūtras 2.49-51 (prāṇāyāma techniques), Gheraṇḍa Saṃhitā, Śiva Saṃhitā, various prāṇāyāma manuals
पूर्ण:
# पूर्ण
**Transliteration**: pūr-ṇa
**POS**: adjective (all genders); past passive participle

**Root Analysis**:
- √पृ (pṛ) – "to fill, make full, satisfy, nourish" + न (na) past passive participle suffix = पूर्ण (pūrṇa) "filled, full, complete, whole, perfect"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: filled, full, complete, whole, perfect; lacking nothing, entire, absolute
- Contextual: in Upaniṣadic philosophy, pūrṇa describes Brahman as absolute fullness/completeness—needing nothing, containing everything; in mathematics/philosophy, denotes totality; "That is pūrṇa, this is pūrṇa" (tat pūrṇam idam pūrṇam) from Īśā Upaniṣad—both the transcendent and immanent are complete/whole
- Symbolic: represents the paradox of fullness—Brahman is pūrṇa (absolutely full) yet when pūrṇa is taken from pūrṇa, pūrṇa alone remains; symbolizes self-sufficiency, perfection, completeness that cannot be added to or diminished; the recognition of inherent wholeness versus seeking external completion

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pūrṇa" = full/complete (from √pṛ to fill + past participle -na). Central to Īśā Upaniṣad opening: "ॐ पूर्णमदः पूर्णमिदं पूर्णात् पूर्णमुदच्यते । पूर्णस्य पूर्णमादाय पूर्णमेवावशिष्यते ॥" (That is full, this is full, from fullness comes fullness; taking fullness from fullness, fullness alone remains). Related: pūrṇatā (fullness), pūraka (filling), sampūrṇa (completely full). Remember: Brahman as pūrṇa = complete, needing nothing.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Pūrṇa is the fundamental characteristic of Brahman—absolute completeness/wholeness/perfection; the famous Īśopaniṣad śānti mantra teaches that both paraṃ brahman (transcendent) and aparaṃ brahman (immanent/manifest creation) are pūrṇa; the mathematical-metaphysical paradox: infinity (pūrṇa) minus infinity (pūrṇa) equals infinity (pūrṇa)—illustrating Brahman's inexhaustible nature; represents that reality is not deficient, not becoming, but always already complete
- **Dharmic Significance**: The realization "I am pūrṇa" (aham pūrṇaḥ) is liberation—recognizing ātman's inherent completeness rather than seeking external fulfillment; all sādhana aims at removing the false sense of incompleteness (apūrṇatā) born from avidyā; the seeking itself implies "I am incomplete" which contradicts the truth "I am always already pūrṇa"; Vedānta teaches: you are not becoming pūrṇa through practices—you are discovering your nature as eternally pūrṇa; desire (kāma) arises from false apūrṇatā-buddhi (sense of incompleteness) which dissolves in ātma-jñāna
- **Mantric Significance**: The pūrṇa-mantra from Īśā/Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣads is chanted as śānti-pāṭha (peace invocation) establishing the meditation on absolute completeness before and after Upaniṣadic study; meditating on "pūrṇam" as mahā-vākya shifts consciousness from sense of lack to recognition of wholeness
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Īśopaniṣad śānti mantra, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 5.1.1, Chāndogya Upaniṣad, Advaita Vedānta texts on Brahman's pūrṇatva, Yoga Vasishtha
पूर्णज्या:
# पूर्णज्या
**Transliteration**: pūr-ṇa-jyā
**POS**: karmadhāraya compound (feminine, nominative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- पूर्ण (pūrṇa) "full, complete" + ज्या (jyā) "bowstring, chord, sine"
- ज्या from √ज्या (jyā) "to grow old, decay" (bowstring metaphorically "stretched")
- Karmadhāraya: "full sine" or "complete chord"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: full sine, complete chord; in Indian mathematics/astronomy, refers to the sine function (as opposed to half-sine or other trigonometric functions)
- Contextual: technical term in jyotiṣa (astronomy/astrology) and gaṇita (mathematics); Indian mathematicians developed trigonometry using jyā (sine) functions; pūrṇa-jyā distinguishes the full sine value from ardha-jyā (half-sine/versed sine)
- Symbolic: in mathematical contexts, represents completeness of measurement; the precision of cosmic calculations

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pūrṇa-jyā" = pūrṇa (full) + jyā (sine/chord). Technical mathematical term. Think of jyā as "bowstring" - the chord of a circle's arc. Pūrṇa-jyā = full sine function. Related: ardha-jyā (half-sine, versed sine, literally "half-chord"), koṭi-jyā (cosine, "perpendicular sine"). Indian mathematicians like Āryabhaṭa developed trigonometry using jyā functions long before European "sine" (which derives from Sanskrit jyā via Arabic jiba).
पूर्णज्यार्द्धं:
# पूर्णज्यार्द्धं
**Transliteration**: pūr-ṇa-jyār-ddhaṃ
**POS**: tatpuruṣa compound (neuter, nominative/accusative singular)

**Root Analysis**:
- पूर्णज्या (pūrṇa-jyā) "full sine" + अर्ध (ardha) "half" → पूर्णज्यार्ध (pūrṇa-jyārdha) "half of the full sine"
- Sandhi: पूर्णज्या (pūrṇa-jyā) + अर्ध (ardha) = पूर्णज्यार्ध (pūrṇa-jyārdha)
- अर्ध from √अर्ध (ardh) "to split, divide" = "half, semi-"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: half of the full sine, semi-sine; half of the complete chord
- Contextual: technical mathematical/astronomical term; represents half the value of pūrṇa-jyā; in Indian trigonometry, various fractional sines were calculated for astronomical precision
- Symbolic: (in mathematical contexts) represents partial or intermediate values in cosmic calculations

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pūrṇa-jyārdhaṃ" = pūrṇa-jyā (full sine) + ardha (half). Compound means "half of full-sine." Sandhi: -ā + a- → -ār-. Related to ardha-jyā (literally "half-chord/sine," though technically refers to versed sine, not half of sine). Indian mathematics developed precise trigonometric tables using various jyā functions. Remember: pūrṇa-jyā = full sine; pūrṇa-jyārdha = half of that value.
पूर्णमदः:
# पूर्णमदः
**Transliteration**: pūr-ṇa-ma-daḥ
**POS**: sandhi phrase (adjective + pronoun)

**Root Analysis**:
- पूर्णम् (pūrṇam) neuter nominative singular of पूर्ण (pūrṇa) "full, complete" + अदस् (adas) nominative neuter singular demonstrative pronoun "that"
- Sandhi: पूर्णम् (pūrṇam) + अदस् (adas) = पूर्णमदः (pūrṇamadaḥ) with visarga
- Full phrase: "that is full/complete"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: that is full, that (one) is complete
- Contextual: opening words of the Īśopaniṣad/Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad śānti mantra; "That" (adaḥ) refers to paraṃ brahman—the transcendent absolute reality; the mantra teaches: "pūrṇam adaḥ pūrṇam idam..." (That is full, this is full...)—both transcendent and immanent reality are complete
- Symbolic: points to the non-dual teaching that Brahman (referred to as "that"—distant, transcendent, beyond) is pūrṇa (absolutely complete/perfect); establishes the framework for understanding reality as inherently whole, not deficient

**Learning Tip**:
- "Pūrṇamadaḥ" = pūrṇam (full/complete, neuter nom.) + adas (that).
