- Symbolic: represents the dynamic, flowing nature of reality; symbolizes the continuous movement and change inherent in manifest existence; can represent either saṁsāra's current carrying souls or the divine grace flowing to devotees

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bahati" is variant of "vahati" (वहति) with ब (ba) for व (va). Standard: √वह् (vah, to carry/flow) + -ति (ti, 3rd sg. present) → vahati (carries, flows). Conjugation of √vah: vahati (3rd sg.), vahāmi (1st sg.), vahasi (2nd sg.). Root √वह् (vah) appears in: vāhana (vehicle, that which carries), vahana (carrying), āvaha (bringing toward), pravāha (current, flow), udvaha (carrying up). Common usage: nadī vahati (the river flows), vāyuḥ vahati (the wind blows), rathaḥ vahati (the chariot carries), kālaḥ vahati (time carries [all things]). Mnemonic: "vah-" sounds like "veh-icle" → vehicle carries = vahati = carries/flows.
बहिरङ्ग:
# बहिरङ्ग
**Transliteration**: ba-hir-aṅ-ga
**POS**: compound adjective/noun (tatpuruṣa) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of बहिरङ्ग (bahiraṅga) or standard बहिरङ्ग (vahiraṅga, though bahir- is more common)
- बहिस्/बहिर् (bahis/bahir) "outside, external, outer" (indeclinable) + अङ्ग (aṅga) "limb, part, member, division" (from अङ्ग् aṅg "to go" or considered primary noun) = बहिरङ्ग (bahiraṅga) "external limb, outer part, external practice/aspect"
- Sandhi: बहिस् (bahis) before vowel → बहिर् (bahir-) before consonant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: external limb, outer part, outward member, exterior aspect, exoteric practice
- Contextual: in Patañjali's Yoga Sūtras, bahiraṅga refers to the first five limbs of aṣṭāṅga-yoga (eight-limbed yoga): (1) yama (ethical restraints), (2) niyama (observances), (3) āsana (posture), (4) prāṇāyāma (breath control), (5) pratyāhāra (sense withdrawal)—these are "external limbs" preparing for the "internal limbs" (antaraṅga): dhāraṇā, dhyāna, samādhi; bahiraṅga practices work with body, breath, ethics, and senses, while antaraṅga works directly with consciousness; the division shows progressive internalization; also used generally for outer/external aspects vs. inner/internal (antar) in any context
- Symbolic: represents the preparatory, foundational stage of spiritual practice; symbolizes that outer disciplines create the conditions for inner realization; embodies the principle that spiritual path moves from gross to subtle, external to internal; the bahiraṅga is necessary groundwork but not the ultimate goal

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bahiraṅga" = bahis/bahir (outside, external) + aṅga (limb, part). Bahis (बहिस्/बहिर्) = outside, external (opposite: antar अन्तर् = inside). Aṅga (अङ्ग) = limb, part, member, division. Aṣṭāṅga-yoga (eight limbs) divided into: **Bahiraṅga** (external, first 5): yama, niyama, āsana, prāṇāyāma, pratyāhāra; **Antaraṅga** (internal, last 3): dhāraṇā, dhyāna, samādhi. Also called: bahiraṅga-sādhana (external practices) vs. antaraṅga-sādhana (internal practices). Pattern: bahir-X (external X) vs. antar-X (internal X): bahir-mukha (outward-facing) vs. antar-mukha (inward-facing). Mnemonic: "bahir" sounds like "barrier" → outer barrier/external = bahiraṅga.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Bahiraṅga represents the outer circumference of spiritual practice that interfaces with the material world; these practices purify the gross aspects of being—body (āsana), energy (prāṇāyāma), ethics (yama-niyama), sensory engagement (pratyāhāra); they prepare the vessel (adhikāra) for deeper inner work (antaraṅga); without bahiraṅga foundation, antaraṅga practices lack stability; represents the manifestation-side of sādhana
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: The five bahiraṅga practices systematically prepare body-mind: yama-niyama purify volition and character; āsana stabilizes body and prāṇic currents; prāṇāyāma refines prāṇa and removes nāḍī blockages; pratyāhāra withdraws energy from sensory dispersion; together they create the sthiratā (stability) and śuddhi (purity) required for dhāraṇā (concentration); bahiraṅga works primarily on annamaya-kośa, prāṇamaya-kośa, and indriyas
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Gaṇeśa (remover of obstacles) is associated with bahiraṅga as these practices remove outer impediments; the deities of the lower cakras (Gaṇeśa at mūlādhāra, Brahmā at svādhiṣṭhāna, etc.) govern bahiraṅga domain
- **Mantric Significance**: Bahiraṅga practices use gross mantras and external forms; utterance is vocal (vācika) or mental but with form (saguṇa); as practice deepens toward antaraṅga, mantra becomes subtler, moving from gross sound to internal vibration to soundless resonance
- **Dharmic Significance**: Bahiraṅga establishes dharmic foundation (yama-niyama) and prepares consciousness for inward turn; while essential, these practices are means (sādhana) not goal (sādhya); over-emphasis on bahiraṅga alone keeps practitioner at superficial level; balanced approach: establish bahiraṅga then progressively move to antaraṅga; in jīvanmukti, bahiraṅga continues naturally but without identification
- **Symbolic Representation**: Depicted as the outer walls, courtyards, and gateways of a temple, leading progressively inward to the garbha-gṛha (inner sanctum = antaraṅga); in yogic diagrams, the outer practices surrounding the central core of consciousness
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Yoga Sūtra of Patañjali (III.7-8 explicitly distinguishes bahiraṅga from antaraṅga: "trayam antaraṅgaṃ pūrvebhyaḥ" = the three [dhāraṇā, dhyāna, samādhi] are internal compared to the previous [five]); commentaries by Vyāsa, Vācaspati Miśra; Haṭha Yoga Pradīpikā; Yoga Yājñavalkya
बहिरिन्द्रियाणि:
# बहिरिन्द्रियाणि
**Transliteration**: ba-hir-in-dri-yā-ṇi
**POS**: compound noun (neuter nominative/accusative plural) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of बहिरिन्द्रियाणि (bahirindriyāṇi) or standard बहिः + इन्द्रियाणि
- बहिस्/बहिः (bahis/bahiḥ) "outside, outward, external" + इन्द्रिय (indriya) "sense organ, faculty" (from इन्द्र Indra + य ya suffix = "belonging to Indra" = power/faculty) in neuter nominative/accusative plural इन्द्रियाणि (indriyāṇi) = बहिरिन्द्रियाणि (bahirindriyāṇi) "external sense organs, outward-directed senses"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: external sense organs, outward-facing senses, senses directed toward outside objects, the organs of perception oriented externally
- Contextual: refers to the five jñānendriyāṇi (organs of knowledge/perception): śrotra (ear/hearing), tvak (skin/touch), cakṣus (eye/sight), jihvā (tongue/taste), ghrāṇa (nose/smell)—when oriented toward external objects (viṣaya); contrasts with antaḥkaraṇa (internal instrument = mind-intellect-ego-citta) which is inward; in spiritual practice, bahirindriyāṇi naturally flow outward toward sense objects, creating dispersion (vikṣepa); pratyāhāra practice withdraws these from external objects; the qualifier "bahir" emphasizes the outward orientation that binds consciousness to external world
- Symbolic: represents the gates through which consciousness habitually flows outward into objectivity; symbolizes the challenge of spiritual practice—the natural centrifugal tendency of awareness; embodies the teaching that liberation requires reversing this outward flow (nivṛtti) through inward turning (pratyak)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bahirindriyāṇi" = bahis/bahiḥ (outside, external) + indriyāṇi (sense organs, neuter nom./acc. plural of indriya). Bahis (बहिस्/बहिः) = outside, outward (opposite: antar = inside). Indriya (इन्द्रिय) = sense organ, faculty. Two types of indriya: (1) **jñānendriya** (ज्ञानेन्द्रिय) = organs of knowledge/perception (5): ear, skin, eye, tongue, nose; (2) **karmendriya** (कर्मेन्द्रिय) = organs of action (5): voice, hands, feet, anus, genitals. Total: 10 indriyas. Bahirindriyāṇi = senses oriented outward toward objects (viṣaya). Contrast: antaḥkaraṇa (अन्तःकरण) = internal instrument = manas-buddhi-ahaṃkāra-citta. Pratyāhāra = withdrawing bahirindriyāṇi from viṣayas. Mnemonic: "bahir" (outer) + "indriya" (sense) → senses flowing outward.
बा:
# बा
**Transliteration**: bā
**POS**: indeclinable particle (avyaya) — variant spelling or possibly different word

**Root Analysis**:
- Not derived from a verbal root. Functions as an indeclinable particle.
- This may be: (1) a variant/shortened form of वा (vā) "or" with ब for व, or (2) possibly बा as an emphatic or vocative particle in certain contexts, or (3) a manuscript variant
- Standard disjunctive particle is वा (vā) "or"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: If this is variant of वा (vā): or, either, alternatively, optionally; if independent: possibly emphatic/vocative particle (context-dependent)
- Contextual: as vā-variant, used to present alternatives or options in philosophical discourse; "X vā Y" (X or Y), "vā...vā..." (either...or...); common in Upaniṣadic and philosophical texts when offering alternative interpretations or paths; indicates non-exclusivity or multiplicity of valid approaches
- Symbolic: if representing vā, symbolizes the flexibility and non-dogmatic nature of authentic spiritual teaching; acknowledges multiple valid perspectives (anekānta-vāda); represents the principle that truth can be approached from various angles

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bā" likely variant of "vā" (वा) with ब for व. Standard: वा (vā) = or, either, alternatively. Usage: "X vā Y" (X or Y); "brahma vā ātmā" (Brahman or the Self, i.e., Brahman which is the Self); "vā...vā..." (either...or...). Common phrases: "iti vā" (or thus, or rather), "athavā" (अथवा, or else, or rather, from atha + vā). Vā is extremely common particle appearing thousands of times in Sanskrit literature. Pattern: X vā Y vā = X or Y (offering alternatives). Disjunctive (vā) vs. conjunctive (ca = and): "rāmaḥ ca kṛṣṇaḥ ca" (Rāma and Kṛṣṇa) vs. "rāmaḥ vā kṛṣṇaḥ vā" (Rāma or Kṛṣṇa). Mnemonic: "vā" sounds like "va-a" (or-ah) → presenting an alternative = or.
बाक्:
# बाक्
**Transliteration**: bāk
**POS**: noun (feminine) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of वाक् (vāk)
- √वच् (vac) – "to speak, to say, to tell" + क् (k) suffix = वाक् (vāk) "speech, voice, word, utterance, sacred sound"
- Note: Standard form is वाक् (vāk); बाक् (bāk) represents व (va) → ब (ba) variant spelling

**Meanings**:
- Literal: speech, voice, word, utterance, statement, sacred sound, language, verbal expression (variant of vāk)
- Contextual: in Vedic and Upaniṣadic texts, Vāk is personified as the goddess of speech (later identified with Sarasvatī); Vāk is the creative cosmic principle—the divine word through which Brahman manifests creation; the famous Vāk-sūkta (Ṛg Veda X.125) where Vāk speaks of herself as pervading all existence; in yoga and Tantra, vāk represents the vibratory śabda-tattva (sound principle) that is the substrate of manifestation; four levels of vāk: parā (supreme, transcendent), paśyantī (seeing/visionary), madhyamā (intermediate/mental), vaikharī (gross/articulated speech)
- Symbolic: represents the cosmic creative vibration (spanda); symbolizes that reality is fundamentally sonic/vibratory; embodies the principle that consciousness expresses through sound/word; Vāk is śakti, the dynamic power of the static Brahman; the universe is described as vāk-prapañca (expansion of the Word)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bāk" is variant of "vāk" (वाक्) with ब for व. Standard: वाक् (vāk) from √वच् (vac, to speak). Root √वच् appears in: vacana (utterance), vācā (by speech, instrumental), vācya (to be said), ukta (spoken). Vāk (वाक्) = speech, word, goddess Speech. Declension irregular: vāk (nom. sg.), vācam (acc. sg.), vācā (inst. sg.), vāci (loc. sg.). Four levels of vāk: (1) **parā** (परा) = supreme, transcendent; (2) **paśyantī** (पश्यन्ती) = seeing, visionary; (3) **madhyamā** (मध्यमा) = intermediate, mental; (4) **vaikharī** (वैखरी) = gross, articulated. Goddess: Vāc/Sarasvatī = goddess of speech, learning, arts. Vāk-śakti = power of speech. Mnemonic: "vāk" sounds like "v-awk" (voice-talk) → speech/voice = vāk.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Vāk is the primordial cosmic vibration (nāda, spanda, śabda-brahman) through which the unmanifest Brahman becomes manifest creation; the creative logos or divine word; in the Ṛg Veda, Vāk declares "I pervade heaven and earth" and "I give birth to the father [Brahman] on the head of this [creation]"—showing Vāk as the creative śakti; in Kashmir Śaivism, parā-vāk is the highest vibration of consciousness (cit-spanda) which descends through paśyantī, madhyamā, to vaikharī (our gross speech); all manifestation is vāk-prapañca (expansion of the Word)
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Vāk-sādhana (practice with speech/mantra) purifies consciousness; the four levels of vāk correspond to progressively subtler dimensions: vaikharī (throat cakra, gross speech), madhyamā (heart cakra, mental speech), paśyantī (navel cakra, intuitive seeing), parā (beyond cakras, transcendent vibration); mantra-japa moves from vaikharī (vocal) through madhyamā (mental) to ajapa (spontaneous, subtle); realization of parā-vāk is realization of śabda-brahman
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Vāk is personified as the goddess Vāc/Sarasvatī, consort of Brahmā (creator); she is white-clad, holding vīṇā (cosmic harmony), book (knowledge), japa-mālā (mantra), kamaṇḍalu (waters of wisdom); as Sarasvatī, she governs learning, music, arts, eloquence; in Tantra, she is Mātṛkā-śakti (power of the letters/phonemes); the 50 varṇas (letters) are her 50 forms; she is invoked for speech-perfection (vāk-siddhi)
- **Mantric Significance**: All mantras are manifestations of Vāk-śakti; the bīja mantras are condensed forms of cosmic vāk; OM is the quintessence of vāk; the practice of mantra-japa is worship of Vāk/Sarasvatī; vāk-siddhi (perfection of speech) is attained through mantra; the Gāyatrī mantra addresses Savitr but is itself vāk; perfect speech (ṛta-vāk, satya-vāk) arises from realization of parā-vāk; silence (mauna) is the womb of vāk
- **Dharmic Significance**: Satya-vācana (truthful speech) is fundamental dharma; right speech (samyag-vāk) is part of the eightfold path; vāk is a primary means of knowledge (śabda-pramāṇa = verbal testimony); Vedas are called apauruṣeya-vāk (non-human speech, divine revelation); the power of vāk creates bondage (through false speech, harsh speech) or liberation (through mantra, truth, sacred study); in jīvanmukti, one's speech becomes spontaneous truth (ṛta-vāk)
- **Symbolic Representation**: Depicted as Goddess Sarasvatī with vīṇā (cosmic sound), swan (discrimination), lotus (purity), book (Vedas); in yantras, represented by the Mātṛkā (alphabet letters) arranged in cakras; the 50 petals of the cakras bearing the 50 varṇas represent Vāk's manifestation; in iconography, the tongue (jihvā) is the seat of Vāk-devī
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Ṛg Veda X.125 (Vāk-sūkta—hymn of Speech personified); Ṛg Veda X.71 (on the origin of speech); Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad (I.5.3, vāk as vital force); Taittirīya Upaniṣad (on vāk and prāṇa); Vāc Ambhṛṇī Sūkta; Devī Māhātmya (Sarasvatī as Vāk); Tantric texts on four levels of vāk (Tantrāloka, Parā-triṃśikā-vivaraṇa); Vākyapadīya of Bhartṛhari (philosophy of language and vāk); Yoga Vāsiṣṭha; Śiva Sūtras
बाक्पाणि:
# बाक्पाणि
**Transliteration**: bāk-pā-ṇi
**POS**: compound noun (tatpuruṣa or karmadhāraya, masculine/feminine) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of वाक्पाणि (vākpāṇi)
- वाक्/बाक् (vāk/bāk) "speech, voice" (from √वच् vac "to speak") + पाणि (pāṇi) "hand, palm" (from √पा pā "to protect" or considered primary noun) = वाक्पाणि/बाक्पाणि (vākpāṇi/bākpāṇi) "hand of speech, speaking hand, hand that speaks"
- Note: Standard form is वाक्पाणि (vākpāṇi); बाक्पाणि (bākpāṇi) represents व → ब variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: hand of speech, speaking hand, hand that communicates like speech, hand associated with speech/voice
- Contextual: refers to hand gestures (mudrā, hasta) that communicate meaning like spoken language; in Indian classical traditions, hand gestures in dance, ritual, and iconography convey specific meanings; the hasta-mudrās of nāṭya-śāstra "speak" narratives without words; in deity iconography, each hand position (abhaya-mudrā, varada-mudrā, jñāna-mudrā, etc.) communicates divine qualities or blessings; metaphorically, skilled hands that express what speech cannot (as in art, music, sculpture)
- Symbolic: represents the embodiment of meaning in non-verbal forms; symbolizes that divine communication transcends verbal language; embodies the teaching that truth can be expressed through gesture, form, and action as much as through words; the unity of vāk (speech/expression) and karma (action)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bākpāṇi" is variant of "vākpāṇi" (वाक्पाणि) with ब for व. Compound: vāk (speech) + pāṇi (hand) = vākpāṇi (speaking hand, hand that communicates). Pāṇi (पाणि) = hand, palm (often used for "hand" in compounds rather than hasta). Examples: pāṇi-graha (taking hand = marriage), su-pāṇi (beautiful hands), pāṇi-tala (palm). Pattern of "speaking X": vāk-cakṣus (speaking eye = expressive eyes), vāk-mudrā (speech gesture). In context: hasta-mudrās (hand gestures) in dance and ritual are vākpāṇi—hands that speak. The 24 single-hand mudrās and 13 double-hand mudrās in Bharata-nāṭya each convey specific meanings = vākpāṇi. Mnemonic: vāk (speech) + pāṇi (hand) → hand that speaks = expressive gesture.
बाचस्पतिः:
# बाचस्पतिः
**Transliteration**: bā-cas-pa-tiḥ
**POS**: compound noun (ṣaṣṭhī-tatpuruṣa, masculine nominative singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of वाचस्पतिः (vācaspatiḥ), another name for बृहस्पति (bṛhaspati)
- वाच् (vāc) "speech" → genitive stem वाचस् (vācas) "of speech" + पति (pati) "lord, master" (from √पा pā "to protect") = वाचस्पति (vācaspati) "lord of speech"
- Nominative singular: वाचस्पतिः (vācaspatiḥ)
- Note: Standard form is वाचस्पतिः; बाचस्पतिः represents व → ब variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: lord of speech, master of eloquence, lord of sacred utterance (variant of vācaspati)
- Contextual: epithet and alternative name for Bṛhaspati (बृहस्पति), the divine preceptor (guru) of the gods (devas); Bṛhaspati/Vācaspati is the deity governing wisdom, learning, sacred speech, eloquence, and teaching; as lord of vāc (speech), he presides over all forms of communication, especially sacred utterances, mantras, and Vedic recitation; in astrology/astronomy, he is the planet Jupiter (Guru-graha); in human realm, the guru embodies Vācaspati's function—transmitting wisdom through speech
- Symbolic: represents the divine principle of wisdom expressing itself through perfect speech; symbolizes that true knowledge manifests as eloquent, truthful, beneficial speech; embodies the unity of jñāna (knowledge) and vāk (expression)—wisdom that can be communicated; represents the guru-tattva, the teaching principle

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bācaspatiḥ" is variant of "vācaspatiḥ" (वाचस्पतिः) with ब for व = another name for Bṛhaspati (बृहस्पति). Compound: vācas (of speech, genitive of vāc) + pati (lord) = vācaspati (lord of speech). Pattern: X-pati = lord of X: deva-pati (lord of gods = Indra), prajā-pati (lord of creatures = Brahmā), vāc-pati/vācas-pati (lord of speech = Bṛhaspati). Bṛhaspati = bṛhat (great, vast) + pati (lord) = great lord. He is: (1) guru of devas, (2) lord of wisdom and eloquence, (3) planet Jupiter, (4) presiding deity of Thursday (guru-vāra). Iconography: golden/yellow, corpulent, holding book and mālā, riding white elephant. Mnemonic: vācaspati = vāc (speech) + pati (lord) = lord of eloquent/sacred speech = Bṛhaspati.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Vācaspati/Bṛhaspati is the cosmic guru, the principle of divine teaching and transmission of sacred knowledge; he governs the flow of wisdom from the transcendent to the manifest through the medium of speech; as lord of vāc, he ensures that Vedic knowledge (śruti) is preserved and transmitted correctly; cosmically, he represents the buddhi-tattva (intelligence principle) at its highest, purest expression; he mediates between divine consciousness and human understanding
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Invoked for vāk-siddhi (perfection of speech), vidyā (knowledge), and buddhi-vṛddhi (increase of intelligence); worship of Bṛhaspati/Vācaspati enhances learning capacity, memory, eloquence, and teaching ability; associated with viśuddha-cakra (throat center, seat of speech) and ājñā-cakra (command center, seat of buddhi); Thursday (guru-vāra) is auspicious for mantra initiation and spiritual teaching; yellow color, yellow sapphire (puṣparāga) are his
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Bṛhaspati/Vācaspati, the golden teacher-deity; guru of the devas (divine beings); consort is Tārā (goddess of stars/navigation through knowledge); son is Kacha (immortal knowledge); he is the priest who officiates in divine yajñas; represents the archetypal guru; every human guru is considered an earthly manifestation of Bṛhaspati
- **Mantric Significance**: "Om Bṛhaspataye Namaḥ" or "Om Vācaspataye Namaḥ" are primary mantras; invoked before study, teaching, or giving discourse; Bṛhaspati mantras enhance learning and remove obstacles to knowledge; as lord of vāc, all sacred utterances flow through his grace; Thursday is the day for special japa of Bṛhaspati mantras; bīja: "Bṛṃ" (बृं)
- **Dharmic Significance**: Represents the guru-tattva—the teaching principle that is essential for spiritual progress; "guru Brahma, guru Viṣṇu, guru devo Maheśvaraḥ" acknowledges guru (Bṛhaspati's earthly form) as supreme; proper speech (satya-vāk, priya-vāk, hita-vāk) is worship of Vācaspati; study of śāstras, contemplation, and teaching are his path; Thursday fasting (guru-vāra-vrata) purifies speech and enhances wisdom; in jyotiṣa, strong Jupiter gives dharmic wisdom and eloquence
- **Symbolic Representation**: Depicted as corpulent golden-yellow deity, holding sacred texts (Vedas/śāstras), prayer beads (mālā for japa), water pot (kamaṇḍalu); riding white elephant (Airāvata) or in chariot drawn by eight horses; sometimes four-armed; wears sacred thread (yajñopavīta); surrounded by students receiving teaching; Jupiter planet in astronomy
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Ṛg Veda (II.23, X.68—hymns to Bṛhaspati as lord of prayer/speech); Bṛhaspati Sūkta; Bṛhaspati Smṛti; Purāṇas (extensive sections on Bṛhaspati as guru of devas); Jyotiṣa śāstras (on Jupiter/Guru graha); Guru Gītā; Guru Pūjā texts; Tantras on guru-tattva
बाजश्रबस:
# बाजश्रबस
**Transliteration**: bā-jaś-ra-ba-sa
**POS**: compound word (possibly corrupted or variant form)

**Root Analysis**:
- Likely a corrupted or variant form of वाजश्रवस (vājaśravas) with ब for व
- वाज (vāja) "strength, vigor, prize, food" + श्रवस् (śravas) "fame, glory, renown" (from √श्रु śru "to hear" = that which is heard/renowned) = वाजश्रवस (vājaśravas) "possessing strength and fame, strong and renowned"
- This appears as a proper name in Vedic and Upaniṣadic texts

**Meanings**:
- Literal: possessing strength and fame, strong and renowned, one who has vigor and glory (likely variant of vājaśravas)
- Contextual: Vājaśravas (or variant Bājaśrabas with ब for व) is the name of Naciketas' father in the Kaṭha Upaniṣad—a brāhmaṇa who performs the viśvajit sacrifice; also appears as a Vedic ṛṣi name; the name combines martial/physical strength (vāja) with spiritual/social glory (śravas); represents the worldly householder concerned with ritual merit and reputation
- Symbolic: in the Kaṭha Upaniṣad context, Vājaśravas represents the conventional religious practitioner who performs rituals mechanically without deeper understanding—contrasted with his son Naciketas who seeks ultimate truth; symbolizes external religiosity vs. inner spiritual seeking

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bājaśrabas" is likely variant of "vājaśravas" (वाजश्रवस) with ब for व. Compound: vāja (strength, vigor, prize) + śravas (fame, glory, renown) = vājaśravas (strong and renowned). Śravas (श्रवस्) from √श्रु (śru, to hear) = that which is heard = fame, renown, glory. This is the name of Naciketas' father in Kaṭha Upaniṣad—the brāhmaṇa who performs viśvajit yajña but gives away old, useless cows (prompting Naciketas to question and eventually seek Yama). Also a Vedic ṛṣi name. Pattern: X-śravas = "having X fame/glory": su-śravas (good fame), uru-śravas (wide fame). Mnemonic: vāja (vigor) + śravas (renown) → renowned for strength/vigor.
बाणि:
# बाणि
**Transliteration**: bā-ṇi
**POS**: noun (feminine) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of वाणी (vāṇī)
- √वच् (vac) – "to speak, to say" + णी (ṇī) suffix (variant of -नी -nī) = वाणी (vāṇī) "speech, voice, word, eloquence, sacred utterance"
- Note: Standard form is वाणी (vāṇī); बाणि (bāṇi) represents व → ब variant spelling

**Meanings**:
- Literal: speech, voice, word, utterance, eloquence, sacred sound, language (variant of vāṇī)
- Contextual: essentially same as वाक् (vāk) and वाणी (vāṇī)—refers to speech, especially divine or sacred speech; Vāṇī is another name for Goddess Sarasvatī, the deity of speech, learning, music, and arts; "vāṇī-devī" = goddess of speech; vāṇī can mean voice (individual speech faculty), language (collection of words), or eloquence (skillful/beautiful speech); often appears in poetic/devotional contexts referring to melodious or inspired speech
- Symbolic: same as vāk—represents divine creative vibration and expression; Vāṇī as goddess embodies the śakti (power) of communication and knowledge transmission; symbolizes that consciousness expresses and creates through sound/word

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bāṇi" is variant of "vāṇī" (वाणी) with ब for व. Standard: वाणी (vāṇī) from √वच् (vac, to speak). Vāṇī is essentially synonymous with vāk (वाक्) = speech, but vāṇī has slightly more poetic/feminine connotation and is more commonly used as the goddess name. Vāk vs. Vāṇī: both from √vac, both mean speech, both refer to Sarasvatī, largely interchangeable. Pattern: vāṇī-devī (goddess of speech), su-vāṇī (eloquent speech), madhura-vāṇī (sweet voice). Goddess Sarasvatī is called: Vāk, Vāṇī, Sarasvatī, Śāradā, Bhāratī, Vāgdevī. The word vāṇī appears in bhakti poetry: "vāṇī me racanā" (composition in my speech/voice). Mnemonic: vāṇī sounds like "vani" (voice in some languages) → voice/speech = vāṇī.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Same as Vāk—Vāṇī is the cosmic creative vibration; as goddess (Vāṇī-devī/Sarasvatī), she is the śakti of Brahmā the creator; she enables the manifestation of knowledge and expression of wisdom; the universe is her utterance; learning, arts, music, and all forms of knowledge flow from her
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Invoked for vāk-siddhi (perfection of speech), kavitva (poetic ability), saṅgīta (musical skill), and vidyā (knowledge); worship of Vāṇī/Sarasvatī on Vasanta Pañcamī (spring fifth) and Sarasvatī Pūjā; associated with viśuddha-cakra (throat center); white color and white flowers offered; practice of mantra-japa, devotional singing (bhajan/kīrtan), and scriptural recitation are vāṇī-sādhana
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Vāṇī-devī = Sarasvatī, the white-clad goddess seated on white lotus or riding white swan (haṁsa); holds vīṇā (stringed instrument = cosmic harmony), pustaka (book = knowledge), akṣa-mālā (rosary = japa), kamaṇḍalu (water pot = purification); consort of Brahmā; mother of the Vedas; patroness of students, artists, musicians
- **Mantric Significance**: "Om Aiṁ Sarasvatyai Namaḥ" (Aiṁ is bīja of Sarasvatī/Vāṇī); "Yā kundendu-tuṣāra-hāra-dhavalā..." (famous Sarasvatī hymn); invoked before study, teaching, writing, or performing arts; Sarasvatī Vandanā recited by students; vāṇī-stuti (praise of speech goddess) before discourse
- **Dharmic Significance**: Right speech (samyag-vāk) is worship of Vāṇī; satya-vāṇī (truthful speech), priya-vāṇī (pleasant speech), hita-vāṇī (beneficial speech) are her expressions; study of śāstras, cultivation of arts, and teaching are her service; in jñāna-mārga, Vāṇī represents the transmission principle—wisdom flowing from guru to disciple through sacred speech
- **Symbolic Representation**: White swan (haṁsa = discrimination between milk and water, eternal and ephemeral), white lotus (purity, spiritual unfoldment), vīṇā (harmony, nāda), book (Vedas, knowledge), white color (sattva, purity); depicted in meditation posture or playing vīṇā; sometimes four-armed
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Ṛg Veda (Vāk-sūkta, Sarasvatī hymns); Sarasvatī Stotra; Vāgdevī Stotra; Tantras on Mātṛkā-śakti and Sarasvatī; Devī Māhātmya; Sarasvatī Kavacam; Śāradā Stotra; texts on four levels of vāk apply to Vāṇī
बाण्या:
# बाण्या
**Transliteration**: bā-ṇyā
**POS**: noun (feminine instrumental singular) — variant spelling

- This is a variant spelling of वाण्या (vāṇyā), instrumental case of वाणी (vāṇī)
- वाणी (vāṇī) "speech" (from √वच् vac "to speak") → instrumental singular वाण्या (vāṇyā) "by means of speech, through speech, with voice"
- Note: Standard form is वाण्या (vāṇyā); बाण्या (bāṇyā) represents व → ब variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: by means of speech, through speech, with voice, by utterance, through the medium of words (variant of vāṇyā, instrumental of vāṇī)
- Contextual: instrumental case indicating the means or instrument; used in phrases like "vāṇyā prokta" (declared by speech), "vāṇyā sṛṣṭi" (creation through speech/word); emphasizes speech as the instrument or medium through which something is accomplished; in Vedāntic contexts, can refer to knowledge transmitted through verbal instruction (śabda-pramāṇa)
- Symbolic: represents the instrumental power of divine speech in creation and transmission; symbolizes that vāk/vāṇī is not just expression but an active creative and transformative force

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bāṇyā" is variant of "vāṇyā" (वाण्या) with ब for व = instrumental case of vāṇī (speech). Declension: vāṇī (nom. sg.) → vāṇyā (inst. sg.). Instrumental case (tṛtīyā vibhakti) shows "by means of, with, through". Pattern: X-yā in instrumental: dhīyā (by intelligence), śraddhayā (by faith), bhaktyā (by devotion), vāṇyā (by speech). Usage: "vāṇyā prokta" = declared by speech; "vāṇyā siddhiḥ" = perfection through/of speech. The instrumental answers "how?" or "by what means?". Mnemonic: vāṇyā sounds like "vāṇī + ā" (with speech) → instrumental = by means of speech.
बाबृहत्वं:
# बाबृहत्वं
**Transliteration**: bā-bṛ-hat-vaṃ
**POS**: abstract noun (neuter nominative/accusative singular with anusvāra) — likely compound or variant

**Root Analysis**:
- Unclear compound; possibly बा (bā, variant of vā "or"?) + बृहत्त्व (bṛhattva) "greatness"
- More likely: बृहत्त्व (bṛhattva) with prefix or simple variant बाबृहत्व
- बृहत् (bṛhat) "great, vast, large, expansive" (from √बृह् bṛh "to grow, increase, expand") + त्व (tva) abstract noun suffix = बृहत्त्व (bṛhattva) "greatness, vastness, magnitude, expansiveness"
- The बा- (bā-) prefix is unclear; may be variant, corruption, or emphatic particle

**Meanings**:
- Literal: greatness, vastness, magnitude, expansiveness, state of being great/large (likely variant or compound form of bṛhattva)
- Contextual: describes the quality of vastness or greatness; in philosophical texts, can refer to the infinite magnitude of Brahman (bṛhat = one of Brahman's epithets); cosmic vastness or divine grandeur; the expansive nature of consciousness or reality
- Symbolic: represents the infinite, boundless nature of ultimate reality; symbolizes the transcendence of all limitations; embodies the teaching that Brahman is ananta (endless), apramāṇa (immeasurable), and bṛhat (vast)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bābṛhatvaṃ" likely related to "bṛhattva" (बृहत्त्व) = greatness, vastness. Root √बृह् (bṛh, to grow, expand, be great): bṛhat (great, vast), bṛhati (it grows), bṛṁhaṇa (increase, nourishment), brahman (Brahman, the vast/expanding reality). The -tva/-ttva suffix forms abstract nouns: bṛhat (great) → bṛhattva (greatness); mahā (great) → māhātmya (greatness); deva (god) → devatva (divinity). Brahman is called bṛhat (the vast one); Bṛhad-āraṇyaka Upaniṣad = "great forest teaching". Pattern: X + -tva = X-ness, state of being X. Mnemonic: "bṛhat" sounds like "big-heart" → vast/great → bṛhattva = vastness/greatness.
बामाधर्म्म:
# बामाधर्म्म
**Transliteration**: bā-mā-dhar-mma
**POS**: compound noun (tatpuruṣa, masculine) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of वामाधर्म (vāmādharma) with ब for व and double म् (mm)
- वाम (vāma) "left, reverse, contrary, inauspicious" (or "beautiful, desirable" in different context) + धर्म (dharma) "law, duty, practice, path, religion" (from √धृ dhṛ "to hold, support") = वामाधर्म (vāmādharma) "left-hand path, vāma practice, tantric dharma"
- Note: Standard would be वामाधर्म (vāmādharma); बामाधर्म्म shows ब for व and geminate म्म

**Meanings**:
- Literal: left-hand path, vāma practice, reverse/contrary dharma, left-path spiritual discipline (variant of vāmādharma)
- Contextual: in Tantra, vāmācāra (left-hand path) or vāmādharma refers to esoteric practices that may involve transgressive elements (pañca-makāra: wine, meat, fish, parched grain, sexual union) used ritually for spiritual transformation; contrasts with dakṣiṇācāra (right-hand path) which follows orthodox Vedic practices; vāmādharma can also mean practices focusing on the goddess (vāmā = beautiful feminine = śakti); the "left" designation comes from Śiva's left side being occupied by Śakti/Devī; not necessarily "evil" but esoteric, non-conventional, focused on śakti-worship
- Symbolic: represents the transcendent approach that goes beyond conventional morality to reach non-dual realization; symbolizes using poison as medicine, transforming base elements into spiritual attainment; embodies the teaching that for the realized, all dualities (pure/impure, auspicious/inauspicious) dissolve

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bāmādharma" is variant of "vāmādharma" (वामाधर्म) with ब for व. Compound: vāma (left) + dharma (path/practice) = vāmādharma (left-hand path). Tantra divided into: **Vāmācāra** (वामाचार) = left-hand path (esoteric, transgressive practices) vs. **Dakṣiṇācāra** (दक्षिणाचार) = right-hand path (orthodox, Vedic practices). Vāma (वाम) meanings: (1) left (opposite: dakṣiṇa = right), (2) reverse/contrary, (3) beautiful/desirable (as epithet of goddess). The pañca-makāra (five M's) of vāmācāra: madya (wine), māṃsa (meat), matsya (fish), mudrā (parched grain), maithuna (sexual union). Not for beginners! Only under guru guidance. Mnemonic: vāma (left) + dharma (path) → left-hand tantric path.
बायु:
# बायु
**Transliteration**: bā-yu
**POS**: noun (masculine) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of वायु (vāyu)
- √वा (vā) – "to blow, to move" + यु (yu) suffix = वायु (vāyu) "wind, air, breath, life force"
- Note: Standard form is वायु (vāyu); बायु (bāyu) represents व → ब variant spelling

**Meanings**:
- Literal: wind, air, breath, breeze, life force, vital air (variant of vāyu)
- Contextual: same as vāyu—refers to: (1) physical wind/air, (2) Vāyu the wind deity, (3) prāṇa-vāyu (vital air in the body), (4) one of the pañca-mahābhūtas (five great elements); Vāyu is personified as the wind god, father of Hanumān and Bhīma; in yogic physiology, vāyu refers to the vital airs (pañca-prāṇa: prāṇa-vāyu, apāna-vāyu, etc.); vāyu-tattva is the air element, associated with touch (sparśa), heart center (anāhata-cakra), and movement
- Symbolic: represents the dynamic, mobile principle in creation; symbolizes prāṇa as the universal life force; embodies the principle of movement, change, and vitality; vāyu is the mediator between earth and ether, connecting gross and subtle

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bāyu" is variant of "vāyu" (वायु) with ब for व. Standard: वायु (vāyu) from √वा (vā, to blow, move). Vāyu (वायु) = (1) wind/air element, (2) wind god, (3) vital air/prāṇa, (4) one of pañca-mahābhūta (five elements): pṛthivī (earth), ap/jala (water), tejas/agni (fire), **vāyu** (air), ākāśa (ether). Vāyu-deva = wind god, father of Hanumān (वानर/monkey hero of Rāmāyaṇa) and Bhīma (पाण्डव hero of Mahābhārata). Vāyu-tattva associated with: anāhata-cakra (heart), sparśa (touch), movement. Pañca-vāyu (five vital airs) all called vāyu: prāṇa-vāyu, apāna-vāyu, samāna-vāyu, udāna-vāyu, vyāna-vāyu. Mnemonic: vāyu sounds like "vā" (to blow) + "yu" → that which blows = wind/air = vāyu.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Vāyu is the air element (vāyu-tattva), fourth of the pañca-mahābhūta; it is the cosmic wind that moves and animates all existence; as a tattva, vāyu provides mobility, dynamism, and life; it is subtler than earth, water, and fire, but grosser than ether (ākāśa); in cosmogony, vāyu arises from ākāśa and gives rise to agni; vāyu pervades the atmosphere (antarikṣa) and connects heaven and earth; as prāṇa, vāyu is the universal life principle sustaining all beings
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Vāyu-tattva is centered at anāhata-cakra (heart center), associated with touch (sparśa-tanmātra), green/smoky color, hexagonal shape; prāṇāyāma works directly with vāyu; the five prāṇa-vāyus circulate through 72,000 nāḍīs; vāyu flows primarily through iḍā, piṅgalā, and suṣumnā; balancing vāyu removes restlessness (vāta-doṣa imbalance in Āyurveda); mastery of vāyu grants laghimā-siddhi (lightness), ability to levitate, and prāṇa-saṁyama
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Vāyu-deva/Vāta/Pavana/Māruta—the wind god; depicted riding deer or chariot pulled by 1000 horses; dark/smoky complexion, swift movement; father of Hanumān (embodiment of prāṇa control, vāyu-putra) and Bhīma (mighty strength from vāyu); friend of Agni and Indra; Vāyu carries Agni's flames and Indra's thunderbolts; represents the active, dynamic divine principle
- **Mantric Significance**: "Om Vāyave Namaḥ" or "Om Pavana-sūnave Namaḥ" (to son of wind = Hanumān); bīja mantra YAM (यं) for vāyu-tattva/anāhata-cakra; invoking Vāyu brings vitality, removes stagnation, increases prāṇa; Mārut-stotra (hymn to wind-gods); so'ham ajapa-japa (breath awareness) is vāyu-sādhana
- **Dharmic Significance**: Vāyu as prāṇa is the link between body and consciousness; control of vāyu (prāṇāyāma) is essential for yoga; vāyu carries the subtle body (sūkṣma-śarīra) at death and rebirth; when prāṇa-vāyu and apāna-vāyu unite, kuṇḍalinī awakens; in jīvanmukti, the sage transcends identification with vāyu but it continues functioning naturally; vāyu represents change, impermanence—all composite things are moved by vāyu toward dissolution
- **Symbolic Representation**: Depicted as smoky/gray, swift deity on deer; anāhata-cakra yantra shows smoky hexagon (vāyu-maṇḍala); wind patterns, swirling motifs; flags and banners moved by wind symbolize vāyu; prāṇa visualized as luminous currents of vāyu flowing through nāḍīs
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Ṛg Veda (hymns to Vāyu, especially VII.90-92); Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad (I.5.22-23, vāyu as cosmic life); Chāndogya Upaniṣad (vāyu-vidyā); Praśna Upaniṣad (II, prāṇa and vāyu); Yoga Sūtra (prāṇāyāma, II.49-53); Haṭha Yoga Pradīpikā (vāyu/prāṇa practices); Śiva Saṁhitā; Śāṇḍilya Upaniṣad; Purāṇas (Vāyu-deva myths)
बायुराकाशमेबच:
# बायुराकाशमेबच
**Transliteration**: bā-yur-ā-kā-śa-me-ba-ca
**POS**: compound phrase with particles (sandhi form, variant spelling)

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling with sandhi: बायुः (bāyuḥ, variant of vāyuḥ "wind") + आकाश (ākāśa "space/ether") + एव (eva "indeed, only") + च (ca "and")
- Sandhi: बायुः (bāyuḥ, nominative) + आकाशम् (ākāśam, accusative) + एव (eva) + च (ca)
- Full phrase variants: vāyuḥ/bāyuḥ + ākāśam + eva + ca = "wind, space indeed, and..."
- Note: ब for व variant, complex sandhi with "me" possibly from "m + e"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: wind and space indeed, air and ether also, the vāyu and ākāśa elements verily (variant spelling with sandhi)
- Contextual: enumerates two of the pañca-mahābhūtas (five great elements)—vāyu (air/wind) and ākāśa (space/ether); the emphatic eva (indeed, verily) adds emphasis; ca (and) connects to other elements in a list; appears in philosophical discussions of cosmic elements or tattvas; these two are the subtlest of the five elements; may be listing elements in order of subtlety or discussing their relationship
- Symbolic: represents the subtle dimensions of manifestation; vāyu and ākāśa are the most refined of the five elements, closest to pure consciousness; symbolizes the progression from gross to subtle in spiritual realization

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bāyurākāśamevaca" = bāyuḥ (wind, variant of vāyuḥ with ब for व) + ākāśam (space/ether, accusative) + eva (indeed, emphatic particle) + ca (and, conjunction). Breaking down: **vāyu/bāyu** (वायु/बायु) = air/wind element; **ākāśa** (आकाश) = space/ether element. The pañca-mahābhūta (five great elements) in order of subtlety (gross → subtle): (1) pṛthivī (earth), (2) ap/jala (water), (3) tejas/agni (fire), (4) **vāyu** (air), (5) **ākāśa** (ether/space). Eva (एव) = indeed, verily, only (emphatic). Ca (च) = and, also (enclitic conjunction). Sandhi creates complex combined forms. Mnemonic: vāyu (air, mobile) + ākāśa (space, all-pervading) = the two most subtle elements.
बासुदेब:
# बासुदेब
**Transliteration**: bā-su-de-ba
**POS**: proper noun (masculine) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of वासुदेव (vāsudeva)
- Etymology: वसुदेव (Vasudeva, Krishna's father's name) + -अ patronymic suffix = वासुदेव (vāsudeva) "son of Vasudeva" or "descendant of Vasu"
- Alternative etymology: वसु (vasu) "good, excellent, wealth, light" + देव (deva) "god, divine" dwelling → one in whom all excellence/divinity dwells
- Note: Standard form is वासुदेव (vāsudeva); बासुदेब (bāsudeba) shows ब for व variants

**Meanings**:
- Literal: Vāsudeva, son of Vasudeva, descendant of Vasu; epithet of Lord Kṛṣṇa (variant of vāsudeva)
- Contextual: primary name for Kṛṣṇa in the Bhagavad Gītā and Bhāgavata Purāṇa; Vāsudeva is the eighth avatāra (incarnation) of Viṣṇu; born to Vasudeva and Devakī in Mathurā; destroyer of the demon Kaṁsa; divine teacher who reveals the Gītā to Arjuna on the Kurukṣetra battlefield; Vāsudeva is considered pūrṇa-avatāra (complete incarnation) possessing all sixteen kalās (divine attributes); in Vaiṣṇava theology, Vāsudeva is the supreme Bhagavān (Personal God); object of bhakti (devotion)
- Symbolic: represents Para-Brahman (supreme reality) manifest in personal form; symbolizes divine consciousness descended to guide humanity; embodies the teaching principle (guru-tattva) in its fullest expression; Vāsudeva's life and teachings integrate karma (action), jñāna (knowledge), and bhakti (devotion)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bāsudeba" is variant of "vāsudeva" (वासुदेव) with ब for व. Etymology: **Vasudeva** (वसुदेव, Krishna's father) + patronymic → **Vāsudeva** (वासुदेव) = son of Vasudeva = Kṛṣṇa. Alternative: **vasu** (excellent, wealth, light) + **deva** (god) → one in whom divinity dwells. Vāsudeva = primary name for Kṛṣṇa in Bhagavad Gītā. Other Kṛṣṇa names: Govinda (cowherd), Mādhava (descendant of Madhu), Keśava (long-haired), Hari (one who removes), Janārdana (one who troubles evil), Acyuta (unfallen). Bhagavad Gītā format: Arjuna addresses Kṛṣṇa as Vāsudeva, Keśava, etc. Famous mantra: "Om Namo Bhagavate Vāsudevāya" (Om, salutation to Lord Vāsudeva). Mnemonic: Vāsu-deva = Vasu's descendant = Krishna.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Vāsudeva is Viṣṇu's eighth and most complete avatāra, the pūrṇa-puruṣa (complete person) embodying all divine attributes; he is Para-Brahman (supreme reality) in accessible personal form; in Pāñcarātra and Bhāgavata theology, Vāsudeva is the catur-vyūha (fourfold manifestation): Vāsudeva (supreme), Saṅkarṣaṇa, Pradyumna, Aniruddha; as jagad-guru (world teacher), he restores dharma in Dvāpara-yuga; Gītā identifies him with the supreme: "vāsudevaḥ sarvam" (Vāsudeva is all)
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Vāsudeva-bhakti (devotion to Vāsudeva) is the primary sādhana in Vaiṣṇavism; meditation on his form (rūpa-dhyāna), repetition of his names (nāma-japa), singing his glories (kīrtana), and surrender to him (śaraṇāgati/prapatti) are the path; visualized in the heart (hṛdaya-puṇḍarīka); his dark-blue form represents the infinite sky of consciousness; bhakti-yoga as taught in Gītā is the royal path to Vāsudeva
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Depicted as beautiful dark-blue youth (śyāma-sundara) with peacock feather crown (mora-mukuṭa), yellow silk garment (pītāmbara), holding flute (veṇu/baṁsurī), conch (śaṅkha), disc (cakra), mace (gadā), lotus (padma); often in tribhaṅga (triple-bend) posture; accompanied by Rādhā (his supreme śakti) and gopīs (devotees); his Mathurā/Dvārakā/Vṛndāvana forms slightly differ; as charioteer in Gītā, he drives Arjuna's chariot
- **Mantric Significance**: "Om Namo Bhagavate Vāsudevāya" is the dvādaśākṣara-mantra (twelve-syllable mantra), considered mahā-mantra for Vaiṣṇavas; "Hare Kṛṣṇa Hare Kṛṣṇa Kṛṣṇa Kṛṣṇa Hare Hare, Hare Rāma Hare Rāma Rāma Rāma Hare Hare" is the mahā-mantra for Kali-yuga; Gītā itself is considered a mantra-śāstra; bījas: Klīṁ (कलीं), Hrīṁ (ह्रीं); recitation of Viṣṇu-sahasranāma includes Vāsudeva
- **Dharmic Significance**: Vāsudeva teaches the Bhagavad Gītā, the quintessential dharma-śāstra synthesizing karma-yoga, jñāna-yoga, and bhakti-yoga; his teaching: perform one's dharma (sva-dharma) without attachment to results (niṣkāma-karma), offering all actions to the Divine (sarva-karma-arpaṇa); ultimate teaching: abandon all dharmas and take refuge in him alone ("sarva-dharmān parityajya mām ekaṁ śaraṇaṁ vraja"); Vāsudeva represents the Personal God (saguṇa-brahman) who is simultaneously the impersonal Absolute (nirguṇa-brahman); liberation (mokṣa) is attained through single-pointed devotion to him
- **Symbolic Representation**: Dark-blue/black color symbolizes infinity and all-pervading nature; peacock feather represents beauty and victory over ego (peacock eats snakes/ego); flute represents divine call drawing souls to liberation; yellow garment represents Vedic knowledge; four arms with conch-disc-mace-lotus represent dharma-protection-destruction-of-evil-spiritual-unfoldment; cow (go) represents dharma and sustenance; Garuḍa (eagle mount) represents Vedas and transcendence
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Bhagavad Gītā (Kṛṣṇa as Vāsudeva teaches Arjuna); Bhāgavata Purāṇa/Śrīmad Bhāgavatam (tenth book = Kṛṣṇa's life); Mahābhārata; Viṣṇu Purāṇa; Harivaṁśa; Brahma-Vaivarta Purāṇa; Gopāla-tāpanī Upaniṣad; Kṛṣṇa Upaniṣad; devotional works by Āḻvārs, Nāyanārs, Jayadeva (Gīta-Govinda), Sūrdās, Mīrābāī, Tulsīdās, Caitanya tradition texts
बाहु:
# बाहु
**Transliteration**: bā-hu
**POS**: noun (masculine) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of बाहु (bāhu), though also possibly related to वाहु (vāhu)
- Possibly from √वह् (vah) "to carry, to bear" + उ (u) suffix = बाहु/वाहु (bāhu/vāhu) "arm" (that which carries/bears)
- Or considered a primary noun not derived from verbal root
- Note: Standard form is बाहु (bāhu); the etymology from √vah is folk etymology, likely primary noun

**Meanings**:
- Literal: arm, forearm, upper arm, hand (from shoulder to hand)
- Contextual: in anatomy, bāhu refers specifically to the upper arm or entire arm; in iconography, deities are described by number of arms: dvi-bhuja (two-armed), catur-bhuja (four-armed), aṣṭa-bhuja (eight-armed), etc.; bāhu represents power, protection, and action; strong arms (bala-bāhu) indicate heroism; embracing with arms (bāhu-parigrah) shows affection; crossed arms (bāhu-bandha) show defiance; raised arms (bāhu-udyata) show blessing or weapon-wielding
- Symbolic: represents the capacity for action (karma); divine multiple arms symbolize omnipotence and multi-functionality; bāhu represents the executive power of consciousness; the arms hold the attributes (āyudha) that indicate the deity's powers and functions

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bāhu" (बाहु) = arm, from shoulder to hand. Etymology uncertain, possibly from √वह् (vah, to carry) as the limb that carries/bears, but likely a primary noun. Body parts: bāhu (arm), hasta/pāṇi (hand), aṅguli (finger), skandha/aṃsa (shoulder). Deities classified by arms: **dvi-bhuja** (द्विभुज) = two-armed; **catur-bhuja** (चतुर्भुज) = four-armed (Viṣṇu, Lakṣmī); **aṣṭa-bhuja** (अष्टभुज) = eight-armed (Durgā); **daśa-bhuja** (दशभुज) = ten-armed (Durgā); **sahasra-bhuja** (सहस्रभुज) = thousand-armed (Avalokiteśvara). Epithets: mahā-bāhu (great-armed = mighty), dīrgha-bāhu (long-armed). Mnemonic: "bāhu" sounds like "bow" (arm bends like a bow) → arm = bāhu.
बाह्यार्थः:
# बाह्यार्थः
**Transliteration**: bāh-yār-thaḥ
**POS**: compound noun (tatpuruṣa, masculine nominative singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of बाह्यार्थः (bāhyārthaḥ)
- बाह्य (bāhya) "external, outer" (from बहिस् bahis "outside" + य -ya suffix) + अर्थ (artha) "object, thing, meaning, purpose" (from √अर्थ् arth "to ask for, to desire") = बाह्यार्थ (bāhyārtha) "external object, outer meaning"
- Nominative singular: बाह्यार्थः (bāhyārthaḥ)

**Meanings**:
- Literal: external object, outer object, external meaning, outward sense, externalthe referent
- Contextual: in Indian philosophy (especially Vedānta and Buddhist epistemology), bāhyārtha refers to objects existing outside the mind/consciousness; contrasts with various philosophical positions: (1) realists accept bāhyārtha (external objects exist independently), (2) idealists deny bāhyārtha (only consciousness exists, vijñāna-vāda/yogācāra); in yoga, bāhyārtha are the sense objects (viṣaya) toward which indriyas are naturally directed; in scriptural exegesis, bāhyārtha is the literal/surface meaning vs. gūḍhārtha (hidden meaning)
- Symbolic: represents the phenomenal world of appearance as opposed to the noumenal reality; symbolizes the outer shell vs. inner essence; embodies the distinction between what appears (bāhya) and what truly is (antar/ātman)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bāhyārthaḥ" = bāhya (external, outer) + artha (object, meaning) + ḥ (nominative). Bāhya (बाह्य) from bahis (बहिस्, outside) + -ya suffix = external, outer (opposite: antar अन्तर् = inner, or ābhyantara आभ्यन्तर = internal). Artha (अर्थ) = object, thing, meaning, purpose, wealth. Pattern: X-artha = object/purpose related to X: para-artha (highest purpose), sva-artha (self-interest), puruṣa-artha (human goal). Philosophical positions: **bāhyārtha-vāda** (realism: external objects exist) vs. **vijñapti-mātra-vāda** (idealism: consciousness-only, no external objects). Bāhyārtha vs. antara-artha (inner meaning). Mnemonic: bāhya (outer) + artha (object) → external object/outer meaning.
बाह्यार्थमिति:
# बाह्यार्थमिति
**Transliteration**: bāh-yār-tham-i-ti
**POS**: compound phrase with quotative particle (accusative + iti)

**Root Analysis**:
- बाह्यार्थम् (bāhyārtham) accusative of बाह्यार्थ (bāhyārtha) "external object" + इति (iti) quotative/conclusive particle "thus, so"
- बाह्य (bāhya) "external" (from बहिस् bahis "outside" + य ya suffix) + अर्थ (artha) "object, meaning" = बाह्यार्थ (bāhyārtha) → accusative बाह्यार्थम् (bāhyārtham) + इति (iti)
- Full phrase: बाह्यार्थम् इति (bāhyārtham iti) = "thus (regarding) the external object, so about external objects"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: thus (regarding) the external object, so about external objects, in this manner concerning outer things, such is the external object
- Contextual: iti is a quotative particle marking the end of a statement, thought, or doctrine; "bāhyārtham iti" concludes a discussion about external objects; appears in philosophical texts when defining or concluding arguments about the existence or nature of external objects (bāhyārtha); the accusative case + iti pattern indicates "X is thus" or "this is what is called X"; common in Vedāntic discourse when dismissing or analyzing the status of external phenomena
- Symbolic: represents the conclusive understanding about the nature of external reality; marks the endpoint of philosophical analysis regarding objectivity; embodies the teaching moment when the true nature of externals is revealed

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bāhyārtham iti" = bāhyārtham (external object, accusative) + iti (thus, quotative particle). Iti (इति) is extremely common quotative/conclusive particle marking: (1) end of quotation ("he said thus"), (2) reason ("because of this"), (3) designation ("this is called X"). Pattern: X-m iti = "thus X, this is X, X is thus". Examples: etat iti (thus this), sat iti (thus [called] existence), brahma iti (thus [called] Brahman). Accusative + iti often means "this is what is meant by X" or "X is thus". In philosophical texts: "bāhyārtham iti" might conclude argument like "external objects are thus [illusory/dependent/etc.]". Mnemonic: iti always marks conclusion/quotation = "thus, so, end-quote".
बिकल्पजाल:
# बिकल्पजाल
**Transliteration**: bi-kal-pa-jā-la
**POS**: compound noun (tatpuruṣa, neuter) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विकल्पजाल (vikalpajāla)
- विकल्प (vikalpa) "conceptual thought, mental construction, alternative, option" (from वि vi "apart, variously" + √कॢप् kḷp "to form, to imagine") + जाल (jāla) "net, web, network, mesh" (from √जल् jal "to cover") = विकल्पजाल (vikalpajāla) "net of mental constructions, web of thoughts, network of conceptualizations"
- Note: Standard form is विकल्पजाल; बिकल्पजाल represents व → ब variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: net of mental constructions, web of thoughts, network of conceptualizations, maze of alternatives, entanglement of concepts (variant of vikalpajāla)
- Contextual: in Yoga Vasishtha and Vedāntic texts, vikalpajāla refers to the complex web of conceptual thinking that obscures direct realization; vikalpa are the mental modifications (citta-vṛtti) that create the appearance of multiplicity and division; the jāla (net) metaphor emphasizes how thoughts trap consciousness; liberation requires transcending vikalpa-jāla through nirvikalpa-samādhi (thought-free absorption); vikalpas are the constructs of subject-object duality
- Symbolic: represents the mental prison of conceptual proliferation; symbolizes how consciousness becomes entangled in its own creations; embodies the teaching that the mind weaves a web that obscures pure awareness; the net that must be cut through by viveka (discrimination) and vairāgya (dispassion)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bikalpajāla" is variant of "vikalpajāla" (विकल्पजाल) with ब for व. Compound: vikalpa (mental construction, conceptual thought) + jāla (net, web) = vikalpajāla (net of thoughts). Vikalpa (विकल्प) from वि (vi, apart, variously) + √कॢप् (kḷp, to form, imagine) = conceptual construction, alternative, option. In Yoga Sūtra I.42, savitarkā-samādhi has vikalpa mixed with direct knowledge. Jāla (जाल) = net, web, mesh, network. Pattern: X-jāla = net/web of X: māyā-jāla (net of illusion), moha-jāla (web of delusion), saṁsāra-jāla (net of worldly existence). Freedom from vikalpajāla = nirvikalpa state (thought-free). Mnemonic: vikalpa (varied thoughts) + jāla (net) → net of entangling thoughts.
बिकार:
# बिकार
**Transliteration**: bi-kā-ra
**POS**: noun (masculine) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विकार (vikāra)
- वि (vi) prefix "apart, away, differently, wrongly" + √कृ (kṛ) – "to make, to do" + अ (a) nominal suffix = विकार (vikāra) "modification, change, transformation, alteration, distortion"
- Note: Standard form is विकार (vikāra); बिकार (bikāra) represents व → ब variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: modification, change, transformation, alteration, distortion, perversion, deviation from natural state, defect (variant of vikāra)
- Contextual: in Sāṃkhya philosophy, vikāra refers to the modifications or evolutes of prakṛti—the evolved products as opposed to prakṛti itself (the unevolved); the 23 vikāras from prakṛti are: buddhi, ahaṃkāra, manas, 5 jñānendriyas, 5 karmendriyas, 5 tanmātras; in Yoga, citta-vikāra are mental modifications that disturb pure consciousness; in Vedānta, vikāra refers to apparent transformations of Brahman (though Brahman is actually nirvikāra, without change); in general usage, vikāra means any change, disease, emotional disturbance
- Symbolic: represents the dynamic modifications superimposed on the unchanging substratum; symbolizes the wave-movements on the ocean of pure awareness; embodies the principle that change belongs to prakṛti/māyā while consciousness (puruṣa/ātman) remains changeless (nirvikāra)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bikāra" is variant of "vikāra" (विकार) with ब for व. Root: वि (vi, apart, differently) + √कृ (kṛ, to make) + -a → vikāra = modification, change. Pattern: vi- prefix often indicates change/deviation: vikāra (modification), viparyaya (perversion), viśeṣa (distinction), vibhāga (division). Opposite: avikāra (अविकार, unchanging, without modification). In Sāṃkhya: **prakṛti** (प्रकृति) = unmanifest nature, unevolved vs. **vikāra** (विकार) = evolved modifications, products. 23 vikāras from prakṛti. In Vedānta: Brahman is nirvikāra (निर्विकार, changeless) while world is vikāra (changing). Emotional disturbances = mano-vikāra. Disease = deha-vikāra. Mnemonic: vi (differently) + kāra (making) → making different = modification/change.
बिकीर्ण:
# बिकीर्ण
**Transliteration**: bi-kīr-ṇa
**POS**: past passive participle (can function as adjective) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विकीर्ण (vikīrṇa)
- वि (vi) prefix "apart, asunder" + √कॄ (kṝ/kīr) – "to scatter, to disperse, to spread, to strew" + ण (ṇa) past passive participle suffix = विकीर्ण (vikīrṇa) "scattered, dispersed, spread, strewn"
- Note: Standard form is विकीर्ण (vikīrṇa); बिकीर्ण (bikīrṇa) represents व → ब variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: scattered, dispersed, spread, strewn, thrown about, distributed, disseminated (variant of vikīrṇa)
- Contextual: describes anything scattered or dispersed; in spiritual contexts, refers to dispersed consciousness or attention spread among multiple objects; vikīrṇa-citta (scattered mind) is the untrained state where awareness jumps from object to object; opposite of ekāgra (one-pointed); can describe flowers strewn in worship, knowledge disseminated, or forces scattered; in yogic context, the dispersion that must be gathered through pratyāhāra and dhāraṇā
- Symbolic: represents the fragmented, distracted state of ordinary consciousness; symbolizes the centrifugal tendency of mind to scatter outward; embodies the condition that must be reversed through yogic concentration; the dispersed rays that need to be focused to create fire

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bikīrṇa" is variant of "vikīrṇa" (विकीर्ण) with ब for व. Root: वि (vi, apart) + √कॄ (kṝ/kīr, to scatter) + -ṇa (past participle) → vikīrṇa = scattered, dispersed. Past participle pattern: √kīr → kīrṇa (scattered). Compare: kiraṇa (ray, from √kṝ = that which scatters/spreads = light ray). Related words: vikṣepa (विक्षेप, dispersion, distraction), vikṣipta (विक्षिप्त, scattered, distracted). Opposite: ekāgra (एकाग्र, one-pointed), samāhita (समाहित, collected, concentrated). Usage: vikīrṇa-manas (scattered mind), vikīrṇa-puṣpa (scattered flowers). Mnemonic: vi (apart) + kīrṇa (scattered) → scattered apart = dispersed/fragmented.
बिगतनिद्रो:
# बिगतनिद्रो
**Transliteration**: bi-ga-ta-nid-ro
**POS**: compound adjective (bahuvrīhi, masculine nominative singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विगतनिद्रः (vigata-nidraḥ)
- वि (vi) "away, without" + गत (gata) past participle of √गम् (gam) "to go" = विगत (vigata) "gone away, departed, without" + निद्रा (nidrā) "sleep" (from नि ni "down" + √द्रा drā "to sleep") = विगतनिद्र (vigata-nidra) "one from whom sleep has departed, sleepless"
- Nominative masculine singular: विगतनिद्रः (vigata-nidraḥ) → with sandhi विगतनिद्रो (vigata-nidro) before vowels
- Note: Standard is विगतनिद्रः; बिगतनिद्रो shows ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: sleepless, one from whom sleep has departed, without sleep, awakened, vigilant, watchful (variant of vigata-nidra)
- Contextual: describes one who is fully awake and alert; in spiritual contexts, refers to the yogi who has overcome spiritual drowsiness (āvasthya) and ignorance (avidyā-nidrā); the enlightened one is vigata-nidra, having awakened from the sleep of māyā; can also literally describe someone who cannot sleep or is keeping vigil; the state of constant awareness maintained by the realized sage
- Symbolic: represents awakening from the sleep of ignorance (avidyā-nidrā); symbolizes the enlightened state where consciousness never sleeps, remaining ever-aware (nitya-bodha); embodies the Upaniṣadic teaching: "While all beings sleep, the sage remains awake"; the vigata-nidra is free from the three states (waking, dreaming, deep sleep) and abides in turīya

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bigatanidro" is variant of "vigatanidraḥ" (विगतनिद्रः) with ब for व. Compound: vigata (gone away, without) + nidrā (sleep) → vigata-nidra (without sleep, sleepless). Pattern: vigata-X = "without X, gone from X": vigata-bhaya (fearless), vigata-krodha (without anger), vigata-moha (without delusion). Gata (गत) = gone (past participle of √गम्). Nidrā (निद्रा) = sleep (feminine). Opposite: nidrā-yukta (possessed of sleep), supta (sleeping). Kaṭha Upaniṣad teaching: "Arise! Awake! (uttiṣṭhata jāgrata)" – call to vigata-nidra state. Mnemonic: vi-gata (gone away) + nidrā (sleep) → sleep has gone = awakened/sleepless.
बिचिन्त्य:
# बिचिन्त्य
**Transliteration**: bi-cin-tya
**POS**: gerundive/absolutive — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विचिन्त्य (vicintya)
- वि (vi) "thoroughly, completely" + √चिन्त् (cint) "to think, to consider, to reflect" + त्वा (tvā) absolutive suffix (variant: य -ya gerundive) = विचिन्त्य (vicintya) "having thoroughly considered, after deep reflection"
- Note: Standard is विचिन्त्य; बिचिन्त्य shows ब for व variant
- Can function as gerundive (expressing obligation: "to be thought about") or absolutive (expressing prior action: "having thought about")

**Meanings**:
- Literal: having thoroughly considered, after deep reflection, having thought through, after contemplating, to be reflected upon, requiring consideration
- Contextual: used to indicate the completion of careful intellectual analysis before taking action or reaching a conclusion; in Yoga Vasishtha philosophical dialogues, vicintya marks the moment when Vasiṣṭha or Rāma has completed deliberation and is ready to speak or act; signifies mature understanding arrived at through prolonged meditation (dhyāna) and discernment (viveka); often precedes important teaching moments where wisdom is to be imparted; the sage speaks only vicintya (after thorough consideration), not rashly
- Symbolic: represents the discriminative wisdom (viveka-jñāna) that arises from careful analysis of reality; symbolizes the contemplative pause before right action (karma-yoga); embodies the teaching that wisdom requires reflection, not mere intellectual grasping; the vicintya state is where buddhi (intellect) has fully examined and understood before consciousness acts

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bicintya" is variant of "vicintya" (विचिन्त्य) with ब for व. Root: √चिन्त् (cint) = to think/consider. Vi- prefix intensifies: "thoroughly thought." Absolutive form shows completed action: "having thought" (like kṛtvā = having done, gatvā = having gone). Common pattern: vi + √verb + -tya/-ya = "having thoroughly verbed": vitarkya (having reasoned), vimṛśya (having examined), vijñāya (having discerned). Gerundive reading: "to be considered." Mnemonic: vi-cint-ya → "by thorough thinking" → after deep reflection. Often precedes statements: "vicintya uvāca" = "having reflected, he spoke."
बिजरो:
# बिजरो
**Transliteration**: bi-ja-ro
**POS**: adjective (masculine nominative singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विजरः (vijaraḥ)
- वि (vi) "without, free from" + जरा (jarā) "old age, decay, deterioration" (from √जॄ jṝ "to grow old, to decay") = विजर (vijara) "without old age, ageless, imperishable"
- Nominative masculine singular: विजरः (vijaraḥ) → with sandhi विजरो (vijaro) before vowels
- Note: Standard is विजरः; बिजरो shows ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: ageless, without old age, undecaying, imperishable, free from deterioration, unaging, exempt from decay, youthful, ever-fresh
- Contextual: describes the immortal Self (Ātman) which does not age or decay despite the body's aging; refers to Brahman which is eternal and beyond time's effects; in Yoga Vasishtha, the vijara nature of consciousness (cit) is contrasted with the decaying body (śarīra); the realized sage sees the vijara Self within the aging body; consciousness itself is vijara—it does not age even as the body grows old; liberation (mokṣa) is recognizing one's vijara nature
- Symbolic: represents the timeless essence beyond biological aging; symbolizes eternal consciousness untouched by temporal change; embodies the Vedantic teaching that the true Self is immortal (amṛta) and ageless (vijara); freedom from jarā (old age) indicates transcendence of time itself; the vijara principle is the changeless witness (sākṣin) observing the aging process without being affected

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bijaro" is variant of "vijaraḥ" (विजरः) with ब for व. Compound: vi (without) + jarā (old age) → vijara (ageless). Root: √जॄ (jṝ) = to grow old, to decay. Pattern: vi-X = "without X": vi-roga (without disease), vi-kleśa (without affliction), vi-kāra (without modification). Jarā (जरा) = old age, decay (feminine noun). Opposite: jarā-yukta (subject to old age), jarā-grasta (seized by old age). Often paired with amara (immortal): amaro vijaro vā = "immortal and ageless." Bhagavad Gītā II.20 describes Ātman as ajo nityaḥ śāśvato 'yaṁ purāṇo na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre—unborn, eternal, ancient, not slain when body is slain (implies vijara). Mnemonic: vi (without) + jarā (old age) → ageless Self.
बिज्ञात:
# बिज्ञात
**Transliteration**: bi-jñā-ta
**POS**: past participle — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विज्ञात (vijñāta)
- वि (vi) "distinctly, specially" + √ज्ञा (jñā) "to know, to understand, to recognize" + त (ta) past participle suffix = विज्ञात (vijñāta) "known, understood, recognized, discerned"
- Note: Standard is विज्ञात; बिज्ञात shows ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: known, understood, recognized, perceived, discerned, comprehended, ascertained, realized, made known
- Contextual: in Vedantic texts, vijñāta refers to direct experiential knowledge (aparokṣa-jñāna) rather than mere intellectual understanding; that which has been vijñāta is that which has been directly realized through meditation and Self-inquiry; Brahman when vijñāta becomes one's living reality, not just theoretical knowledge; the vijñāta-tattva is the principle that has been fully comprehended; in Yoga Vasishtha, the Self is described as vijñāta when it has been directly experienced (sākṣātkṛta), not merely heard about from scriptures
- Symbolic: represents the transition from śravaṇa (hearing) and manana (reflection) to nididhyāsana (direct realization); symbolizes experiential wisdom (anubhava-jñāna) as opposed to book knowledge (śāstra-jñāna); embodies the difference between knowing about fire and being burned by it; the vijñāta state is where knowledge becomes being (jñāna becomes svarūpa)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bijñāta" is variant of "vijñāta" (विज्ञात) with ब for व. Root: √ज्ञा (jñā) = to know. Vi- prefix adds "distinctly, specially": vijñāna = special knowledge, science, discernment. Past participle -ta shows completed action: "has been known." Related: jñāta (merely known), vijñāta (distinctly known/realized), prajñāta (fully known), parijñāta (completely known around all sides). Pattern: vi + √jñā + -ta = vijñāta (known/realized). Vijñāna (विज्ञान) = discernment, special knowledge, science. Mnemonic: vi (special) + jñā (know) + -ta (done) → specially known = distinctly understood/realized. Often in phrase: vijñāta-tattva = "the principle that has been realized."
बिज्ञानमय:
# बिज्ञानमय
**Transliteration**: bi-jñā-na-ma-ya
**POS**: adjective (masculine nominative singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विज्ञानमय (vijñānamaya)
- विज्ञान (vijñāna) "discernment, higher knowledge, discriminative wisdom" (from वि vi "distinctly" + √ज्ञा jñā "to know") + मय (maya) suffix "consisting of, made of, full of" (from √मा mā "to measure, to form") = विज्ञानमय (vijñānamaya) "consisting of discernment, made of higher knowledge"
- Note: Standard is विज्ञानमय; बिज्ञानमय shows ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: consisting of discernment, made of higher knowledge, composed of discriminative wisdom, full of special understanding, constituted by vijñāna
- Contextual: refers to the vijñānamaya-kośa (wisdom sheath), the fourth of the five sheaths (pañca-kośa) covering the Ātman in Vedantic psychology; this sheath is the seat of buddhi (intellect), viveka (discrimination), and higher reasoning; it is subtler than the mind sheath (manomaya-kośa) and represents the faculty of discernment that can distinguish real from unreal (sat-asat-viveka); in meditation, the sādhaka must transcend even the vijñānamaya-kośa to reach ānandamaya-kośa and ultimately pure Ātman; Yoga Vasishtha teaches that while vijñāna is closer to truth than ordinary thinking, it is still a covering (kośa) that must be penetrated
- Symbolic: represents the intellectual-intuitive faculty that bridges lower mind and pure consciousness; symbolizes discriminative wisdom (viveka-jñāna) as the instrument for Self-realization; embodies the transition from mental activity to direct knowing; the vijñānamaya level is where philosophical understanding resides, but it must be transcended for final liberation

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bijñānamaya" is variant of "vijñānamaya" (विज्ञानमय) with ब for व. Vijñāna (विज्ञान) = discernment, higher knowledge, science. Maya suffix (मय) = "made of, consisting of" (like annamaya = made of food, prāṇamaya = made of life force). This is the fourth kośa: annamaya (food) → prāṇamaya (vital energy) → manomaya (mind) → vijñānamaya (wisdom) → ānandamaya (bliss). Vijñānamaya is the sheath of buddhi (intellect) and viveka (discrimination). Mnemonic: vijñāna (special knowledge) + maya (made of) → wisdom sheath. Taittirīya Upaniṣad describes all five kośas systematically, showing vijñānamaya as subtler than mano but grosser than ānanda.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Vijñānamaya-kośa is the fourth of five nested sheaths (kośa) encasing the Ātman; it corresponds to the buddhitattva (intellect principle) in Sāṃkhya philosophy and is the seat of discriminative wisdom; this sheath enables the individual (jīva) to distinguish between Self and not-Self; it is the locus of spiritual decision-making and philosophical insight; vijñānamaya bridges the empirical mind (manas) and pure consciousness (cit); in cosmic manifestation, it represents the causal/intellectual layer of existence
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Associated with ājñā-cakra (third eye center), the seat of intuitive wisdom and command; cultivation of vijñānamaya occurs through viveka-khyāti (discriminative discernment) and śravaṇa-manana-nididhyāsana (hearing-reflection-meditation) practice; advanced yogis refine vijñānamaya to achieve prajñā (wisdom), then transcend it entirely; meditation pierces through vijñānamaya when the meditator realizes even wisdom-formations are objects, not the subject; the vijñānamaya level is where one practices ātma-anātma-viveka (Self/not-Self discrimination)
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Vijñānamaya is governed by buddhi-śakti (power of intellect) and presided over by deities of wisdom such as Sarasvatī (goddess of learning) and Gaṇeśa (remover of obstacles to knowledge); Dākṣiṇāmūrti (south-facing Śiva as supreme teacher) embodies perfected vijñānamaya
- **Dharmic Significance**: Central to the Vedantic path of jñāna-yoga (yoga of knowledge); vijñānamaya-kośa is where viveka (discrimination between eternal and non-eternal) operates; this sheath must be cultivated to mature spiritual understanding, but ultimately transcended—even vijñāna is a kośa (covering) hiding pure Ātman; liberation requires going beyond vijñānamaya to recognize oneself as the witnessing consciousness (sākṣin) observing even wisdom-thoughts
- **Symbolic Representation**: Depicted as a luminous sphere or sheath of radiant light surrounding the inner sheaths; often symbolized by the rising sun or clear mirror reflecting truth; in iconography, represented by the third eye (ājñā) or crown region; the clarity and brilliance of vijñānamaya contrasts with the turbulence of manomaya
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Taittirīya Upaniṣad (II.3-5) systematically describes the pañca-kośa model including vijñānamaya-kośa; extensively discussed in Vedānta-sāra, Pañcadaśī, and Vivekacūḍāmaṇi; foundational to Advaita Vedanta's method of negation (neti-neti) applied to the kośas
बिदुः:
# बिदुः
**Transliteration**: bi-duḥ
**POS**: verb (3rd person plural, perfect tense) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विदुः (viduḥ)
- √विद् (vid) "to know, to understand, to perceive" + उः (uḥ) 3rd person plural perfect ending = विदुः (viduḥ) "they know, they have known, they understand"
- Perfect tense indicates completed or established action with continuing relevance: "they (now) know" (having learned/realized)
- Note: Standard is विदुः; बिदुः shows ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: they know, they have known, they understand, they are aware, they have learned, they perceive, they recognize
- Contextual: frequently used in Vedic and classical Sanskrit to indicate those who possess established knowledge; "viduḥ" often refers to the wise ones, the knowers of truth (tattva-vit), those who have realized Brahman; in Upaniṣads and Yoga Vasishtha, viduḥ designates the enlightened sages who have direct knowledge (aparokṣa-jñāna); contrasted with "na viduḥ" (they do not know)—the ignorant who lack Self-knowledge; often in phrases like "brahmavido viduḥ" (the knowers of Brahman know), "ye viduḥ" (those who know), "tad viduḥ" (they know that)
- Symbolic: represents established wisdom and direct realization; symbolizes the community of the enlightened (jñānin); embodies the completion of spiritual learning where knowledge is no longer theoretical but lived reality

**Learning Tip**:
- "Biduḥ" is variant of "viduḥ" (विदुः) with ब for व. Root: √विद् (vid) = to know (one of most important roots—appears in veda, vidyā, vedānta). Perfect tense 3rd person plural: vid + uḥ = viduḥ (they know). Related forms: veda (he/she knows—perfect used as present), vidma (we know), vittha (you know), vidur (they know—alternate form). Pattern: viduḥ indicates established/realized knowledge, not mere hearing. Common in scriptural phrases: "tat tvam asi iti viduḥ" = "they know 'That thou art'." Mnemonic: vid (know) + uḥ (they, perfect) → they [definitely] know. Contrast: jānanti (they know, present tense, ordinary knowing) vs. viduḥ (they know, perfect tense, realized knowing).
बिदुषां:
# बिदुषां
**Transliteration**: bi-du-ṣāṁ
**POS**: noun (masculine genitive plural) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विदुषाम् (viduṣām)
- √विद् (vid) "to know" + वस् (vas) masculine agent noun suffix forming विद्वस् (vidvas) "knower, wise one, learned person" → genitive plural विदुषाम् (viduṣām) "of the wise ones, of the learned, of the knowers"
- Perfect active participle विद्वस् (vidvas) declines irregularly; stem form विदुष् (viduṣ-) appears in oblique cases
- Note: Standard is विदुषाम्; बिदुषां shows ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: of the wise ones, of the learned, of the knowers, of the scholars, of the sages, belonging to the wise, among the learned
- Contextual: refers to the community or tradition of enlightened sages (jñānin); "viduṣām" indicates possession, association, or characteristic of those who have Self-knowledge; used in phrases describing the qualities, teachings, or domain of the wise; in Upaniṣadic and Vedantic texts, viduṣām designates the realized masters whose understanding is authoritative; contrasted with ordinary people (loka) or the ignorant (ajñānin); often in expressions like "viduṣām mate" (in the opinion of the wise), "viduṣām dharmāḥ" (the duties of the learned)
- Symbolic: represents the wisdom lineage and tradition of enlightened teachers; symbolizes the collective understanding of Self-realized beings; embodies the consensus of those who have transcended intellectual knowledge for direct realization

**Learning Tip**:
- "Biduṣāṁ" is variant of "viduṣām" (विदुषाम्) with ब for व. Root: √विद् (vid) = to know. Agent noun: vid-vas (vidvān/vidvas) = knower, wise person. Irregular declension: nominative vidvān, genitive plural viduṣām (stem viduṣ- in oblique cases). Genitive case shows possession/relationship: "of the wise ones." Pattern: vidvān (wise one, singular) → viduṣām (of wise ones, plural genitive). Related: paṇḍita (learned scholar), jñānin (knower), tattva-vit (knower of reality). Mnemonic: vid (know) + vas (agent) + -ām (genitive plural) → of the knowers. Common phrase: "viduṣāṁ mate" = according to the wise, in the view of sages.
बिद्:
# बिद्
**Transliteration**: bid
**POS**: verbal root (dhātu) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of √विद् (vid)
- √विद् (vid) "to know, to understand, to perceive, to find, to learn, to experience" — fundamental verbal root belonging to Vedic class II (ad-ādi) and class VI (tud-ādi)
- Note: Standard is √विद्; बिद् shows ब for व variant
- Not derived from a smaller root; this IS the fundamental root from which many knowledge-related words derive

**Meanings**:
- Literal: to know, to understand, to perceive, to realize, to find, to learn, to discover, to experience, to ascertain, to be aware
- Contextual: in Vedic and classical Sanskrit, √vid represents not just intellectual knowledge but experiential realization and direct perception; the perfect tense of √vid (veda, "he/she knows") is used as a present tense, indicating that true knowledge is timeless and established; in Yoga Vasishtha and Upaniṣads, vid refers to direct Self-knowledge (ātma-jñāna), not mere conceptual understanding; the enlightened sage is one who has "known" (veda) Brahman directly; vid is the root of veda (knowledge, scripture), vidyā (knowledge, learning), vijñāna (discernment), vedānta (end of knowledge), vidvān (wise one)
- Symbolic: represents the fundamental cognitive faculty of consciousness; symbolizes the self-illuminating nature of awareness (svaprakāśa-cit); embodies the principle that consciousness knows itself directly without mediation; vid is the activity of cit (pure consciousness) recognizing its own nature

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bid" is variant of "√vid" (√विद्) with ब for व. One of the most fundamental Sanskrit roots! Derivatives: veda (knowledge/Veda), vidyā (knowledge/learning), vidvān (wise one), vijñāna (discernment/science), vedānta (Vedanta/end of knowledge), vetti (knows, present tense), veda (knows, perfect as present), viduḥ (they know), jñā + vid compounds. Two conjugation classes: class II (vetti, vidmaḥ) and class VI. Perfect tense used as present: veda = "I know" (established knowledge). Mnemonic: vid → veda → vidyā → all knowledge terms. English cognates: "wit," "wisdom," "video" (Latin "to see" = to know). This root appears in countless philosophical terms—master it!

**Metaphysics**:
