**Learning Tip**:
- "Birāṭ" is variant of "virāṭ" (विराट्) with ब for व. Etymology: vi (widely) + √rāj (to shine/rule). Meaning: "shining everywhere" = cosmic form, universal body. In Vedantic four-state model: (1) Virāṭ (cosmic) / Viśva (individual) = waking, (2) Hiraṇyagarbha (cosmic) / Taijasa (individual) = dreaming, (3) Īśvara (cosmic) / Prājña (individual) = deep sleep, (4) Brahman / Turīya = transcendent. Virāṭ is the totality of physical universe as divine body. Bhagavad Gītā XI: Kṛṣṇa's virāṭa-rūpa (cosmic form) shown to Arjuna. Mnemonic: vi (everywhere) + rāj (shine) → cosmic shining = universal form. Virāṭ-Puruṣa = Cosmic Person containing all beings.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Virāṭ is the cosmic manifestation of Brahman, the totality of the physical universe viewed as a single organism; in Vedantic cosmology, Virāṭ is the

 first gross manifestation, corresponding to sthūla-śarīra (gross body) at the cosmic level; the entire visible universe with all its galaxies, worlds, and beings is the body of Virāṭ; Virāṭ is associated with the waking state (jāgrat-avasthā) and with Viśva (individual waking consciousness); corresponds to the first quarter of OM in Māṇḍūkya teaching; Virāṭ is the macrocosmic counterpart to the human body
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Meditation on Virāṭ involves visualizing the entire cosmos as the divine body; Virāṭ-upāsanā (worship/contemplation of the cosmic form) expands awareness from individual to universal; helps dissolve egoic identification by seeing oneself as part of cosmic whole; preparatory practice for higher non-dual realization; some yoga systems associate different parts of Virāṭ's body with different realms and deities
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Virāṭ is personified as Virāṭ-Puruṣa (Cosmic Person) in Ṛg Veda's Puruṣa-sūkta; identified with Nārāyaṇa, Viṣṇu, or Brahmā in different traditions; the virāṭa-rūpa of Kṛṣṇa in Bhagavad Gītā XI is the most famous depiction—Arjuna sees all worlds, beings, gods, and time itself within Kṛṣṇa's cosmic form; Virāṭ contains all deities as parts of one universal divinity
- **Dharmic Significance**: Virāṭ represents Brahman's immanent aspect—divinity not as transcendent otherness but as the very fabric of manifest reality; realization of Virāṭ overcomes the illusion that the world is separate from or opposed to spirit; "seeing God in everything" is seeing Virāṭ; leads to cosmic consciousness where individual awareness expands to encompass the whole; intermediate stage between dualistic devotion and absolute non-dual realization
- **Symbolic Representation**: Depicted as the Cosmic Person (Puruṣa) whose body constitutes the universe; in iconography of Bhagavad Gītā XI, shown with countless faces, eyes, arms, containing all beings, gods, worlds, and time; Puruṣa-sūkta describes cosmic sacrifice where Virāṭ's body parts become different parts of creation; represented as the macrocosm in diagrams showing correspondence between cosmos and human body
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Ṛg Veda Puruṣa-sūkta (X.90) describes Virāṭ-Puruṣa; Māṇḍūkya Upaniṣad presents Virāṭ as cosmic waking state; Bhagavad Gītā chapter XI (Viśvarūpa-darśana-yoga) shows Kṛṣṇa's virāṭa-rūpa; Praśna Upaniṣad discusses Virāṭ; Vedānta-sāra systematizes Virāṭ in cosmic-individual correspondence schema
बिश्बम्भर:
# बिश्बम्भर
**Transliteration**: biś-vam-bha-ra
**POS**: adjective/noun (masculine) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विश्वम्भर (viśvambhara)
- विश्व (viśva) "universe, all, everything" + √भृ (bhṛ) "to bear, to support, to sustain" + अ (a) agent noun suffix = विश्वम्भर (viśvam-bhara) "universe-bearer, sustainer of all, supporter of the world"
- Tatpuruṣa compound: viśvam (accusative "the universe") + bhara (bearer)
- Note: Standard is विश्वम्भर; बिश्बम्भर shows ब for व and ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: universe-bearer, sustainer of all, supporter of the world, one who upholds everything, cosmic sustainer
- Contextual: an epithet for the supreme deity (Īśvara, Viṣṇu, Śiva, or Brahman) who sustains and supports the entire manifest universe; describes the sustaining function (sthiti) of divinity as opposed to creation (sṛṣṭi) and dissolution (laya); in Yoga Vasishtha and Vedantic texts, refers to the consciousness that is the substratum (adhiṣṭhāna) of all manifestation; the universe "rests in" or is "borne by" the infinite consciousness; Viśvambhara holds all worlds and beings in existence through divine power
- Symbolic: represents the sustaining power of consciousness that maintains cosmic order; symbolizes the divine as the foundation and support of all existence; embodies the teaching that all phenomena depend on and are sustained by the infinite

**Learning Tip**:
- "Biśvambhara" is variant of "viśvambhara" (विश्वम्भर) with ब for व (twice). Compound: viśva (universe, all) + √bhṛ (to bear/support). Agent noun bhara (भर) = bearer, supporter (from √bhṛ). Pattern: X-bhara = "X-bearer": bhūmi-bhara (earth-bearer = mountain), āśā-bhara (hope-bearer). Viśva (विश्व) = all, universe, entire. √भृ (bhṛ) gives: bharaṇa (supporting), bibharti (bears), dhāraṇa (holding). Mnemonic: viśva (universe) + bhara (bearer) → cosmic sustainer. Epithet of Viṣṇu as preserver, or any deity as cosmic support. Related: viśva-dhāra (universe-holder), jagad-dhātr (world-supporter). Consciousness is viśvambhara—it bears/sustains all appearances.
बिश्रामः:
# बिश्रामः
**Transliteration**: bi-śrā-maḥ
**POS**: noun (masculine nominative singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विश्रामः (viśrāmaḥ)
- वि (vi) "complete, thorough" + √श्रम् (śram) "to be tired, to toil, to exert" + घञ् (ghañ) nominal suffix = विश्राम (viśrāma) "complete rest, cessation from toil, repose, relaxation"
- Note: Standard is विश्रामः; बिश्रामः shows ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: rest, repose, relaxation, cessation from labor, relief from exertion, pause, respite, tranquility
- Contextual: in Yoga Vasishtha and spiritual texts, viśrāma refers not merely to physical rest but to the profound repose of consciousness resting in its own nature; the peace that comes when mental activity (vṛtti) ceases and awareness abides in itself; viśrāma is the state of the mind when it stops running after objects and "rests" in pure being; contrasted with śrama (toil, effort, striving) of worldly pursuits and even spiritual practices—viśrāma is effortless being; the goal of meditation is viśrāma—the mind's complete rest in the Self
- Symbolic: represents the peace beyond all activity and becoming; symbolizes consciousness at rest in itself, not engaged with objects; embodies the teaching that true rest is not sleep or inactivity but the Self's natural state (sahaja-avasthā) of effortless awareness

**Learning Tip**:
- "Biśrāmaḥ" is variant of "viśrāmaḥ" (विश्रामः) with ब for व. Root: वि (vi, thoroughly) + √श्रम् (śram, to toil/be tired). Viśrāma = "complete rest, cessation from toil." Opposite: śrama (श्रम) = toil, effort, labor, fatigue. Related: viśrānti (repose, cessation), ā-śrama (hermitage, stage of life literally "without toil"), pari-śrama (exertion). Pattern: vi-√śram = thorough rest. In spiritual context: viśrāma = the mind resting in Self, cessation of mental activity (vṛtti-nirodha). Bhagavad Gītā: yogastha kuru karmāṇi—act from yoga (inner rest), not agitation. Mnemonic: vi (complete) + śrāma (from śram, toil) → complete rest/repose. True viśrāma is consciousness resting in itself, not merely physical relaxation.
बिश्वरूप:
# बिश्वरूप
**Transliteration**: biś-va-rū-pa
**POS**: adjective/noun (masculine/neuter) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विश्वरूप (viśvarūpa)
- विश्व (viśva) "universe, all, entire" + रूप (rūpa) "form, appearance, shape" = विश्वरूप (viśva-rūpa) "having the form of the universe, universal form, cosmic appearance, all-formed"
- Bahuvrīhi compound: "one whose form (rūpa) is the universe (viśva)" or Karmadhāraya: "form which is the universe"
- Note: Standard is विश्वरूप; बिश्वरूप shows ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: universal form, cosmic form, all-formed, having the appearance of the entire universe, multiform, omniform
- Contextual: most famously refers to the viśvarūpa-darśana (vision of the universal form) revealed by Kṛṣṇa to Arjuna in Bhagavad Gītā chapter XI; describes the deity's cosmic manifestation where the entire universe with all beings, worlds, gods, and time itself is revealed as the divine body; in Vedantic thought, viśvarūpa is the recognition that the supreme consciousness manifests as the totality of existence; seeing viśvarūpa means perceiving that all forms are forms of the One; also refers to Viśvarūpa as a name/epithet of Viṣṇu, Śiva, or the supreme deity
- Symbolic: represents the immanent aspect of divinity—God not as separate creator but as the very fabric of manifest reality; symbolizes the non-dual teaching that there is nothing outside of or other than Brahman; embodies the vision that overcomes duality by seeing all multiplicity as expressions of one divine being

**Learning Tip**:
- "Biśvarūpa" is variant of "viśvarūpa" (विश्वरूप) with ब for व. Compound: viśva (universe, all) + rūpa (form). Meaning: "universal form, all-formed, whose form is the universe." Most famous from Bhagavad Gītā XI where Kṛṣṇa reveals viśvarūpa-darśana (vision of cosmic form) to Arjuna. Pattern: X-rūpa = "having form of X": nara-rūpa (human form), deva-rūpa (divine form). Viśva (विश्व) = all, entire, universe. Rūpa (रूप) = form, shape, appearance. Mnemonic: viśva (all/universe) + rūpa (form) → form that is the universe = cosmic/universal form. Synonyms: virāṭ-rūpa (cosmic form), viśvamūrti (universal embodiment). Vision of viśvarūpa reveals unity underlying all multiplicity.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Viśvarūpa is the manifestation of supreme consciousness as the totality of the cosmos; it is Brahman's visible, immanent aspect where the formless takes infinite forms simultaneously; represents the teaching that the universe is not separate from divinity but is divine embodiment; in Vedantic cosmology, viśvarūpa corresponds to Īśvara's creative expression—the One appearing as Many while remaining One; the vision of viśvarūpa dissolves the illusion of separation between God and world
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Viśvarūpa-darśana is a yogic vision granted by divine grace (prasāda) to qualified devotees; Arjuna required divya-cakṣus (divine eye) to perceive it, showing it transcends ordinary perception; meditation on viśvarūpa expands consciousness from individual to cosmic awareness; practice involves seeing divinity in all forms and beings (sarva-bhūta-darśana); leads to dissolution of ego-boundaries and recognition of universal Self; preparatory to formless non-dual realization
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Viśvarūpa is primarily associated with Kṛṣṇa's revelation in Bhagavad Gītā XI, but also appears as epithet of Viṣṇu, Śiva, Devī, and Brahman; described as having countless faces, eyes, mouths, arms, ornaments; contains all beings, gods, sages, demons, worlds, elements, and time within one cosmic body; simultaneously beautiful and terrifying—shows both creative and destructive aspects; beyond all limited deity-forms while encompassing them all
- **Dharmic Significance**: Vision of viśvarūpa represents transition from bhakti (devotional dualism) toward jñāna (non-dual knowledge); Arjuna sees that Kṛṣṇa—his friend and charioteer—is identical with the entire universe and its source; overcomes the illusion (māyā) that divinity is separate from creation; teaches that supreme reality is both transcendent (para) and immanent (viśvarūpa); realization of viśvarūpa is seeing "all this is Brahman" (sarvam khalv idam brahma); intermediate vision before absolute formless realization
- **Symbolic Representation**: In Bhagavad Gītā iconography, depicted as overwhelming cosmic vision with infinite forms; shown with multiple heads, arms, eyes radiating in all directions; contains galaxies, suns, moons, fire, oceans, mountains, all beings; time (kāla) with open mouth devouring all; often painted with radiant, sometimes frightening aspects; impossible to capture fully in art—artistic depictions only hint at infinite totality; represents the coincidentia oppositorum (unity of opposites)
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Bhagavad Gītā chapter XI (Viśvarūpa-darśana-yoga) is the primary textual source; also described in Śrīmad Bhāgavata Purāṇa (Kṛṣṇa shows viśvarūpa to Yaśodā and others); Viṣṇu Purāṇa and other Purāṇas elaborate on viśvarūpa; Devī-bhāgavata describes goddess's viśvarūpa; philosophical commentaries by Śaṅkara, Rāmānuja, Madhva interpret the Gītā vision
बिश्वाः:
# बिश्वाः
**Transliteration**: biś-vāḥ
**POS**: adjective (masculine nominative plural) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विश्वाः (viśvāḥ)
- विश्व (viśva) "all, entire, universal" → nominative plural masculine विश्वाः (viśvāḥ) "all (ones), all beings, the universal ones"
- विश्व from वि (vi) "apart, all around" + √श्वि (śvi) "to swell, to expand" = "all-pervading, entire, universal"
- Note: Standard is विश्वाः; बिश्वाः shows ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: all, all beings, all ones, the universal ones, everyone, everything (as plural subjects)
- Contextual: nominative plural form used to refer to all beings, creatures, or entities collectively; "viśvāḥ" as subject indicates "all (beings) do/are X"; commonly appears in Vedic and classical texts referring to the totality of conscious beings, gods, or entities; used in universal statements about the nature of reality affecting all beings; distinguished from singular viśvam (the universe as whole) vs. plural viśvāḥ (all individual beings within it)
- Symbolic: represents the multiplicity of beings all of whom share the same divine essence; symbolizes the many appearing from the One; embodies the teaching that all beings (viśvāḥ) are ultimately expressions of one consciousness

**Learning Tip**:
- "Biśvāḥ" is variant of "viśvāḥ" (विश्वाः) with ब for व. Base: viśva (विश्व) = all, entire, universal. Nominative plural masculine: viśva → viśvāḥ. Used as plural subject: "all beings (do/are X)." Declension: nom. pl. viśvāḥ, acc. pl. viśvān, inst. pl. viśvaiḥ. Pattern: singular viśvam (the universe as totality) vs. plural viśvāḥ (all beings individually). Related: viśva-deva (all-gods, collective deities), sarva (all, every). Mnemonic: viśva (all/universal) + plural -āḥ → all beings, everyone, everything. Common in Vedic hymns addressing or describing all beings collectively.
बिषयं:
# बिषयं
**Transliteration**: bi-ṣa-yaṁ
**POS**: noun (masculine accusative singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विषयम् (viṣayam)
- वि (vi) "toward, into" + √सि (si) "to bind" + अय (aya) suffix = विषय (viṣaya) "object, domain, sphere, sense-object" → accusative विषयम् (viṣayam) "the object" (as direct object)
- Note: Standard is विषयम्; बिषयं shows ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: object, sense-object, subject matter, domain, sphere, field, topic, realm, province
- Contextual: in Yoga and Vedantic psychology, viṣaya refers to the objects of the senses and mind—everything that consciousness can be directed toward; the five sense-objects (pañca-viṣaya): sound, touch, form, taste, smell corresponding to the five senses; also includes mental objects like thoughts, emotions, memories; in Yoga Sūtra, withdrawal from viṣayas (pratyāhāra) is the fifth limb; attachment to viṣayas (viṣaya-āsakti) is the cause of bondage; in Yoga Vasishtha, viṣayas are contrasted with the viṣayin (subject, experiencer)—realization comes when the distinction collapses
- Symbolic: represents the external world as it appears to consciousness; symbolizes that which draws awareness outward and creates attachment; embodies the objects of desire (kāma) that perpetuate saṃsāra

**Learning Tip**:
- "Biṣayam" is variant of "viṣayam" (विषयम्) with ब for व. Base: viṣaya (विषय) = object, sense-object, domain. Accusative singular: viṣaya → viṣayam (as direct object). Root: वि (vi, toward) + √सि (si, to bind). Pattern: consciousness directed "toward" (vi) objects where it gets "bound" (si). Five sense-objects (pañca-viṣaya): śabda (sound), sparśa (touch), rūpa (form), rasa (taste), gandha (smell). Opposite: viṣayin (विषयिन्) = subject, experiencer. Related: indriya (sense organ), artha (object). Yoga Sūtra II.54: pratyāhāra = withdrawal of senses from viṣayas. Mnemonic: vi-ṣaya → "toward-binding" → object that binds consciousness. Central concept in yoga psychology.
बिष्णोरानन्दं:
# बिष्णोरानन्दं
**Transliteration**: biṣ-ṇor-ā-nan-daṁ
**POS**: compound phrase (masculine accusative singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a compound phrase with variant spelling:
- विष्णोः (viṣṇoḥ) genitive singular "of Viṣṇu" + आनन्दम् (ānandam) accusative singular "bliss, joy" = विष्णोरानन्दम् (viṣṇor-ānandam) "the bliss of Viṣṇu, Viṣṇu's joy"
- Sandhi: viṣṇoḥ + ānandam → viṣṇor ānandam (visarga ḥ → r before vowel)
- Tatpuruṣa (genitive) compound: ānandam (bliss) belonging to viṣṇoḥ (Viṣṇu)
- Variant: बिष्णोरानन्दं shows ब for व
- आनन्द (ānanda) from आ (ā) intensifying prefix + √नन्द् (nand) "to rejoice" = "great joy, bliss"

**Meanings**:
- Literal: the bliss of Viṣṇu, Viṣṇu's joy, the joy that is Viṣṇu, divine bliss
- Contextual: refers to the blissful nature of Viṣṇu as supreme reality; in Vaiṣṇava theology, Viṣṇu (or Nārāyaṇa, Kṛṣṇa) is characterized by supreme ānanda (bliss); this ānanda is not pleasure derived from objects but the intrinsic bliss of pure being; in Vedantic teaching, Brahman is sat-cit-ānanda (existence-consciousness-bliss), and Viṣṇu as Brahman embodies this ānanda; devotees seek to experience viṣṇor-ānanda through bhakti; the ānanda of Viṣṇu is also the bliss that pervades and sustains creation
- Symbolic: represents the blissful aspect of ultimate reality; symbolizes that divine nature is inherently joyful, not neutral or sorrowful; embodies the teaching that true bliss is found in the infinite, not in finite objects

**Learning Tip**:
- "Biṣṇor-ānandam" is variant of "viṣṇor-ānandam" (विष्णोरानन्दम्) with ब for व. Compound: viṣṇoḥ (genitive of viṣṇu, "of Viṣṇu") + ānanda (bliss). Sandhi: viṣṇoḥ + ānanda → viṣṇor ānanda (ḥ → r before a). Viṣṇu (विष्णु) = the Pervader, supreme deity. Ānanda (आनन्द) = bliss, joy (from ā + √nand, to rejoice). Pattern: X-ānanda = "bliss of X": brahma-ānanda (bliss of Brahman), ātma-ānanda (bliss of Self). Sat-cit-ānanda (सच्चिदानन्द) = existence-consciousness-bliss (three aspects of Brahman). Mnemonic: viṣṇoḥ (of Viṣṇu) + ānanda (bliss) → divine bliss, Viṣṇu's inherent joy. Ānanda is the third member of sat-cit-ānanda formula.
बिस्रस्तमेणी:
# बिस्रस्तमेणी
**Transliteration**: bi-sras-ta-me-ṇī
**POS**: compound adjective (feminine nominative singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of विस्रस्तमेखला (visrasta-mekhalā) or similar compound
- वि (vi) "apart, asunder" + √स्रंस् (sraṃs) "to fall, to slip, to loosen" + त (ta) past participle = विस्रस्त (visrasta) "fallen, loosened, disheveled" + मेखला (mekhalā) "girdle, belt" or मेणी (meṇī) may be variant/corruption
- Bahuvrīhi compound: "one whose X is visrasta (loosened)"
- Note: Standard would be विस्रस्तमेखला; बिस्रस्तमेणी shows ब for व variant and possibly textual variation in second member

**Meanings**:
- Literal: having loosened girdle/belt, with disheveled appearance, with fallen/loosened ornaments or hair braids
- Contextual: describes a state of disarray or absorption where conventional grooming and decorum are abandoned; in ascetic or yogic contexts, visrasta-appearance indicates complete disregard for worldly concerns and social conventions; can describe yogis, renouncers, or devotees in states of ecstatic absorption (samādhi, bhāva) who are oblivious to physical appearance; also used in poetic/narrative contexts to describe women in states of emotional distress, passion, or spiritual fervor
- Symbolic: represents transcendence of ego-concerns including self-presentation; symbolizes the state where consciousness is so absorbed in truth that bodily appearance becomes irrelevant; embodies freedom from vanity and social conformity

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bisrasta-meṇī" appears to be variant of "visrasta-X" (विस्रस्त-X) with ब for व. Root: वि (vi, apart) + √स्रंस् (sraṃs, to fall/slip) + -ta (past participle) = visrasta (fallen, loosened, disheveled). Pattern: visrasta-X = "having loosened/fallen X": visrasta-veṣa (disheveled dress), visrasta-keśa (loose hair). The second member "meṇī" may be regional/variant form. Related: vyasta (scattered), vikṣipta (disturbed), mukta (released). Mnemonic: vi (apart) + srasta (fallen/loosened) → disheveled appearance. In spiritual context: indicates absorption beyond concern for appearance. Often describes yogis or ecstatic devotees.
बीचितरङ्गन्यायेन:
# बीचितरङ्गन्यायेन
**Transliteration**: vī-ci-ta-raṅ-ga-nyā-ye-na
**POS**: compound noun phrase (masculine instrumental singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a compound with instrumental ending:
- वीचितरङ्गन्याय (vīci-taraṅga-nyāya) "the principle/maxim of waves and ripples" + एन (ena) instrumental singular ending
- वीचि (vīci) "wave" + तरङ्ग (taraṅga) "ripple, wave" + न्याय (nyāya) "principle, maxim, logical rule"
- Dvandva compound वीचितरङ्ग (vīci-taraṅga) "waves and ripples" + tatpuruṣa with न्याय: "the principle of waves-and-ripples"
- Instrumental: वीचितरङ्गन्यायेन (vīci-taraṅga-nyāyena) "by the wave-ripple principle, through the maxim of waves and ripples"
- Note: बीचितरङ्गन्यायेन shows ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: by the principle of waves and ripples, through the maxim of wave-like movements, according to the wave-ripple analogy
- Contextual: in Vedantic and yogic philosophy, the vīci-taraṅga-nyāya is an illustration used to explain the relationship between consciousness and its modifications; just as waves (vīci) and ripples (taraṅga) are not different from the ocean but are movements within it, so too thoughts, emotions, and perceptions are movements (vṛtti) within consciousness, not separate from it; this nyāya teaches that mental phenomena are like waves—they arise, exist briefly, and subside back into the ocean of awareness; used in Yoga Vasishtha and Advaita texts to illustrate non-difference between mind-modifications and pure consciousness
- Symbolic: represents the teaching that all phenomena are movements within the one reality; symbolizes the dynamic yet non-separate nature of manifestation; embodies the principle that diversity does not negate underlying unity

**Learning Tip**:
- "Vīci-taraṅga-nyāyena" (वीचितरङ्गन्यायेन) with ब for व variant. Compound: vīci (wave) + taraṅga (ripple/wave) + nyāya (principle/maxim) + instrumental -ena. Vīci (वीचि) = wave. Taraṅga (तरङ्ग) = ripple, wave, undulation. Nyāya (न्याय) = principle, maxim, logical rule, analogy. Pattern: X-nyāya = "the principle/maxim of X" used as illustrative examples: rajju-sarpa-nyāya (rope-snake analogy), ghaṭākāśa-nyāya (pot-space analogy). Instrumental -ena = "by means of, through, according to." Mnemonic: vīci-taraṅga (waves-ripples) + nyāya (principle) → the wave-ripple principle/analogy. Teaching: just as waves are not separate from ocean, mental modifications (vṛtti) are not separate from consciousness (cit). Classic Vedantic illustration.
बुद्धीन्द्रिय:
# बुद्धीन्द्रिय
**Transliteration**: bud-dhīn-dri-ya
**POS**: noun (neuter)

**Root Analysis**:
- This appears to be a variant or error for ज्ञानेन्द्रिय (jñānendriya) "knowledge-sense" or बुद्धि (buddhi) + इन्द्रिय (indriya)
- If बुद्धीन्द्रिय (buddhīndriya): बुद्धि (buddhi) "intellect, intelligence" (from √बुध् budh "to awaken, to know") + इन्द्रिय (indriya) "sense organ, faculty" = "intellect-organ, cognitive faculty"
- इन्द्रिय (indriya) from इन्द्र (indra) "chief, lord" + य (ya) suffix = "belonging to Indra, chief faculty"
- Note: Standard term is ज्ञानेन्द्रिय (jñānendriya) "knowledge-sense" not buddhīndriya

**Meanings**:
- Literal: cognitive faculty, intellect-organ, knowledge-sense (non-standard term; likely means jñānendriya)
- Contextual: in Sāṃkhya and Yoga psychology, the five jñānendriyas (knowledge-senses) are the organs of perception: śrotra (ear/hearing), tvak (skin/touch), cakṣus (eye/sight), rasanā (tongue/taste), ghrāṇa (nose/smell); these are distinguished from the five karmendriyas (action-organs): vāk (speech), pāṇi (hand), pāda (foot), pāyu (excretory), upastha (reproductive); if buddhīndriya is intended, it may conflate buddhi (intellect) with the sense-organs, though buddhi is technically separate as the determinative faculty
- Symbolic: represents the gateways through which consciousness receives information about the external world; the instruments of knowing

**Learning Tip**:
- "Buddhīndriya" (बुद्धीन्द्रिय) appears non-standard. Standard terms: jñānendriya (ज्ञानेन्द्रिय) = knowledge-sense (5 senses of perception). Buddhi (बुद्धि) = intellect (from √budh, to awaken/know). Indriya (इन्द्रिय) = sense organ, faculty. Five jñānendriyas: (1) śrotra (ear), (2) tvak (skin), (3) cakṣus (eye), (4) rasanā (tongue), (5) ghrāṇa (nose). Opposite: karmendriya (कर्मेन्द्रिय) = action-organ (5 organs of action). In Sāṃkhya: 11 indriyas total = 5 jñānendriyas + 5 karmendriyas + 1 manas (mind). Buddhi is separate from indriyas as the determinative faculty. Mnemonic: jñāna (knowledge) + indriya (sense) → knowledge-sense = organ of perception. May be textual variant or conflation.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: The jñānendriyas (if this is what's meant) are the five subtle sense-faculties in Sāṃkhya cosmology; they evolve from the tanmātras (subtle elements) and enable the jīva (individual soul) to perceive the manifest world; distinct from gross physical organs, indriyas are subtle faculties; buddhi itself is a higher tattva—the determinative intellect that processes sense-data
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: Control of indriyas is central to yoga practice; pratyāhāra (sense-withdrawal) is the fifth of Patañjali's eight limbs; involves withdrawing the senses from objects (viṣaya) like a tortoise withdrawing its limbs; mastery over indriyas prevents dissipation of consciousness and enables concentration; indriyas are associated with specific cakras and nāḍīs in tantric physiology
- **Dharmic Significance**: The indriyas are the instruments through which the jīva experiences bondage and, when mastered, liberation; uncontrolled indriyas chase after sense-objects (viṣaya) creating attachment (rāga) and aversion (dveṣa); viveka (discrimination) requires control of indriyas; Kaṭha Upaniṣad uses the chariot metaphor: Ātman is the master, buddhi is the charioteer, manas the reins, indriyas the horses
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Sāṃkhya-kārikā enumerates the tattvas including indriyas; Yoga Sūtra discusses indriya-jaya (mastery of senses) and pratyāhāra; Kaṭha Upaniṣad and Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad describe the hierarchy: Ātman > buddhi > manas > indriyas > viṣayas
बुद्धीन्द्रियाणि:
# बुद्धीन्द्रियाणि
**Transliteration**: bud-dhīn-dri-yā-ṇi
**POS**: noun (neuter nominative/accusative plural)

**Root Analysis**:
- This is the plural form of बुद्धीन्द्रिय (buddhīndriya) - see previous entry
- More likely intended as ज्ञानेन्द्रियाणि (jñānendriyāṇi), plural of ज्ञानेन्द्रिय (jñānendriya)
- बुद्धीन्द्रिय (buddhīndriya) stem + आनि (āni) neuter nominative/accusative plural ending = बुद्धीन्द्रियाणि (buddhīndriyāṇi) "the cognitive faculties, the knowledge-senses"
- Note: Standard term would be ज्ञानेन्द्रियाणि (jñānendriyāṇi)

**Meanings**:
- Literal: the cognitive faculties, the knowledge-senses, the organs of perception (plural)
- Contextual: refers to the five jñānendriyas (knowledge-senses) collectively as subjects or objects in a sentence; the pañca-jñānendriyāṇi (five knowledge-senses) are: (1) śrotra (ear, organ of hearing), (2) tvak (skin, organ of touch), (3) cakṣus (eye, organ of sight), (4) rasanā (tongue, organ of taste), (5) ghrāṇa (nose, organ of smell); these receive the corresponding tanmātras (subtle elements): śabda (sound), sparśa (touch), rūpa (form/color), rasa (taste), gandha (smell); in yoga practice, control and withdrawal of these indriyas is essential for meditation
- Symbolic: represent the five gateways through which consciousness flows outward toward objects; the instruments that create the illusion of external world when uncontrolled; when mastered, become tools for Self-realization

**Learning Tip**:
- "Buddhīndriyāṇi" (बुद्धीन्द्रियाणि) is plural of buddhīndriya. Likely means jñānendriyāṇi (ज्ञानेन्द्रियाणि) = the five knowledge-senses. Nominative/accusative plural neuter: -āṇi ending. The pañca-jñānendriyas (5 knowledge-senses): (1) śrotra/śravaṇa (श्रोत्र, ear/hearing), (2) tvak/sparśana (त्वक्, skin/touch), (3) cakṣus/darśana (चक्षुस्, eye/sight), (4) jihvā/rasanā (जिह्वा/रसना, tongue/taste), (5) ghrāṇa (घ्राण, nose/smell). Each receives its tanmātra (subtle element). Mnemonic device: "Ears Touch Eyes Taste Nose" → Śrotra-Tvak-Cakṣus-Rasanā-Ghrāṇa. These 5 + manas (mind) + 5 karmendriyas (action-organs) = 11 indriyas. Pratyāhāra = withdrawal of these from viṣayas (objects).
बृणोते:
# बृणोते
**Transliteration**: bṛ-ṇo-te
**POS**: verb (3rd person singular, present middle voice, ātmanepada)

**Root Analysis**:
- √वृ (vṛ) "to choose, to select, to cover" (also written √बृ bṛ in some texts) + नोते (note) 3rd person singular present middle ending = वृणोते/बृणोते (vṛṇote/bṛṇote) "he/she/it chooses for oneself, selects, prefers"
- Middle voice (ātmanepada) indicates action done for one's own benefit or interest
- Present tense class IX (kryādi-gaṇa) conjugation
- Note: बृणोते shows ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: he/she/it chooses, selects, picks, prefers, elects (for oneself)
- Contextual: in Vedic and classical texts, vṛ/bṛ (to choose) appears in contexts of deliberate selection or preference; the middle voice emphasizes that the choice is made for one's own benefit or according to one's own will; used in spiritual contexts for choosing the path of dharma, selecting a guru, or preferring wisdom over ignorance; Kaṭha Upaniṣad famously contrasts preyas (the pleasant) which fools choose vs. śreyas (the good) which the wise choose
- Symbolic: represents the power of free will and discrimination (viveka); symbolizes consciousness's capacity to choose its direction; embodies the teaching that spiritual progress requires deliberate choice

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bṛṇote" is variant of "vṛṇote" (वृणोते) with ब for व. Root: √वृ (vṛ) = to choose, to select, to prefer. Class IX verb (kryādi). Middle voice (ātmanepada) 3rd singular present: vṛṇote = "he/she chooses (for self)." Active voice would be vṛṇāti. Related: vara (choice, boon, best), varaṇa (choosing), vṛta (chosen). Pattern: middle voice emphasizes self-benefit. Kaṭha Upaniṣad II.2: "śreyo hi dhīro 'bhibhavatyapramatto / mūḍhaḥ kāmānām anu vṛṇīte" (the wise man chooses the good; the fool follows desires). Mnemonic: vṛṇote → chooses for oneself. Conjugation: vṛṇomi (I choose), vṛṇoṣi (you choose), vṛṇote (he chooses), etc.
बृत्त:
# बृत्त
**Transliteration**: bṛt-ta
**POS**: past participle — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of वृत्त (vṛtta)
- √वृत् (vṛt) "to turn, to revolve, to happen, to exist, to behave" + त (ta) past participle suffix = वृत्त (vṛtta) "turned, revolved, happened, occurred, existed, behaved"
- Note: Standard is वृत्त; बृत्त shows ब for व variant

**Meanings**:
- Literal: turned, revolved, occurred, happened, existed, passed, behaved, conducted oneself, come to pass, established
- Contextual: in narrative and philosophical texts, vṛtta describes events that have occurred or states that have come into being; "yathā vṛttam" (as it happened) introduces accounts of past events; in ethical contexts, vṛtta refers to conduct, behavior, or way of life; su-vṛtta (well-conducted) vs. dur-vṛtta (ill-conducted); vṛtta also means circular, round (from the "turning" sense); in prosody, vṛtta refers to metrical patterns (as opposed to free verse)
- Symbolic: represents the actualized, the manifest, that which has come into existence from potential; symbolizes the dynamic nature of reality which is constantly "turning" (vṛt)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bṛtta" is variant of "vṛtta" (वृत्त) with ब for व. Root: √वृत् (vṛt) = to turn, to happen, to exist. Past participle -ta: vṛt + ta = vṛtta (turned, happened). Multiple meanings: (1) occurred, happened (yathā vṛttam = as it happened); (2) behaved, conducted (su-vṛtta = well-behaved); (3) circular, round (vṛtta-maṇḍala = circular disc); (4) metrical verse (vṛtta-chandas = metrical poetry). Related: vṛtti (activity, mode, fluctuation), pravṛtti (engagement, activity), nivṛtti (cessation, withdrawal). Mnemonic: vṛt (turn/happen) + -ta (done) → that which has turned/happened = occurred, established. Common in "iti vṛttam" (thus it happened) in narratives.
बृह:
# बृह
**Transliteration**: bṛh
**POS**: verbal root (dhātu) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of √बृह् (bṛh), more commonly √बृंह् (bṛṃh) or √वृह् (vṛh)
- √बृह्/बृंह् (bṛh/bṛṃh) "to grow, to increase, to expand, to strengthen, to make great" — fundamental verbal root
- Not derived from a smaller root; this IS the fundamental root from which many words derive
- Note: बृह shows variant spelling; standard forms include बृह्, बृंह्, वृह्

**Meanings**:
- Literal: to grow, to increase, to expand, to become great, to strengthen, to enlarge, to magnify, to swell
- Contextual: in Vedic and Upaniṣadic literature, √bṛh represents the principle of expansion and growth—both physical and spiritual; the root appears in बृहत् (bṛhat, great, vast), ब्रह्मन् (brahman, the infinite expanding reality), बृहस्पति (bṛhaspati, lord of expansion/prayer); in spiritual contexts, bṛh refers to the expansion of consciousness toward infinity; the process of spiritual growth (ādhyātmika-vṛddhi) is bṛh; Brahman is so named because it eternally expands (bṛṃhate) or because it makes all things grow
- Symbolic: represents the fundamental cosmic principle of expansion from point to infinity; symbolizes consciousness's nature to grow and encompass all; embodies the teaching that reality is not static but ever-expanding (nitya-vṛddhi)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bṛh" (बृह) is variant of √बृह्/√बृंह् (bṛh/bṛṃh) = to grow, to expand. One of the most important Vedic roots! Derivatives: bṛhat (बृहत्, great, vast), brahman (ब्रह्मन्, the Absolute—"that which expands"), bṛhaspati (बृहस्पति, lord of expansion = Jupiter/guru of gods), bṛṃhaṇa (बृंहण, strengthening, nourishing). Meaning: to grow, increase, expand, strengthen. Brahman is called brahman because it bṛṃhate (expands infinitely) or bṛṃhayati (makes all things grow). Related to English "bright" (through expansion of light). Mnemonic: bṛh → expansion/growth → gives Brahman (the ever-expanding reality). Master this root to understand countless Vedic terms!

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: √Bṛh represents the fundamental cosmic principle of expansion; Brahman itself is derived from this root, indicating that ultimate reality is characterized by infinite expansion (ananta-vistāra); the universe's expansion from bindu (point) to viśva (all) is the activity of bṛh; in Vedic cosmology, creation is bṛṃhaṇa (expansion) from the unmanifest, and dissolution is saṃhāra (contraction) back to the source; the root embodies the dynamic, ever-growing nature of existence
- **Energetic/Yogic Application**: In spiritual practice, bṛh represents the expansion of consciousness beyond limited ego-identification; meditation practices aim at citta-vistāra (expansion of mind) through bṛh; as awareness expands (bṛṃhate), it encompasses more until it realizes its identity with infinite Brahman; prāṇāyāma practices involve bṛṃhaṇa (expansion) of prāṇa; the goal is mahattva (greatness) achieved through continuous bṛh
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Bṛhaspati (Jupiter, guru of the gods) is the deity of this root—he who makes wisdom expand; Brahman as ब्रह्मन् (neuter) derives from √bṛh; the Vedic goddess Bṛhatī personifies expansion; all deities in their cosmic (virāṭ) forms embody bṛh
- **Mantric Significance**: The syllable BṚṂ contains the root bṛh and is used as bīja for expansion and growth; Gāyatrī mantra addresses Savitr to expand (bṛṃhaya) our wisdom; many Vedic mantras invoke deities to bṛṃhayat (strengthen, increase) devotees
- **Dharmic Significance**: Brahman is fundamentally defined by √bṛh—it is that which is ever-expanding, limitless, infinite; spiritual evolution is the bṛh (expansion) of limited individual awareness (jīva) until it recognizes its infinite nature (Brahman); mokṣa is the ultimate bṛh where all limitations dissolve into boundlessness; the teaching is that consciousness naturally expands when obstacles (āvaraṇa) are removed
- **Symbolic Representation**: Represented by expanding circles, ripples spreading outward, the universe emanating from a point; the cosmic egg (hiraṇya-garbha) expanding into manifest creation; symbols of growth like trees, flames reaching upward
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Ṛg Veda uses bṛh extensively; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa etymologizes brahman from √bṛh; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad (named for its "great" bṛhat forest teaching) explores Brahman; Taittirīya Upaniṣad describes Brahman as that from which all beings bṛṃhante (grow); etymological discussions in all major Vedantic commentaries
बृहत्:
# बृहत्
**Transliteration**: bṛ-hat
**POS**: adjective (all genders) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of बृहत् (bṛhat), more commonly written as बृहत्
- √बृह्/बृंह् (bṛh/bṛṃh) "to grow, to expand" + अत् (at) participial suffix = बृहत् (bṛhat) "great, large, vast, high, tall, wide, expansive, abundant"
- Present participle form used as adjective
- Note: बृहत् is standard; variant spellings exist

**Meanings**:
- Literal: great, large, vast, big, high, tall, wide, broad, expansive, abundant, extensive, mighty, lofty
- Contextual: in Vedic and Upaniṣadic texts, bṛhat is a key term describing the infinite, unlimited, all-encompassing nature of Brahman and cosmic realities; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad is named for the "great forest" (bṛhat āraṇyaka) teaching; bṛhat describes the vastness of cosmic space, the magnitude of divine power, the infinity of consciousness; opposite of aṇu (atomic, minute); used to describe anything that transcends ordinary human scale or comprehension; in Sāma Veda, Bṛhat is a specific sāman (chant)
- Symbolic: represents infinity, boundlessness, the unlimited nature of ultimate reality; symbolizes that which cannot be measured or contained; embodies the teaching that Brahman is beyond all limits (asaṅkhyeya)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bṛhat" (बृहत्) = great, vast, large. From √बृह् (bṛh, to expand). Participial form ending in -at/-vat. Declined irregularly: strong stem bṛhat-, weak stem bṛhat-/bṛhad-. Neuter nom/acc: bṛhat (great). Masculine nom: bṛhān. Related: brahman (ब्रह्मन्, the vast/infinite), bṛhaspati (बृहस्पति, lord of the vast). Opposite: aṇu (अणु, atomic, minute), kṣudra (क्षुद्र, small). Famous Upaniṣad: Bṛhadāraṇyaka (great forest teaching). Sāma chant: Bṛhat-sāman. Pattern: bṛhat-X = "the great X": bṛhad-devatā (great deity), bṛhad-vrata (great vow). Mnemonic: bṛh (expand) + -at (participial) → great/vast/expanding. Describes Brahman's infinity.
बृहत्तरकर्णं:
# बृहत्तरकर्णं
**Transliteration**: bṛ-hat-ta-ra-kar-ṇaṁ
**POS**: compound adjective (masculine accusative singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of बृहत्तरकर्णम् (bṛhattara-karṇam)
- बृहत् (bṛhat) "great, large" + तर (tara) comparative suffix = बृहत्तर (bṛhattara) "greater, larger" + कर्ण (karṇa) "ear" = बृहत्तरकर्ण (bṛhattara-karṇa) "having greater ears, larger-eared"
- Accusative singular: बृहत्तरकर्णम् (bṛhattara-karṇam)
- Bahuvrīhi compound: "one who has (bṛhattara) greater ears (karṇa)"
- Note: बृहत्तरकर्णं shows variant spelling

**Meanings**:
- Literal: having greater ears, having larger ears, larger-eared, with bigger ears (describing someone or something)
- Contextual: likely appears in narrative or descriptive passages describing physical characteristics; may describe animals (elephants, rabbits, donkeys have large ears) or mythological beings; in some contexts, large ears symbolize good listening capacity or receptivity to teaching; śravaṇa (hearing) is the first step in Vedantic sādhana, so symbolic "large ears" might indicate openness to wisdom; could also be purely descriptive in stories
- Symbolic: may represent enhanced capacity for receiving knowledge through śravaṇa (hearing/listening); symbolizes receptivity to spiritual teaching

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bṛhattara-karṇam" (बृहत्तरकर्णम्) with variant spelling. Compound: bṛhattara (greater, comparative) + karṇa (ear). Bṛhat (बृहत्, great) + tara (तर, comparative suffix) = bṛhattara (greater, larger). Karṇa (कर्ण) = ear. Bahuvrīhi compound describes possessor: "having greater ears." Pattern: X-karṇa = "having X ears": dīrgha-karṇa (long-eared), uccaiḥ-karṇa (high-eared, alert). Comparative -tara creates "more X": bṛhat → bṛhattara (greater), mahā → mahattara (greater). Mnemonic: bṛhat (great) + tara (more) + karṇa (ear) → having greater ears. May be literal (large-eared animal) or symbolic (receptive to teaching). Śravaṇa (hearing) is first step of Vedantic study.
बृहत्वञ्च:
# बृहत्वञ्च
**Transliteration**: bṛ-hat-tvañ-ca
**POS**: compound phrase (neuter nominative/accusative singular + conjunction)

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a phrase combining multiple elements:
- बृहत्त्व (bṛhattva) "greatness, vastness" (from बृहत् bṛhat "great" + त्व tva abstract noun suffix) + च (ca) "and"
- Sandhi: bṛhattva + ca → bṛhattvañ ca (anusvāra before ca)
- त्व (tva) or त्तव (ttva) suffix forms abstract nouns denoting quality or state

**Meanings**:
- Literal: and greatness, and vastness, and the quality of being great, and expansiveness, and magnitude
- Contextual: च (ca) "and" connects this quality to other qualities in a list; appears in enumerations of divine or cosmic attributes; bṛhattva (greatness, vastness) is one of the fundamental characteristics of Brahman or cosmic realities; used in philosophical discussions listing the essential properties of ultimate reality; often paired with other abstract qualities like nityatva (eternality), ekatva (oneness), anantattva (infinity)
- Symbolic: represents infinity and boundlessness as essential attributes of reality; symbolizes that which transcends all measure and limitation

**Learning Tip**:
- "Bṛhattvañ ca" (बृहत्वञ्च) = "and greatness." Compound: bṛhattva (greatness) + ca (and). Bṛhat (बृहत्, great) + tva (त्व, abstract suffix) = bṛhattva (greatness, vastness, the quality of being great). Ca (च) = and (conjunction, enclitic). Sandhi: bṛhattva + ca → bṛhattvañ ca (anusvāra before c). Pattern: X-tva = "X-ness, quality of being X": mahattva (greatness), nityatva (eternality), ekatva (oneness). Tva-suffix creates abstract nouns from adjectives. Mnemonic: bṛhat (great) + tva (ness) + ca (and) → "and greatness." Common in lists of divine attributes: sat-tva, cit-tva, ānanda-tva, bṛhat-tva, nitya-tva describing Brahman's essential nature.
बेतालेत्यादि:
# बेतालेत्यादि
**Transliteration**: ve-tā-le-ty-ā-di
**POS**: compound phrase (indeclinable) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a quotative compound phrase with variant spelling:
- वेताल (vetāla) "ghost, spirit, animated corpse" + इति (iti) quotative particle "thus, called, so-called" + आदि (ādi) "beginning with, et cetera"
- Formula: X-ity-ādi = "X and so forth, [categories] beginning with X"
- Sandhi: vetāla + iti + ādi → vetālety ādi
- Variant: बेतालेत्यादि shows ब for व

**Meanings**:
- Literal: vetāla and so forth, ghosts etc., spirits and similar beings, [categories] beginning with vetāla
- Contextual: a formulaic expression indicating a class of subtle beings with vetāla as the first or representative example; vetālas are a category of supernatural beings—spirits that inhabit corpses or wander as ghosts; the ity-ādi formula avoids exhaustive enumeration: "vetālas and similar beings" might include bhūtas (spirits), pretas (hungry ghosts), piśācas (demons), yakṣas, rākṣasas, and other subtle entities; used in texts discussing cosmology, occult powers, or obstacles on the spiritual path; in Yoga Vasishtha and tantric texts, such beings represent subtle-body manifestations or mental projections
- Symbolic: represents the various subtle non-physical forms of consciousness; symbolizes mental projections and thought-forms; embodies the teaching that consciousness can take countless forms beyond the physical body

**Learning Tip**:
- "Vetālety-ādi" (वेतालेत्यादि) with ब for व variant. Formula: vetāla + iti + ādi = "vetāla etc., ghosts and so forth." Vetāla (वेताल) = ghost, spirit, animated corpse (supernatural being from folklore). Iti (इति) = quotative "thus, called, so-called." Ādi (आदि) = beginning with, et cetera, and so on. Pattern: X-ity-ādi = "X and similar things." Common formula avoiding exhaustive lists. Related beings: bhūta (spirit), preta (hungry ghost), piśāca (demon), yakṣa, rākṣasa. Famous text: Vetāla-pañcaviṃśati (25 tales of a vetāla). Mnemonic: vetāla (ghost) + iti (thus) + ādi (etc.) → "ghosts and so on" → category of subtle beings. Used when discussing supernatural entities collectively.
बेदत्रयः:
# बेदत्रयः
**Transliteration**: ve-da-tra-yaḥ
**POS**: compound noun (masculine nominative singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of वेदत्रयः (veda-trayaḥ)
- वेद (veda) "knowledge, Veda" (from √विद् vid "to know") + त्रय (traya) "three, triad" = वेदत्रय (veda-traya) "the three Vedas, the Vedic triad"
- Nominative singular: वेदत्रयः (veda-trayaḥ) "the three Vedas" (as subject)
- Karmadhāraya or dvandva compound
- Variant: बेदत्रयः shows ब for व

**Meanings**:
- Literal: the three Vedas, the Vedic triad, the threefold Veda
- Contextual: refers to the original three Vedas: (1) Ṛg Veda (ऋग्वेद, hymns of praise), (2) Sāma Veda (सामवेद, chants/melodies), (3) Yajur Veda (यजुर्वेद, sacrificial formulas); in earlier Vedic period, these three constituted the complete Vedic canon; the Atharva Veda (अथर्ववेद, magical formulas) was added later as the fourth; the veda-traya is also called tray meaning "the threefold knowledge"; Brāhmaṇas, Āraṇyakas, and Upaniṣads are associated with this triad; in Bhagavad Gītā and other texts, "knower of the three Vedas" (trayī-vid) refers to learned Brahmins; the threefold division reflects different ritual functions
- Symbolic: represents the totality of revealed knowledge (śruti) in its original form; symbolizes the three modes of approaching the divine through sound: recitation (ṛc), melody (sāman), and ritual utterance (yajus)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Veda-trayaḥ" (वेदत्रयः) with ब for व variant = "the three Vedas." Veda (वेद) = knowledge, Veda (from √vid, to know). Traya (त्रय) = three, triad (from त्रि tri, three). Compound: veda-traya = threefold Veda. The three original Vedas: (1) Ṛg Veda (ऋग्वेद, hymns), (2) Sāma Veda (सामवेद, melodies), (3) Yajur Veda (यजुर्वेद, ritual formulas). Fourth added later: Atharva Veda (अथर्ववेद). Also called trayī (त्रयी, the threefold). Pattern: X-traya = "triad of X": deva-traya (three gods: Brahmā-Viṣṇu-Śiva), guṇa-traya (three guṇas). Related: trayī-vid (त्रयीविद्, knower of three Vedas). Mnemonic: veda (Veda) + traya (three) → the three Vedas. Originally the complete canon before Atharva inclusion.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: The veda-traya represents the threefold manifestation of divine knowledge (jñāna) revealed to the ṛṣis; Ṛg Veda embodies knowledge through vision/seeing (dṛṣṭi), Sāma Veda through sound/hearing (śruti), Yajur Veda through action/ritual (karma); together they encompass the three paths: jñāna-yoga (knowledge), bhakti-yoga (devotion through hymns), and karma-yoga (ritual action)
- **Mantric Significance**: The three Vedas correspond to three levels of sacred sound: Ṛg = mantra (fixed verbal formulas), Sāma = melodic elaboration (gāna), Yajur = ritual utterance (yajña-vākya); together they represent the complete spectrum of Vedic sonics; some teachings associate them with AUM's three parts (A-U-M)
- **Dharmic Significance**: The veda-traya constitutes the foundation of dharma and spiritual knowledge in Hindu tradition; study of the three Vedas (trayī-vidyā) was the traditional education of Brahmins; they are considered apauruṣeya (not of human authorship) and nitya (eternal); knowledge of veda-traya qualifies one for ritual and teaching roles; in Vedantic perspective, the three Vedas represent lower knowledge (aparā-vidyā) compared to supreme knowledge (parā-vidyā) of Brahman
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Bhagavad Gītā refers to the threefold Veda (trayī); Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad distinguishes aparā-vidyā (including the Vedas) from parā-vidyā; classical Hindu law texts (Dharma-śāstra) discuss the study of veda-traya; commentarial literature extensively discusses the three Vedas' respective domains
बेदनीय:
# बेदनीय
**Transliteration**: ve-da-nī-ya
**POS**: gerundive/potential passive participle (adjective) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of वेदनीय (vedanīya)
- √विद् (vid) "to know" + अनीय (anīya) gerundive/potential passive participle suffix = वेदनीय (vedanīya) "to be known, worthy of being known, fit to be known, that which should be known"
- Gerundive expresses obligation, necessity, or fitness
- Variant: बेदनीय shows ब for व

**Meanings**:
- Literal: to be known, worthy of being known, fit to be known, that which should/must be known, deserving knowledge
- Contextual: in philosophical and scriptural texts, vedanīya designates essential truths or realities that must be understood for spiritual progress; "ātmā vedanīyaḥ" (the Self is to be known) expresses the primary imperative of Vedanta; vedanīya indicates not just intellectually interesting but spiritually necessary knowledge; in Upaniṣadic teaching, certain truths are vedanīya—they must be realized, not just heard about; contrasts with jñeya (knowable in general) vs. vedanīya (specifically worthy/necessary to know)
- Symbolic: represents essential spiritual knowledge that liberates; symbolizes truth that demands realization; embodies the teaching that some knowledge is not optional but imperative for liberation

**Learning Tip**:
- "Vedanīya" (वेदनीय) with ब for व variant = "to be known, worthy of being known." Root: √विद् (vid, to know). Gerundive suffix: -anīya (also -ya, -tavya) expresses obligation/necessity: "should be X-ed." Pattern: √vid + anīya = vedanīya (to be known). Compare: kāryaṇīya/kartavya (to be done), śrotavya (to be heard), mantavya (to be thought). Related: jñeya (knowable), veda (knowledge), vedya (to be known, simpler gerundive). Mnemonic: ved (know) + anīya (should be) → "should be known" = worthy/necessary knowledge. Upaniṣadic formula: "ātmā vā are draṣṭavyaḥ śrotavyo mantavyo nididhyāsitavyaḥ" (the Self is to be seen, heard, thought upon, meditated upon) — series of gerundives showing obligations. Vedanīya indicates essential, not optional, knowledge.
बेदमाता:
# बेदमाता
**Transliteration**: ve-da-mā-tā
**POS**: compound noun (feminine nominative singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of वेदमाता (veda-mātā)
- वेद (veda) "knowledge, Veda" + माता/मातृ (mātā/mātṛ) "mother" = वेदमाता (veda-mātā) "mother of the Vedas, source of Vedic knowledge"
- Tatpuruṣa compound: mātā (mother) of veda (Vedas)
- Variant: बेदमाता shows ब for व

**Meanings**:
- Literal: mother of the Vedas, Veda-mother, source of the Vedas, origin of Vedic knowledge
- Contextual: an epithet for the divine feminine principle that is the source of all sacred knowledge; most commonly refers to Gāyatrī Devī, the personification of the Gāyatrī mantra, considered the mother of all Vedas; also applied to Sarasvatī (goddess of knowledge and speech), Vāc (divine speech personified), or Śakti in her wisdom aspect; the concept embodies the teaching that all revelation flows from the feminine divine principle; in some traditions, veda-mātā refers to the primordial sound (nāda) or speech (vāk) from which the Vedas emerged
- Symbolic: represents the divine feminine as the source of all wisdom and revelation; symbolizes the creative power (śakti) that manifests as knowledge; embodies the teaching that wisdom has a maternal, nurturing quality

**Learning Tip**:
- "Veda-mātā" (वेदमाता) with ब for व variant = "mother of the Vedas." Veda (वेद) = knowledge/Veda. Mātā/Mātṛ (माता/मातृ) = mother. Compound: veda-mātā = mother/source of Vedas. Pattern: X-mātā = "mother of X": dharma-mātā (mother of dharma), bhūmi-mātā (Earth Mother). Commonly refers to: (1) Gāyatrī Devī (goddess of Gāyatrī mantra), (2) Sarasvatī (goddess of knowledge), (3) Vāc/Vāk (divine speech). Gāyatrī called vedamātā because Gāyatrī mantra is considered essence of all Vedas. Mnemonic: veda (Veda) + mātā (mother) → source/mother of Vedas = divine feminine wisdom principle. Related: veda-pitā (father of Vedas, often Brahmā). The divine feminine as source of sacred knowledge.

**Metaphysics**:
- **Cosmic Role**: Veda-mātā represents the feminine aspect of Brahman as the source of all revelation and knowledge; in Śākta (goddess-centered) philosophy, the supreme goddess is the origin of the Vedas and all wisdom; she is the power (śakti) through which the formless Brahman manifests as articulated knowledge; the Vedas, though considered eternal (nitya) and author-less (apauruṣeya), are understood to have emanated from the divine mother's creative breath
- **Deity or Energy Form**: Primarily identified with Gāyatrī Devī, who personifies the Gāyatrī mantra and is worshipped as the mother of all Vedas; also Sarasvatī, goddess of learning, arts, and sacred speech; Vāc/Sarasvatī as divine speech (vāk-śakti) who spoke the Vedas into existence; in tantric traditions, Tripurā-sundarī or Lalitā as the supreme wisdom goddess; the divine mother in all her forms as vidyā-śakti (power of knowledge)
- **Mantric Significance**: The Gāyatrī mantra itself is considered the sonic form of veda-mātā; recitation of Gāyatrī is worship of the Veda-mother; the mantra begins with invocation of three realms (bhūr bhuvaḥ svaḥ) representing her all-encompassing nature; AIM (aiṁ) is the bīja-mantra of Sarasvatī as veda-mātā
- **Dharmic Significance**: The concept of veda-mātā emphasizes the nurturing, life-giving aspect of divine knowledge; just as a mother gives birth and nourishes, the Veda-mother births and sustains all wisdom traditions; this feminine principle of knowledge is to be approached with devotion (bhakti) and reverence; the student-teacher relationship (guru-śiṣya) mirrors the mother-child bond in the transmission of sacred knowledge
- **Symbolic Representation**: Depicted as a radiant goddess, often seated on a lotus or swan; holds Vedas or scriptures in her hands; sometimes shown with four or more arms representing different aspects of knowledge; surrounded by light or flames representing jñāna-agni (fire of knowledge); white or golden color symbolizing purity and illumination
- **Primary Textual Attestation**: Purāṇas (especially Devī Bhāgavata Purāṇa) describe the goddess as source of Vedas; Devī Māhātmya exalts the goddess as supreme wisdom; Gāyatrī Upaniṣad and related texts elaborate on Gāyatrī as veda-mātā; tantric texts describe the goddess as vidyā-rūpiṇī (embodiment of knowledge); hymns to Sarasvatī invoke her as mother of all learning
बेदवादिनाम:
# बेदवादिनाम
**Transliteration**: ve-da-vā-di-nām
**POS**: compound noun (masculine genitive plural) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of वेदवादिनाम् (veda-vādinām)
- वेद (veda) "Veda, knowledge" + वादिन् (vādin) "speaker, advocate, expounder" (from √वद् vad "to speak" + इन् in agent suffix) → genitive plural वादिनाम् (vādinām) = वेदवादिनाम् (veda-vādinām) "of the Veda-speakers, of those who expound the Vedas"
- Variant: बेदवादिनाम shows ब for व

**Meanings**:
- Literal: of the Veda-speakers, of the Veda-expositors, of those who advocate/teach the Vedas, belonging to Vedic scholars
- Contextual: genitive plural referring to the community or tradition of those who recite, teach, or expound the Vedas; veda-vādin can mean: (1) orthodox Vedic scholars and teachers (as opposed to heterodox traditions), (2) those who quote or cite Vedic authority, (3) ritual specialists versed in Vedic mantras; in some contexts, may refer specifically to Mīmāṃsakas (followers of Pūrva-Mīmāṃsā who focus on Vedic ritual injunctions); used to indicate possession, association, or characteristic: "teachings of the Veda-speakers," "tradition of Vedic authorities"
- Symbolic: represents the lineage and tradition of Vedic transmission; symbolizes orthodox religious authority based on śruti (revealed scripture)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Veda-vādinām" (वेदवादिनाम्) with ब for व variant = "of the Veda-speakers." Veda (वेद) = Veda. Vādin (वादिन्) = speaker, advocate (from √वद् vad, to speak + agent suffix -in). Genitive plural: vādinām = "of the speakers." Pattern: X-vādin = "speaker/advocate of X": vedānta-vādin (Vedanta expounder), dharma-vādin (dharma advocate), tarka-vādin (logician). Related: vāda (speech, doctrine, debate), vaktṛ (speaker), vācaka (expressive). Opposite: a-vaidika (non-Vedic). Mnemonic: veda (Veda) + vādin (speaker) + genitive plural -ām → "of those who speak/teach the Vedas." Refers to traditional Vedic scholars, teachers, ritualists. In debates, veda-vādins represent orthodox position citing Vedic authority.
बेदशिरः:
# बेदशिरः
**Transliteration**: ve-da-śi-raḥ
**POS**: compound noun (neuter nominative singular) — variant spelling

**Root Analysis**:
- This is a variant spelling of वेदशिरः (veda-śiraḥ)
- वेद (veda) "Veda, knowledge" + शिरस् (śiras) "head, top, summit, chief" = वेदशिरस् (veda-śiras) "head of the Vedas, crown of Vedic knowledge, supreme Vedic teaching"
- Nominative singular neuter: वेदशिरः (veda-śiraḥ)
- Tatpuruṣa compound: śiras (head) of veda (Vedas)
- Variant: बेदशिरः shows ब for व

**Meanings**:
- Literal: head of the Vedas, crown of the Vedas, summit of Vedic knowledge, chief/supreme Vedic text
- Contextual: typically refers to the Upaniṣads, which are considered the philosophical culmination and "head" of the Vedas; since Upaniṣads come at the end of Vedic corpus, they are called vedānta (end/culmination of Vedas) and veda-śiras (head of Vedas); metaphorically, the head is the highest, most important part, so veda-śiras indicates the supreme or essential Vedic teaching; sometimes specifically refers to Īśa Upaniṣad or other principal Upaniṣads; represents the pinnacle of Vedic revelation—the knowledge of Brahman
- Symbolic: represents the highest wisdom teachings; symbolizes the culmination and essence of all sacred knowledge; embodies the teaching that philosophical knowledge (jñāna) is the crown of ritual knowledge (karma)

**Learning Tip**:
- "Veda-śiraḥ" (वेदशिरः) with ब for व variant = "head of the Vedas." Veda (वेद) = Veda. Śiras (शिरस्) = head, top, summit, crown, chief part. Nominative neuter: śiraḥ. Compound: veda-śiras = head/crown/summit of Vedas. Typically refers to Upaniṣads as the philosophical crown of Vedic literature. Pattern: X-śiras = "head/chief of X": ākāśa-śiras (crowned by sky), loka-śiras (world-head). Śiras indicates supremacy, highest part. Related: vedānta (वेदान्त, end of Vedas = Upaniṣads). Mnemonic: veda (Veda) + śiras (head) → crown/summit of Vedas = Upaniṣads. The Upaniṣads are both vedānta (temporal end) and veda-śiras (hierarchical summit) of Vedic corpus. Represents jñāna-kāṇḍa (knowledge portion) as supreme over karma-kāṇḍa (ritual portion).

ब्राह्मणश्चैब:
